If this method is used for fuel and fuel products, the purchase should be based, whenever possible, on three competitive prices. 
(F)  Sole Source Purchases. The purchase of a particular good or service does not require public advertisement and competitive bidding, regardless of amount, if there is a single or sole source of supply of the good or service needed by the City. The City Council shall be informed by the Purchasing Director of all reasons making the proposed sole source procurement appropriate if the item costs more than $25,000.00. If the item costs less than $25,000.00, a record of such purchase specifying the amount paid, the item purchased and the vendor shall be made by the Purchasing Director. 
(G)  Emergency Purchases. 
(1)  The City Manager is authorized to make emergency purchases of supplies and materials in the open market for immediate delivery in actual emergencies arising from unforeseen causes including delays by contractors, delays in transportation, unanticipated volume of work, the failure to receive competitive bids from prospective bidders and other similar emergencies. 
(2)  The City Manager shall attempt to receive competitive quotations from suppliers before making said emergency purchases. The City Manager may also use competitive sealed proposals for emergency purchases. 
(3)  A report of such emergency purchases in writing shall be made together with a record of the prices secured together with a full and complete account of the circumstances of such emergency. Such a report shall be made within two working days following the date of such purchase or purchase order and shall be kept on file in the office of the Purchasing Director and shall be open to public inspection. A copy of the report shall be presented to the Council by the Purchasing Director at or before the next regular Council meeting. 
(4)  The limit for such emergency purchases shall be $50,000.00 except for emergency purchases involving the health, safety or welfare of the City residents, such as but not limited to emergency purchases for the Water Resources Department, where repairs and parts cannot wait for the bidding process or Council approval at a regular meeting. In these cases, such emergency purchases shall not exceed $200,000.00 and shall require the approval of both the City Manager and Mayor, or Vice Mayor in the absence of the Mayor. For the purposes of this section, in the absence of the City Manager, the Assistant City Manager has authority to act for and on behalf of the City Manager. 
(H)  Competitive Sealed Proposal Purchases. 
(1)  The use of competitive bids may not be practical or advantageous to the City when qualifications, experience or competence are more important than price in making a purchase. Use of the competitive sealed proposal procurement method must be recommended by the Purchasing Director and approved by the City Council before the request for competitive sealed proposals is issued. 
(2)  Competitive sealed proposals may only be used if there is more than one solution to a purchasing issue and the competitive sealed proposals will assist in choosing the best solution or if there is no readily identifiable solution to a purchasing issue and the competitive sealed proposals will assist in identifying one or more solutions. 
(3)  Competitive sealed proposals shall be used in accordance with the provisions of T.C.A. § 12-3-1207. 
(4)  Adequate public notice of competitive sealed proposals must be given. The notice method(s) used shall be the same as for competitive bids for purchases of more than $25,000.00. 
(5)  The request for competitive sealed proposals shall state the factors to be used to evaluate the proposals, including price, and shall state their relative importance in the evaluation. The request for competitive sealed proposals shall state that the evaluation shall determine whose proposal is the most advantageous to the City taking into consideration all of the stated factors. The request for competitive sealed proposals may state that price shall be separately submitted and included in the evaluation through a multi-step process. A multi-step process may include submission of pricing before or after the evaluation and any discussion of the proposals with the proposers. 
(6)  The competitive sealed proposals shall not be disclosed during the negotiation and evaluation process, which shall follow their submittal and opening, but they shall be made open for public inspection after the intent to award the contract to a particular proposer is announced. 
(7)  After the competitive sealed proposals are submitted, the City may but is not required to, conduct discussions to clarify and to assure full understanding of the proposal and its responsiveness to the City's requirements, provided that all responsible proposers whose proposals are reasonably capable of being selected are afforded fair and equal treatment. During these discussions, the City may not disclose to one proposer information derived from another proposal. 
(8)  As a result of these discussions, proposers may but are not required to be allowed to make revisions to their proposals so that the City may obtain the best and final offer from each proposer if said revisions are submitted and received before the City's intent to award to a particular proposer is announced. 
(9)  In recommending a particular proposal for acceptance, the purchasing agent shall describe the basis on which the award is made. 
(10)  Each proposer shall be notified of the proposer selected for recommendation to the City Council before the proposed City Council action. A protest by an aggrieved proposer who is not selected will be heard by the City Council if filed with the City Council, through the City Recorder, within seven days after the intended award is announced. 
(11)  Any issue raised by the protesting party after the seven-day period shall not be considered as part of the protest. The City Council may stay an award due to a pending protest without financial or other obligation to the proposer recommended to the Council. The City Council may, by resolution, adopt rules and procedures applicable to protests. 
(I)  Purchases of services from a professional. 
(1)  Contracts for services to be performed by a lawyer, accountant, architect, engineer, fiscal agent, financial advisor, educational consultant, or a similar service to be performed by a professional person or group of professional persons shall not be based upon competitive bids but upon the basis of recognized competence and integrity in accordance with T.C.A. § 12-3-1209 and other provisions of state law. 
(2)  In procuring professional services the City may, but is not required to, issue a request for qualifications ("RFQ") or/and a request for proposals ("RFP") or to help it identify individuals or firms with relevant qualifications and experiences. 
(3)  If the City is seeking architectural or engineering services and it does not choose to obtain them from an architectural or engineering service provider with whom it has a satisfactory existing working relationship or if the scope of needed services is outside the known technical competencies of the City's existing professional service providers, the City shall comply with T.C.A. § 12-4-107. 
(4)  If the RFQ or/and RFP process is used for architectural or engineering services, the purchasing agent shall seek information from any firm licensed in Tennessee relevant to their qualifications and experience relative to the scope of the work, the complexity of the work, the professional disciplines required to satisfactorily perform the work and the estimated value of the services to be rendered. The purchasing agent, or a selection committee, as specified in the RFQ or/and RFP, may interview the firm regarding the furnishing of the required services. The purchasing agent or selection committee shall then select the firm deemed qualified and seek to negotiate a contract for the needed services for compensation determined to be fair and reasonable to the City. If these negotiations do not result in a satisfactory contract, negotiations may continue with other qualified individuals or firms until an agreement is reached. 
(5)  For fiscal agent, financial advisor or advisory services to be provided to the City, a written contract must be entered into prior to, or promptly upon, the inception of the relationship specifying the services to be rendered and the costs and expenses to be covered under the contract. 
(6)  Contracts for energy related services that include both engineering services and equipment and which have as their purpose the reduction of energy costs in public facilities shall be awarded on the same basis as contracts for professional services in accordance with T.C.A. § 12-4-110. 
(J)  Water storage tank painting and maintenance. The City, in accordance with T.C.A. § 12-4-112, may use a request for proposal process for the painting and maintenance of water storage tanks and appurtenant facilities or may competitively bid such contracts. 
(K)  Terms and Conditions. 
(1)  Any and all notices, advertisements, invitations to bid or requests to propose, or other procurement method shall state that the City has and retains the power to reject any and all bids or proposals. This power shall exist whether or not expressly so reserved. 
(2)  In evaluating any bid or proposal, including those based on price competition and those using competitive sealed bids, the City may consider whether the bidder or proposer is responsible and disqualify from consideration any non-responsible bidder or proposal. A bid or proposal may be disqualified based on any of the following: 
(a)  Ability to perform the contract or to provide the material or service required; 
(b)  Ability to provide the material or service within the time specified without delay or interference; 
(c)  The character, integrity, reputation, experience and efficiency of the bidder or proposer; 
(d)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder or proposer with laws and regulations relating to the contract or service; 
(e)  The ability of the bidder or proposer to provide future maintenance and/or service; 
(f)  The terms and conditions stated in the bid or proposal; and, 
(g)  Past performance with the City by bidder or proposer. 
(3)  The City may, but only to the extent the City Attorney deems allowed by federal and state law, give preference in competitive procurements to Tennessee goods and services. 
(4)  The City shall use life cycle cost of commodities as developed and disseminated by the federal government in accordance with T.C.A. § 12-3-903. 
(5)  The City shall if required, and may if authorized by federal or state law, use energy efficiency standards in its procurement process in accordance with T.C.A. §§ 12-3-904 through 12-3-911 et seq. 
(6)  The City shall include re-refined or recycled motor oil in its specifications for competitive bids for lubricating motor oil, if any, in accordance with T.C.A. § 12-3-807 unless specialized equipment or circumstances require specialized treatment. 
(7)  The City shall not be obligated to award any contract or to make any purchase if: 
(a)  The contract or purchase would violate conflict of interest laws or the City's ethical standards policy; 
(b)  The vendor does not provide or complete all requirements for a valid City contract including but not limited to: non-collusion affidavits; illegal immigrant affidavits; payment and performance bonds; proof of insurance; retainage agreements; grants assurance certifications; drug free workplace policy certifications; proof of corporate existence and good standing; and, proof of required licenses or permits. 
(8)  Bid specifications for the purchase of chemical products shall require that the manufacturer create and maintain a material safety data sheet in accordance with T.C.A. § 6-56-307. 
(L)  Rejection of Bids and Proposals. The City Manager shall have the right to reject all submittals for a particular procurement (whether submitted as quotations, bids, proposals, or in some other format) and to authorize the reissuance (with or without revision) of the procurement. Any such rejection and reissuance may be timely appealed to the City Council in accordance with subsection (M), Protests. 
(M)  Protests. A participant in a City procurement may protest any such procurement. If the City Council is required to approve the procurement award, the decision on the protest shall be made by the City Council. If the procurement does not require City Council approval in advance of the award, the decision on the protest shall be made by the City Manager. Protests of competitive sealed proposals shall be made in accordance with subsection (H) and any resolution related thereto. Protests of procurements made by other methods shall be made in accordance with such rules and procedures as the Council made adopt by resolution. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 84-39 § 1, 09-27-84; Ord. No. 91-45 §§ 1-2, 08-15-91; Ord. No. 97-O-15 §§ 1-5, 05-29-97; Ord. No. 99-O-53 § 1, 09-23-99; Ord. No. 06-O-38 § 1, 08-03-06; Ord. No. 12-O-29 § 1, 09-27-12; Ord. No. 13-O-38 § 1, 09-26-13; Ord. No. 14-O-55 § 1, 12-11-14; Ord. No. 15-O-43 §§ 1-9, 07-30-15; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-11 - Reserved. 
Section 2-12 - Indemnity for certain officials. 
(A)  The City shall indemnify the Mayor, City Council members, City Manager, City Recorder, City Treasurer, City Judge, City Attorney, department heads, and members of the various boards, commissions and committees of the City from any liability arising out of the performance of their official duties and while engaged in the course of their employment or discharge or attempted discharge of their official duties. The City is authorized and required to provide counsel for the foregoing to defend any claims and to indemnify them from any judgment rendered against them or any one of them provided, however, that such indemnity shall not extend to any judgment for punitive damages unless such punitive damages are included in the coverage of any insurance policy issued to the City and even though such amount may be within any deductible. Such indemnity shall not extend to any judgment for damages arising out of any willful wrongdoing as such term has been construed or will be construed in the statutes of the State of Tennessee providing for indemnity to officials or employees of municipal governments. 
(B)  It is the intent of this section that, for any suit for which there is insurance coverage for the City under any comprehensive general liability insurance policy or any other policy of insurance providing coverage for the City, its officers and employees, those set forth in subsection (A) herein will be indemnified for any self-insured or deductible portion. In any suit for which there is no insurance and no immunity or qualified immunity, those set forth in subsection (A) herein shall be indemnified from any judgment rendered against them or any one of them arising out of the performance of their official duties while engaged in the course of their employment or discharge or attempted discharge of their official duties except said indemnity shall not extend to any judgment for punitive damages or damages arising out of any willful wrongdoing by any such person claiming indemnity. It is not the intent of the City by the passage of this section to waive any immunity that the City or those set forth in subsection (A) herein would otherwise have or to provide protection for any amount above the limits of the Tennessee Governmental Tort Liability Act. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 86-12 § 1, 03-20-86) 
Section 2-13 - Schedule of court costs for City Court. 
The City Judge is hereby authorized to assess court costs as follows: 
Filing Complaint ..... $2.00 
Warrant and Affidavit ..... 4.00 
Issuing Summons, each defendant ..... 5.00 
Search Warrant ..... 4.00 
Executing Search Warrant ..... 15.00 
Arrest ..... 65.00 
Docketing ..... 2.00 
Judgment ..... 3.00 
Appearance Bond ..... 2.00 
Continuance, each ..... 1.50 
Subpoena, Issue, each witness ..... 2.00 
Subpoena, Serving, each witness ..... 4.00 
Mittimus, each ..... 2.00 
Issuance of Garnishment ..... 2.00 
Notice of Trial Date, mailed ..... 2.00 
Service of Process, mailed ..... 3.50 
Abstract, Motor Vehicle Violation ..... 2.00 
Entering Order (payment hearing-forfeiture, etc.) ..... 2.00 
Jail Fee, per day ..... 8.00 
Entering Order of Appeal ..... 3.00 
Bill of Costs (furnish) ..... 2.00 
Municipal Training and Education Fee ..... 1.00 
Stay Motion and Affidavit ..... 8.50 
Forfeiture of a cash bond or other security for municipal traffic citation ..... 13.75 
Electronic traffic citation fee ..... 5.00 
Court costs from City Court may be collected in the same manner as fines. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 90-31 § 1, 07-05-90; Ord. No. 97-O-17 § 1, 06-26-97; Ord. No. 05-O-09 § 1, 03-31-05; Ord. No. 11-O-18 § 1, 06-23-11; Ord. No. 14-O-42 § 1, 08-28-14) 
Charter reference- Charter § 44, City Judge's power to impose fines and costs. 
Section 2-14 - Limitations on employee activity in City Council elections. 
(A)  An officer or employee of the City shall not use official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of a City Council election nor shall such officer or employee take an active part in managing or conducting a campaign in any Council election. Except as otherwise provided, nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit or limit a City employee's right to register and vote in any election or to express an opinion as an individual on political subjects and candidates. For the purpose of this section, a campaign for Council or Council election shall include any campaign or election for Council including the office of Mayor. Activities which are prohibited are the following: 
(1)  serving as an officer of any campaign organization in a Council election; 
(2)  serving as an officer, member, or contributor of a Political Action Committee for a Council election; 
(3)  contributing, soliciting, receiving, collecting, handling, disbursing, or accounting for contributions or other funds for a campaign purpose in a Council election; 
(4)  organizing, selling tickets to, or promoting any fund-raising activity on behalf of a candidate for office in a Council election; however, attendance is permitted; 
(5)  soliciting votes in support of or in opposition to a candidate for office in a Council election while in a uniform which would identify the individual as a City employee or while on duty as a City employee; 
(6)  using official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of a Council election; 
(7)  endorsing or opposing a candidate for an office in a Council election in a political advertisement, broadcast, campaign literature, or similar material although a yard sign may be displayed in the yard of the employee's personal residence; 
(8)  displaying one or more political picture(s), sticker(s), poster(s), or sign(s) on behalf of or in opposition to one or more candidates for the Council on a personal automobile parked at the place of employment with the City that has a cumulative size greater than 11/2 sq. ft.; and, 
(9)  displaying one or more political pictures, stickers, badges, or buttons on the employee's clothing while on duty or while in a uniform which would identify the individual as a City employee. 
(B)  Any employee violating this section is subject to reprimand, suspension, demotion, dismissal, or any combination of the foregoing according to the nature and severity of the offense. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 91-24 § 1, 05-09-91) 
Charter reference- Charter § 102, limitations on participation in election of Council. 
Section 2-15 - Abstention. 
When a member of the City Council exercises the right of abstention, the abstention shall not be considered for purposes of determining the majority vote on the question under consideration. In determining whether the question under consideration passes or fails, only the aye and nay votes will be considered. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 3; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 95-O-76 § 1, 01-18-96) 
Section 2-16 - Special Revenue Funds. 
A Special Revenue Fund shall be any fund so designated by the City's budget, or comprehensive annual financial report, or system of ledgers and accounts, or City Recorder. Any revenues earned or received in a Special Revenue Fund shall be committed to the purpose of that Special Revenue Fund unless otherwise restricted. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 3; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 11-O-16 § 1, 06-23-11) 
Section 2-17 - Budget. 
(A)  The budget approved as part of the annual appropriations ordinance may be amended so as to increase total expenditures for a Fund during the course of a fiscal year only with City Council approval as expressed by an ordinance specifically amending the budget. 
(B)  The budget approved as part of the annual appropriations ordinance may be amended as to individual line items within a Fund during the course of a fiscal year without City Council approval provided that no such amendment may increase total expenditures for the Fund. 
(C)  The City Manager may transfer money within a Fund from and between line items, cost categories and departmental budgets without City Council approval provided that no such transfer shall increase total expenditures in a Fund over the approved budget amount and provided further that such transfers are reported to the City Council at the next regular meeting and entered into the minutes. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-48 § 1, 10-01-15) 
Section 2-18 - Acceptance of funds-Property seized by law enforcement and forfeited pursuant to state law. 
(A)  The City is authorized to accept the distribution of funds from property forfeited pursuant to Tennessee Code § 39-11-701 et seq., and awarded to the City by court order in accordance with Tennessee Code § 39-11-713. 
(B)  All funds accepted by the City pursuant to this section shall be accounted for in an account or accounts specifically designated exclusively for law enforcement purposes. Such funds shall be administered in keeping with the accounting procedures prescribed by the Tennessee Comptroller of the Treasury. 
(C)  Five percent of any funds accepted by the City pursuant to this section shall be paid to the District Attorney General for the 16th Judicial District. The City shall make such payments on a quarterly basis. 
(D)  Any funds accepted by the City pursuant to this section shall be used exclusively for law enforcement purposes, provided, however, that no such funds may be used to supplement the salaries of any public employee or law enforcement officer or be used to supplant other local or state funds. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-19 , § 2, 4-19-18) 
Sections 2-19-2-35 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION 

Section 2-36 - Commission created. 
An urban environmental commission for the City is hereby created and shall be known as the "Urban Environmental Commission." 
(Ord. of 05-04-61 § 1; Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 §§ 1-2, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-37 - Composition; member term of office; compensation; removal from office; vacancies. 
(A)  The Urban Environmental Commission shall consist of nine members. The term of office shall be three years, staggered, with the term of a City Council member being coterminous with the Council member's term of office. Commission members shall be qualified voters of the City. All members shall be appointed by the Mayor with approval of the Council. 
(B)  All Commission members shall serve as such without compensation unless and until Council shall fix and provide for such compensation. Commission members may be removed by majority vote of the Council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office after a due process hearing. Vacancies occurring in the membership of the Commission by reason of removal or for any other reason shall be filled by the Mayor with the consent of the Council for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. of 05-04-61 § 2; Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-38 - Organization; chair term of office; meetings; rules and records. 
The Urban Environmental Commission shall elect its chair from among its membership and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chair shall be for one year, with eligibility for reelection. The Urban Environmental Commission shall hold at least eleven regular meetings each year. Such meetings shall be open to the public. The Commission shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations. All such records shall be a public record. 
(Ord. of 05-04-61 § 1; Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-39 - Appointment of employees, consultants; expenditures; gifts. 
The Urban Environmental Commission may recommend to the City Manager the appointment of such employees as it may deem necessary for its work. The Commission may also contract with engineers, architects, and other consultants for such services as it may require, subject to approval of the City Council. The expenditures of the Commission for compensation of employees, carrying out contracts or any other purpose, exclusive of expenditures from gifts, if any, shall be within the amounts, if any, appropriated for the purpose by the Council. No indebtedness for which the City shall be liable shall be contracted by the Commission unless such appropriation therefore is made by the Council pursuant to lawful authority and then only to the extent of such appropriation or unless the contract of such indebtedness is expressly authorized by the Council in a manner authorized by law and then only to the extent so authorized. The Commission shall have the right to accept gifts and donations for the exercise of its functions. 
(Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-40 - Budget. 
The creation of a budget by the Urban Environmental Commission is authorized, said budget to include funds from the City, federal or state grants or loans, and gifts. The budget is subject to approval by the City Council. 
(Charter § 74, budget information to be furnished to City Manager upon request; Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-41 - Duties. 
The duties and powers of the Urban Environmental Commission shall be: 
(A)  study, investigate, develop and carry out plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety, cleanliness and aesthetic influences and values of the City by beautifying the streets, highways, alleys, lots, yards and other similar places in the City; 
(B)  aid in the prevention of fires, diseases and other casualties by the removal and elimination of trash and other debris from the streets, highways, alleys, lots, yards, plots and other similar places; 
(C)  encourage the placing, planting and preservation of trees, flowers, plants, shrubbery and other objects of beauty and ornamentation in the City; 
(D)  protect song birds and other wild fowl; 
(E)  recommend plans to other agencies of the City for beautification of the City; and, 
(F)  otherwise promote public interest in the general improvement of the appearance and aesthetics of the City; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to abridge or change the powers and duties of the other commissions, departments, boards and like agencies of the City. 
(Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-42 - Public hearings. 
The Urban Environmental Commission shall be authorized and empowered to schedule and conduct public hearings. 
(Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-43 - City employees to render assistance. 
All officers and employees of the City shall render such reasonable assistance and information to the Urban Environmental Commission as may be requested by it for its work. 
(Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Section 2-44 - Reports to Council. 
The Urban Environmental Commission shall from time to time, and at least annually, submit written reports to the City Council giving information regarding its activities. The reports shall include a financial report for the previous year and a budget for the upcoming year. The reports shall contain such other recommendations as the Commission feels should have the attention of the Council. 
(Ord. No. 91-36 § 1, 06-20-91; Ord. No. 93-O-29 § 3, 08-26-93) 
Sections 2-45-2-47 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Section 2-48 - Board created; composition. 
Pursuant to the Charter and the provisions of Public Acts of Tennessee, 1929, Chapter 100, there is hereby created a "Public Library Board" in and for the City, consisting of seven members known as "Library Directors," or "Directors." 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1) 
Section 2-49 - Qualifications of members. 
The members of the Public Library Board shall be citizens of the City and persons qualified to vote in the City. Not more than one official of the City, elected or appointed, shall be a member or director of the Board. Not more than five of the members or directors of the Board appointed by the City shall be of the same sex. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1; Ord. No. 01-O-09 § 1, 02-15-01) 
Section 2-50 - Compensation. 
The members of the Public Library Board shall serve without salary or other compensation. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1) 
Section 2-51 - Election of members; term of office. 
The City Council shall elect or appoint seven members or directors to membership on the Public Library Board, three for a term of one year, two for a term of two years and two for a term of three years. All succeeding members or directors of the Board shall be elected for terms of three years. The annual election of new members or directors of the Board shall be made at a regular meeting of the City Council coming annually, as near as practicable, after the date upon which the first Board is elected or appointed as provided in this section. Every qualified person so elected or appointed to membership on the Board shall hold office for the elected term and until a successor is elected. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1) 
Section 2-52 - Removal from office; vacancies. 
Any member or director of the Public Library Board may be removed from office by majority vote of the City Council for failure to attend meetings of the Board, or for any other neglect of duties as such member or director, or for any misconduct in office. The Council shall fill vacancies occurring in the membership of the Board, whether caused by death, resignation, disability, removal from office by becoming ineligible for membership on the Board by reason of removal of residence from the City, or other reason, or for any other cause. Persons elected or appointed to fill vacancies shall serve out the unexpired term only or until a successor is elected or appointed. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 1) 
Section 2-53 - Organization. 
The Public Library Board shall meet and organize annually by electing officers and adopting bylaws and regulations. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1) 
Section 2-54 - Appointment of Librarian and assistants; powers and duties. 
The Public Library Board may appoint or employ a Librarian. The Librarian shall administer the internal affairs of the library and may appoint such assistants or employees as may be necessary upon the authority expressly conferred on the Librarian by the Board. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1) 
Section 2-55 - Employees under control and direction of Board. 
The Librarian and all assistants and employees, and the operation and administration of any library established under the provisions of this article, shall be under the supervising control and direction of the Public Library Board. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 2) 
Section 2-56 - Gifts. 
The Public Library Board is hereby authorized and empowered to accept gifts, bequests and devises of money, personal or real property to be used by it for library purposes, including the establishment, operation, administration and maintenance of a public library for the inhabitants of the City and others, as may be permitted by the Board, in conjunction with any other person, including Rutherford County, Tennessee, or any county library board that may be created by or for such county, or any established library. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 3) 
Section 2-57 - Authority of Board to encumber, transfer, and convey property. 
The title to all property acquired by the Public Library Board shall be vested in the members of the Board and in their successors in office who shall have power to convey, lease, mortgage, encumber or otherwise transfer and convey such property as it may be authorized to do by the City Council or its successors. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 3) 
Section 2-58 - Gift establishing library; name of board and public library. 
In appreciation of the initial gift made to the Public Library Board by H. T. Linebaugh, Sr., of Tampa, Florida, for the purpose of establishing, maintaining, operating or administering a public library in and for the City, and the acceptance of such gift by the Board, the Board shall thenceforth be known and designated as the "Mattie V. Linebaugh Public Library Board of the City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee," and any library established, operated, administered or maintained by the Board in whole or in part with the funds so donated by H. T. Linebaugh, Sr., shall include in its name or designation an appropriate designation or name indicating the donor or any member of his family he may designate. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 4; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1) 
Section 2-59 - Library to be free to City inhabitants; extension of privileges. 
Any library established or provided by the Public Library Board shall be free to inhabitants of the City. The Board may extend the privileges and facilities of such library to persons residing outside the City upon such terms as it may deem proper and, to that end, may contract with any county library board. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 5) 
Section 2-60 - Rules for loss or injury to property. 
The Public Library Board shall have power to make reasonable rules providing penalties for loss or injury to library property, and to enforce such rules. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 6) 
Section 2-61 - Annual report to Board. 
The Librarian of any library established, operated, administered, or maintained under the provisions of this article shall make and submit an annual report to the Public Library Board in such appropriate form and manner as the Board may designate. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 7) 
Section 2-62 - Annual report to Council. 
The Public Library Board shall make an annual report to the City Council in such form and manner as it may require. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 7) 
Section 2-63 - Annual audit. 
All library accounts of every character shall be audited annually by or under the authority of the City Council, unless such audit is expressly waived by the Council. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 7) 
Section 2-64 - Liability of City. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary that may be provided, expressly or impliedly, by any provision of this article, neither the City nor the City Council in any way obligates itself or themselves to establish, or to assist in the establishment of any library in the City, nor shall the City nor the Council in any way be responsible for the handling, investment, collection or safekeeping of any funds or property that may be donated, bequeathed or devised to the Public Library Board or to any library that it may establish, operate, administer or maintain, and neither the City nor its Council shall in any way be obligated or responsible for the operation, administration or maintenance of any such library, and neither the Board nor the individual members or directors thereof, nor appointee or employee of the Board or of its individual members nor of the Librarian or of the library assistants or employees shall have any power or authority whatsoever to make or incur any contract, liability or obligation whatsoever for or on behalf of the City or its Council, except with the express authorization and consent of the City and its Council being first provided by appropriate resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. of 11-19-42 § 8) 
Sections 2-65-2-74 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER RESOURCES DEPARTMENT AND BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 2f, adopted August 16, 2018, renamed article IV title to read as herein set out. Formerly, such article pertained to water and sewer department and board. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Section 2-75 - Department created. 
There is hereby created and established a "Water Resources Department" as a separate department of the City's government, having jurisdiction over the water and sanitary sewer systems (hereinafter referred to as "water and sewer systems"). The Water Resources Department shall be a part of the City's utility enterprises division. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , §§ 5, 6, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-76 - Board created; composition; term of office; vacancies; bond; oath. 
(A)  Board created; composition. There is hereby created a "Water Resources Board" of the City, composed of eight members, to have and to exercise general supervision and control of the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of the Water Resources Department and of the water and sewer systems of the City, including without limitation by reason of enumeration to exercise the powers and the performance of the duties hereinafter conferred upon said Board; subject, however, to the terms and provisions of this article and, subject further, to the supervision and control of the City Manager over said Water Resources Department and said water and sewer systems provided for in Charter § 97. 
(B)  Term of office. Six members of the Board shall be residents of the City appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. Their terms shall be four years staggered. The two other members shall be Council members appointed by the Mayor with approval of the Council whose term shall be coterminous with the member's Council term of office. 
(C)  Vacancies. Vacancies in the membership of the Board shall occur upon the death or resignation or removal of a member, or upon a member ceasing to be a qualified voter or elector or a property holder of the City; and a member may be removed from office, and a vacancy be thus created, by the Mayor with the consent of the Council, for incompetency or incapacity of a member to perform the duties of a member or for neglect of the duties of such member or for any misconduct of a member in the performance of duties, upon written charges being filed by the Mayor with the Council and a copy thereof being served upon such member, and upon a reasonable opportunity being afforded such member to be heard in person and by attorney upon said charges in a hearing before the Council. 
(D)  Bond; oath. Each member of the Board shall give such bond, if any, as may be required by resolution of the Council, and shall qualify by taking the same oath of office as prescribed for Council members. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 97-O-57 § 1, 11-13-97; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 1, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 12-O-14 §§ 1-2, 06-21-12; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18; Ord. No. 18-O-55 , §§ 1, 2, 10-18-18) 
Section 2-77 - Organization; quorum; meetings; compensation. 
(A)  Organization; quorum. After each subsequent appointment and qualification of a member or members to the Water Resources Board for a new term, and at the first meeting held subsequent to the appointment and qualification of such members for such new term, the Board shall again elect its chair and vice-chair and a secretary; provided, however, that the Board, instead of electing a secretary from its membership, may designate a regular or part-time employee of the Water Resources Department to serve as secretary of the Board. If any member so elected chair, vice-chair or secretary (other than a non-member of the Board designated as secretary as aforesaid), shall die or resign, or for any other reason shall cease to serve as such chair, vice-chair or secretary, the vacancy so occurring may be filled by the Board for the unexpired term. A majority of the Board shall constitute a quorum and the Board shall act by majority vote of the members present at any meeting attended by a quorum and vacancies in the Board shall not affect its powers and authority so long as a quorum remains. 
(B)  Meetings. The Board shall hold public meetings as often as may be necessary, but at least once per month, at such regular time and place as the Board may determine. Changes in the time and place of holding regular meetings shall be made known to the public as far in advance as practicable. Any regular meeting may be adjourned from time to time by appropriate entry upon the minutes of the Board, and the Board may hold special meetings at such regular place of meeting at such times and as often as may be deemed necessary, either: 
(1)  upon the call of the chair, the vice-chair or a majority of the Board and the posting, at least 12 hours prior to the time fixed for the holding of such meeting, of a copy of such call in the principal office of the Department and, when practicable, upon giving oral or written notice thereof to the members not calling or participating in the call of the particular special meeting; or, 
(2)  upon the written consent of all the members of the Board and the posting, at least 12 hours prior to the time fixed for the holding of such meeting, of a copy of such written consent in such principal office. 
The secretary of the Board and the Director of the Department, and such other personnel of said systems as the Board shall require, shall attend all regular, adjourned, and special meetings of the Board unless such attendance be excused by the Board or the chair of the Board, and the City Manager may attend such of said meetings as the City Manager may deem necessary or advisable. 
(C)  Compensation. All members of the Board shall serve as such without compensation, but they shall be allowed necessary traveling and other expenses while engaged in the business of the Board, including an allowance not exceeding $100.00 per meeting for attendance and not exceeding two meetings per calendar month, such expenses to constitute a cost of operation and maintenance of the City's water and sewer systems. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. of 04-19-72 § 1; Ord. No. 86-25A § 1, 08-14-86; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 2, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 00-O-56 § 1, 08-17-00; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-78 - Powers and duties; budget. 
(A)  Powers and duties. In addition and incidental to the powers and duties conferred upon or vested in the Water Resources Board by the provisions of Code § 2-76 or by any other provision of this article, the Board shall have and perform the following powers and duties, to wit: 
(1)  study and analyze the operations of the Water and Sewer Department and of the water and sewer systems and make recommendations to the City Council for the improved and more efficient and economical operation thereof; 
(2)  consider the need for and make recommendations to the Council with reference to the maintenance, improvement and extension of the water and sewer systems and the method or methods of financing same; 
(3)  study and analyze the present or any future or proposed water and/or sewer rates and charges, the financial requirements of the water and sewer systems, including funds necessary to pay all operating costs and expenses necessary to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds payable solely from the revenues and income of said systems or payable from such revenues and income and, in the event of a deficiency of such revenues and income, from unlimited ad valorem taxes levied on all the taxable property within the City necessary to pay the principal of and interest on any other bonds issued by the City for water and/or sewer purposes which are not expressly payable from such revenues and income but by the terms thereof are payable solely from the levy of such taxes necessary to provide the sinking funds required to be set aside for the payment of any such bonds by the resolution or resolutions authorizing such bonds and necessary to provide for the necessary and appropriate maintenance, improvement and extension of said systems, and make recommendations to the Council as to such financial requirements of said systems, and recommend any specific schedule of rates and charges which the Board considers necessary to meet such financial requirements; and, 
(4)  study and make recommendations to the Council as to the personnel required for the economical and efficient operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of the water and sewer systems; and the salary or other compensation and other terms and conditions under which such personnel shall be employed or shall work, and make recommendations to the City Manager as to the particular person or persons deemed by it suitable for employment, where the employment of such person or persons is provided for in the budget for the Department and said systems for the current fiscal year or, if not so provided for, when the employment of such person or persons is specifically authorized by the Council. 
(B)  Budget. On or before May 15 th of each year, unless such time be extended by the Council, the Board shall submit to the City Manager, for submission to and consideration by the Council, a budget for the Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of the water and sewer systems for the ensuing fiscal year, setting forth under appropriate headings the recommended itemized expenditures required for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of said systems during such ensuing year, including the amounts to pay principal of and interest on bonds payable in whole or in part from the revenues and income from said systems and maturing during such ensuing year and the amount or amounts required by the resolution or resolutions authorizing such bonds to be set aside in reserve or sinking funds for such bonds during such ensuing year and including any recommended expenditures to be made from the proceeds of bonds which the Board may recommend to be issued by the City or from tax or other funds which the Council may be requested to provide, and also setting forth a detailed estimate of the income and revenues to be derived from said systems during such ensuing year, supported by a detailed summary of the actual income and revenues from said systems during the current and the preceding fiscal years and of the actual expenditures made from such income and revenues during such current and preceding fiscal years for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of said systems, and also by a detailed statement of the proceeds from bonds and of other funds made available by the Council or otherwise to, and actually expended for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of, said systems during the current and preceding fiscal years; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be held or construed to prevent the City Manager from preparing, submitting and recommending to the Council a like budget for the Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of said systems during such ensuing fiscal year. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 3, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Charter reference- Charter § 4A, authority to purchase and operate public utility plants furnishing water; issuance and sale of bonds; sale of services; fixing of rates. 
Section 2-79 - Limitations on power and authority. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this article that may be expressly or impliedly provided, nothing in this article shall be held or construed to: 
(A)  empower the Water Resources Board to authorize or make any expenditure, unless said expenditure is provided for in the budget for the current fiscal year adopted by the City Council for the Water Resources Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of the water and sewer systems, and unless each such expenditure has not actually been previously made, or unless the Council otherwise has previously and specifically provided funds by the issuance of bonds or otherwise for the purpose of making such expenditure and has authorized such funds to be expended for the specified purpose; 
(B)  empower the Board to borrow money on the faith and credit of the City or on the faith and credit of the water and sewer systems or the income and revenues therefrom or the properties thereof or otherwise, or to give and execute any evidence(s) of any such indebtedness; provided that nothing in this clause hereof shall be held or construed to prevent the Board from authorizing or making any expenditure (not previously authorized and made), provision for which is made in the budget for the current fiscal year adopted by the Council for the Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of said systems or the funds for which have previously been specifically otherwise provided for the purpose by the Council; 
(C)  prevent the Council from reducing or eliminating any item(s) of expenditures provided for in said budget to the extent not theretofore already authorized to be made or made; 
(D)  authorize the Board in its own name, or as it may direct, to take charge of, deposit or otherwise control the deposit, withdrawal or disbursement of any of the funds of the Department and of the water and sewer systems; or, 
(E)  affect in any manner or way any contract or obligation of the City with respect to the water and sewer systems or the income or revenues therefrom or the properties thereof, nor with respect to any bonds issued in connection with such systems or obligations assumed with respect to such bonds. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 4, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-80 - Reports to Council. 
The Water Resources Board shall make an annual report for each fiscal year of the operations, receipts and expenditures of the Water Resources Department and of the water and sewer systems to the City Council and, if and so long as requested by the Council, quarterly reports of such operations, receipts and expenditures, reflecting total income and revenues of said department and of said systems and, under headings corresponding with the items in the budget for the current fiscal year of said department and systems, the expenditures authorized and/or made during the period covered by such reports. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 5, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-81 - Miscellaneous provisions. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary that may be expressly or impliedly provided in this article, it is hereby expressly provided as follows: 
(A)  all funds of the Water Resources Department and of the water and sewer systems shall be kept separate and apart from all other funds of the City and shall continue to be kept, deposited and disbursed by and in the name of the City Treasurer as at the present time, until and only to such extent as the Council may hereafter specifically authorize and direct; 
(B)  subject to the approval of the City Manager, and to the availability of funds therefor, the Water Resources Board shall contract for all services, supplies, equipment and machinery required in the operation, maintenance, improvement and extension of the water and sewer systems, but all such contracts or purchases shall be pursuant to Code § 2-10 expenditures and emergency purchases; 
(C)  the Board shall have no power or authority to lower, raise or otherwise change any rate or charge for water or sewer service or other services which may be furnished by the Department and the water and sewer systems; and, 
(D)  the Council reserves full and complete power and authority to adopt the budget for the Department and the water and sewer systems in such amount(s) as it shall determine and whether or not in agreement with the budgetary recommendations of the Board, and also full and complete power and authority over the rates and charges for water and sewer services and other services furnished by said department and said systems, but the Council will receive and give full consideration to the recommendations of the Board as to any proposed budget or schedule of rates and charges. 
(Ord. of 10-23-58 § 1; Ord. No. 84-39 § 3, 09-27-84; Ord. No. 98-O-16 § 6, 06-11-98; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 5, 8-16-18) 
Cross reference- Code § 33-1, et seq., schedule of water rates and sewer service charges. 
Sections 2-82-2-84 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRIC DEPARTMENT AND POWER BOARD 

Section 2-85 - Department created. 
(A)  Consistent with the City's Charter, in 1939 the City purchased the electric generating plant and distribution system serving the City and created the City's Electric Department as a department of the City government having jurisdiction over the electric generating plant, electric distribution system, and street lighting system (collectively, the "electric system") within and outside the City. 
(B)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary that may be expressed or implied in this article, it is hereby expressly provided as follows: 
(1)  The Council reserves full and complete power and authority to adopt the budget for the Electric Department and the electric system in such amounts as it determines upon consideration to the recommendations of the Power Board as to any proposed budget and in adherence to the City's agreement with the Tennessee Valley Authority; 
(2)  With the exception of safety policy and procedures related to specialized work on the electric system, all City employment policy and procedures will be adopted and implemented by the Electric Department unless variances are approved by Power Board. 
(C)  The Electric Department shall be a part of the City's Utility Enterprises Division. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 4, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-86 - Power Board created. 
(A)  Manner of creation. The Council, having purchased the electric system within the authority of its Charter, elects not to appoint a board of public utilities under T.C.A. § 7-52-107, and alternatively appoints a board for the electric system consistent with the Charter and this section. 
(B)  Board creation. There is hereby created a "Power Board" of the City, to have and to exercise general supervision and control of the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system of the City including, without limitation by reason of enumeration, to exercise the powers and the performance of the duties hereinafter conferred upon the Power Board by the Council. The Power Board's authority and responsibilities are subject to the terms and provisions of this article. 
(C)  Board; term of office. The Power Board shall be composed of five members, four citizen members and one Council member. 
(1)  The four citizen members shall be residents of the City appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the Council and serve four-year, staggered terms. For the initial appointment upon adoption of this article, the Mayor shall designate two citizen members to serve two years and two members to serve four years. Thereafter, each appointment will be for four years. Appointments made to fill vacancies will fill only the uncompleted term of the member vacating the Power Board. 
(2)  The fifth member shall be a Council Member appointed by the Mayor and whose term shall be coterminous with that Council member's current term of office at the time of appointment. 
(3)  Members of the Power Board serve at the will of the Council and may be removed from the Power Board by the Council without cause. 
(D)  Oath; bond. Each member of the Power Board shall qualify by taking the same oath of office as prescribed for Council members, and give such bond, if any, as may be required by resolution of the Council. 
(E)  Vacancies. Vacancies in the membership of the Power Board occur upon the death or resignation or removal of a member, or upon a member ceasing to be a resident of the City. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as appointments and the new member so appointed shall fulfill the remainder of the term of the vacating member. 
(F)  Organization. After the initial appointment of the Power Board members and at the first meeting after July 1st of each subsequent year, as its first order of business, the Power Board shall elect its chair, its vice-chair, and a secretary. Upon election, the chair shall preside for the remainder of the meeting and for thereafter during the elected member's term. The Power Board may elect to designate an employee of the Electric Department to serve as secretary of the Power Board. In the event the chair is unavailable for any reason, the vice-chair shall preside at the meeting, and in the event the chair and vice-chair are both unavailable for any reason, the longest serving member of the Power Board shall preside at the meeting. 
(G)  Quorum. A majority of the required members of the Power Board constitutes a quorum for that meeting and the Power Board shall act by majority vote of the members present at any meeting attended by a quorum. Vacancies in the Power Board shall not affect its powers and authority so long as a quorum remains. 
(H)  Meetings. 
(1)  Regular meetings. The Power Board shall hold public meetings as often as may be necessary, but at least once per month, at such regular time and place as the Power Board may determine. All Power Board regular meetings and notice thereof shall comply with T.C.A. § 8-44-101 et seq. Changes in the time and place of regular meetings shall be made known to the public as far in advance as practicable. Any regular meeting may be adjourned from time to time by appropriate entry upon the minutes of the Power Board. 
(2)  Special meetings. The Power Board may hold special meetings at such regular place of meeting at such times and as often as may be deemed necessary upon the call of the chair, the vice-chair, or a majority of the Power Board at a duly noticed meeting, the City Manager and Utility Enterprises Director, the Council member serving on the Power Board, or Council. All Power Board special meetings and notices thereof shall comply with T.C.A. § 8-44-101 et seq. Such call for a special meeting shall designate with specificity the reason for the meeting and shall be posted, at least twelve hours prior to the time fixed for the holding of such meeting, at the principal office of the department and City Hall, and, when practicable, upon giving oral or written notice thereof to the members not calling or participating in the call of the particular special meeting. 
(I)  Compensation. All members of the Power Board shall serve as such without compensation or benefit but they shall be allowed necessary traveling and other expenses while engaged in the business of the Power Board, including an allowance not exceeding $300.00 per month for attendance at meetings, such expenses to constitute a cost of operation and maintenance of the City's electric system. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 4, 8-16-18) 
Section 2-87 - Power Board powers and duties. 
(A)  Generally. In addition to and incidental to the powers and duties conferred upon or vested in the Power Board by the provisions of this Section, the Power Board shall have and perform the following powers and duties, to wit: 
(1)  Study and analyze the operations of the Electric Department and of the electric system and guide and direct the Utility Enterprises Director to make improvements for a more efficient and economical operation thereof, including the development and implementation of rules and regulations pertaining to the provision of electric service to customers and as approved by the Tennessee Valley Authority; 
(2)  Guide and direct the Utility Enterprises Director with respect to the maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system and the method or methods of financing same; 
(3)  Study and analyze the financial requirements of the electric system, including funds required (i) to pay all operating costs and expenses necessary to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds payable solely from the revenues and income of the electric system or payable from such revenues and income; (ii) to pay, in the event of a deficiency of such revenues and income, from unlimited ad valorem taxes levied on all the taxable property within the City necessary to pay the principal of and interest on any other bonds issued by the City for electric system purposes which are not expressly payable from such revenues and income, but by the terms thereof are payable solely from the levy of such taxes necessary to provide the sinking funds required to be set aside for the payment of any such bonds by the resolution or resolutions authorizing such bonds; (iii) to provide for the necessary and appropriate maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system; 
(4)  Study the financial requirements of the electric system and create the necessary schedule of rates and charges which the Power Board considers necessary to meet such financial requirements; 
(5)  Study and secure the necessary insurance to protect the assets of the Electric Department and the electric system and to protect the City against any reasonable liability related to operation of the Electric Department and the electric system; 
(6)  Study and make recommendations to the Utility Enterprises Director as to the personnel required for the economical and efficient operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system, including recommendations on the salary, other compensation, and the terms and conditions under which such personnel shall be employed or work, provided such personnel are provided for in the budget for the Electric Department and electric system for the current fiscal year; or, if not so provided for, when the employment of such person or persons is specifically authorized by the Council through a budget amendment; 
(7)  Subject to Council approval of funds budgeted therefore, authorize the Utility Enterprises Director to contract for all services, supplies, equipment, and machinery required in the operation maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system, provided, however, (i) that the Utility Enterprises Director shall have the authority to let contracts within the Electric Department's budget obligating the electric plant on purchase orders without prior approval by the Power Board in an amount set by resolution of the Power Board; and (ii) all emergency purchases by the Electric Department shall be subject to procedures set forth in Section 2-10 of the Code; 
(8)  Subject to Council approval of funds budgeted therefore, make any expenditure for the current fiscal year for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system; and 
(9)  Subject to Council budget approval and consistent with the City's contract with the Tennessee Valley Authority, lower, raise, or otherwise change any rate or charge for electric service or other services furnished by the Electric Department and the electric system. 
(B)  Limitations. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this article that may be expressly or impliedly provided, nothing in this article shall be held or construed to: 
(1)  Empower the Power Board to borrow money on the faith and credit of the City or on the faith and credit of the electric system or the income and revenues therefrom or the properties thereof or otherwise, or to give and execute any evidence(s) of any such indebtedness; provided that nothing in this clause hereof shall be held or construed to prevent the Power Board from authorizing or making any expenditure (not previously authorized and made), provision for which is made in the budget for the current fiscal year adopted by the Council for the Electric Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system; 
(2)  Authorize the Power Board in its own name to purchase, hold, or encumber any real property; 
(3)  Prevent the Council from reducing or eliminating any item(s) of expenditures provided for in said budget to the extent not theretofore already encumbered or made; or 
(4)  Affect in any manner or way any contract or obligation of the City with respect to the electric system or the income or revenues therefrom or the properties thereof, nor with respect to any bonds issued in connection with the electric system or obligations assumed with respect to such bonds. 
(C)  Budget. On or before May 15th of each year, unless such time be extended by the Council, the Power Board shall submit to the City Manager, for submission to and consideration by the Council, the budget for the Electric Department for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system for the ensuing fiscal year, which shall be prepared in cooperation with the City Manager and which shall set forth under appropriate headings: 
(1)  The recommended itemized expenditures required for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system during such ensuing year; 
(2)  The amounts to pay principal of and interest on bonds payable in whole or in part from the revenues and income from the electric system and maturing during such ensuing year and the amount or amounts required by the resolution or resolutions authorizing such bonds to be set aside in reserve or sinking funds for such bonds during such ensuing year and including any recommended expenditures to be made from the proceeds of bonds which the Power Board may recommend to be issued by the City or from tax or other funds which the Council may be requested to provide; 
(3)  Set forth a detailed estimate of the income and revenues to be derived from the electric system during such ensuing year, supported by a detailed summary of the actual income and revenues from the electric system during the current and the preceding fiscal years and of the actual expenditures made from such income and revenues during such current and preceding fiscal years for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system; and 
(4)  A detailed statement of the proceeds from bonds and of other funds made available by the Council or otherwise to, and actually expended for, the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system during the current and preceding fiscal years. 
Nothing herein contained shall be held or construed to prevent the City Manager from commenting upon or providing additional information for consideration by the Council with respect to the budget for the Electric Department and for the operation, maintenance, improvement, and extension of the electric system during such ensuing fiscal year. 
(D)  Reports to Council. The Power Board shall make an annual report for each fiscal year of the operations, receipts, and expenditures of the Electric Department and of the electric system to the Council and, if and so long as requested by the Council, quarterly reports of such operations, receipts, and expenditures, reflecting total income and revenues of the Electric Department and of the electric system and, under headings corresponding with the items in the budget for the current fiscal year of the Electric Department and electric system, the expenditures authorized and made during the period covered by such reports. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 4, 8-16-18) 
Sections 2-88-2-90 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MURFREESBORO GOLF COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 83-6 § 1, added Ch. 43 §§ 43-1 through 43-9, renumbered Art. V, §§ 2-91 through 2-99. 

Section 2-91 - Murfreesboro Golf Commission Created. 
The City golf commission created in 1983 shall be known as the "Murfreesboro Golf Commission." 
(Ord. No. 83-6 § 1, 04-21-83; Ord. No. 14-O-45 § 1, 11-06-14) 
Section 2-92 - Composition; Member Term of Office; Compensation. 
(A)  Composition; member term of office. The Murfreesboro Golf Commission shall consist of seven members, one of whom shall be a City Council member. The remaining six members shall be qualified voters of the City. A member of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve as an ex-officio member. All members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Council. Each term of a Murfreesboro Golf Commission member shall be for three years, staggered. The term of the Council member shall be coterminous with the member's council term of office. 
(B)  Compensation. All members of the Commission shall serve as such without compensation unless and until the Council shall fix and provide for such compensation. 
(Ord. No. 83-6 § 1, 04-21-83; Ord. No. 88-45 § 1, 08-11-88; Ord. No. 90-04 § 1, 01-11-90; Ord. No. 90-10 § 1, 02-22-90; Ord. No. 96-O-55 § 1, 10-10-96; Ord. No. 14-O-45 § 1, 11-06-14) 
Section 2-93 - Organization; Chair Term of Office; Meetings; Rules and Records. 
The Murfreesboro Golf Commission shall elect its chair from among its membership and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the Commission chair shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. The Commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each quarter. Such meetings shall be open to the public. The Commission may adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep minutes of its meetings. 
(Ord. No. 83-6 § 1, 04-21-83; Ord. No. 14-O-45 § 1, 11-06-14) 
Sections 2-94, 2-95 - Reserved. 
Section 2-96 - Purposes. 
The purposes of the Murfreesboro Golf Commission are as follows: 
(A)  to assist in identifying sources of funds and in the securement of funds for the construction and maintenance of golf courses and facilities; 
(B)  to recommend the selection and employment of engineers, architects, landscape architects and other consultants; 
(C)  to review and recommend plans, methods and contracts for construction for golf courses and related facilities; 
(D)  to study and recommend land for acquisition for golf courses and facilities; 
(E)  to establish fees and charges, and golf course rules, regulations and guidelines, for play and conduct on the City's golf courses by participants and other members of the public; 
(F)  to oversee the operations of the Golf Department in order to assure quality golf courses which meet the needs and protect the interests of the public; and, 
(G)  to annually recommend a budget for the Golf Department to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 83-6 § 1, 04-21-83; Ord. No. 14-O-45 § 1, 11-06-14) 
Sections 2-97-2-109 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RISK MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-8 § 1, added Ch. 45, renumber Art. VI, §§ 2-110 through 2-114. 

Section 2-110 - Committee created. 
A risk management committee for the City is hereby created and shall be known as the "Risk Management Committee." 
(Ord. No. 86-8 § 1, 04-03-86) 
Section 2-111 - Composition; term of office; compensation; removal from office. 
(A)  Composition. The Risk Management Committee shall consist of four members, one of whom shall be a Council member. All members shall be appointed by the Mayor with approval of the Council. A Committee member may be reappointed. 
(B)  Term of office. The terms of office of the three members of the Committee who are not on the Council shall be three years, staggered. The term of the Council member shall be one year but shorter in the event the member's service as Council member terminates. 
(C)  Compensation. All Committee members shall serve without compensation until the Council shall fix and provide for such compensation by resolution. 
(D)  Removal from office. Committee members may be removed by majority vote of the Council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. 
(Ord. No. 86-8 § 1, 04-03-86; Ord. No. 90-42 § 1, 09-20-90) 
Section 2-112 - Settlement of actions. 
The following authority is delegated by the Risk Management Committee: 
(A)  the City Attorney is authorized to compromise and settle any action for damages or relief sought under the Governmental Tort Liability Act provided the City Attorney has the concurrence of the City Manager on all claims under $5,000.00, and the concurrence of a majority of the Committee on all claims exceeding $5,000.00; 
(B)  the City Attorney is authorized to make payments under the workers' compensation law for temporary total disability benefits and medical benefits with the concurrence of the City Manager; 
(C)  the City Attorney is authorized to compromise and settle any action for permanent partial disability benefits and permanent total disability benefits under the workers' compensation law in an amount not exceeding $5,000.00 provided the City Attorney has the concurrence of the City Manager, and in an amount exceeding $5,000.00 provided the City Attorney has the concurrence of a majority of the Committee; and, 
(D)  the City Attorney, with the concurrence of the City Manager or a majority of the Committee, as provided in subsections (A) and (B) above, is authorized to reject offers of settlement without submission to the Mayor and Council for prior approval. 
State Law reference- T.C.A. § 29-20-309. 
Section 2-113 - Purposes. 
The purposes of the Risk Management Committee are as follows: 
(A)  promote safety in the work place for employees of the City; 
(B)  promote public safety; 
(C)  prior to compromise and settlement, review damage claims made against the City as provided in Code § 2-112; 
(D)  prior to compromise and settlement, review damage claims against officers, employees, Mayor, City Council members, and members of boards and commissions alleged to have occurred while said persons were acting within the scope and in the course of their duties for the City, as provided in Code § 2-112; and, 
(E)  recommend a budget and oversee compliance with said budget. 
(Ord. No. 86-8 § 1, 04-03-86) 
Section 2-114 - Reports to Council. 
The Risk Management Committee shall from time to time, and at least quarterly, submit written reports to the City Council giving information regarding claims and claims experience against the City. 
(Ord. No. 86-8 § 1, 04-03-86) 
Sections 2-115-2-119 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PROCEDURE FOR COUNCIL HEARINGS 

Section 2-120 - City Judge to make rulings upon request. 
When there is a hearing before the Mayor and City Council, the Mayor may request the City Judge sit and make evidentiary rulings during the course of the hearing. The City Judge will not have a vote on the matter under consideration. 
(Ord. No. 88-52 § 1, 10-27-88) 
Section 2-121 - Subpoenas. 
The City Recorder shall issue subpoenas for witnesses to appear before the Mayor and City Council. Subpoenas will be served as in civil actions in courts of law. 
(Ord. No. 88-52 § 1, 10-27-88) 
Section 2-122 - Transcript as evidence. 
When the matter under consideration has been heard by the City Recorder or City Manager and a typed transcript is available, either party may introduce the transcript in its entirety as evidence in the hearing before the City Council. Notice shall be given as set forth in Code § 2-123(B). 
(Ord. No. 88-52 § 1, 10-27-88) 
Section 2-123 - Admissible evidence; affidavits; exception; documentary evidence; notice. 
(A)  Admissible evidence. The Mayor and City Council shall admit and give probative effect to evidence admissible in a court and, when necessary, ascertain facts not reasonably susceptible to proof under the Rules of Court, evidence not admissible thereunder may be admitted if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. The City shall give effect to the rules of privilege recognized by law and to statutes protecting the confidentiality of certain records and shall exclude evidence which in its judgment is irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious. 
(B)  Affidavits. At any time not less than ten days prior to a hearing or a continued hearing, any party shall deliver to the opposing party a copy of any affidavit which the party proposes to introduce in evidence. Unless the opposing party, within seven days after delivery, delivers to the proponent a request to cross-examine an affiant, the right to cross-examination of such affiant is waived. If the affidavit is introduced in evidence, it shall be given the same effect as if the affiant had testified orally. If the opposing party requests the right to cross-examine an affiant, the affidavit may be used by the proponent in order to shorten the time for the hearing but the opponent shall be afforded the opportunity to cross-examine the affiant. Delivery for purposes of this section shall mean actual receipt. 
(C)  Exception. The Mayor and City Council may admit affidavits not submitted in accordance with this section where necessary to prevent injustice. 
(D)  Documentary evidence. Documentary evidence otherwise admissible may be received in the form of copies or excerpts, or by incorporation by reference to material already on file with the City. Upon request, parties shall be given an opportunity to compare the copy with the original, if reasonably available. 
(E)  Official notice. Official notice may be taken of: 
(1)  any fact that could be judicially noticed in the courts of this state; 
(2)  the record of other proceedings before the City; 
(3)  technical or scientific matters within the City's specialized knowledge; and, 
(4)  Codes or standards that have been adopted by the City or an agency of the United States, of the State of Tennessee, or of another state, or by a nationally recognized organization or association. 
(Ord. No. 88-52 § 1, 10-27-88) 
Sections 2-124-2-160 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - RESERVED 

Sections 2-161-2-165 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CABLE TV COMMISSION 

Section 2-166 - Commission created. 
A commission is established and shall be known as the "Cable TV Commission." 
(Ord. No. 90-14 § 1, 04-05-90; Ord. No. 08-O-52 § 1, 02-05-09) 
Section 2-167 - Purposes. 
The purposes of the Cable TV Commission are as follows: 
(A)  oversee the cable television franchise of the local cable television franchise holder for the City; 
(B)  receive complaints from City residents and assure full compliance with the terms and provisions of the local cable television franchise; 
(C)  forward complaints received from City residents to the Tennessee Regulatory Authority relative to any state cable and video franchise holder providing services within the City of Murfreesboro; 
(D)  monitor compliance and petition non-compliance issues with the Tennessee Regulatory Authority on state cable and video franchising;
