All pavements or sidewalks hereafter constructed on any street in the City shall be of uniform width with other pavements or sidewalks now located on such street. If such pavements or sidewalks vary in width, such newly constructed pavement or sidewalk shall, if reasonably practicable, be at least as wide as the widest pavement or sidewalk lying adjacent or nearest thereto. 
(Ord. of 10-21-26 § 6; Code 1949, Ch. 23 § 36; Ord. No. 10-O-05 § 11, 03-04-10) 
Sections 28-47-28-100 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WORK WITHIN EXISTING RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Section 28-101 - Rights-of-way excavation permit. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, break, excavate, tunnel, undermine, or in any manner damage any area located within the limits of a City right(s)-of-way, including but not limited to pavement, storm drainage way, shoulder, curb, sidewalk, traffic control device, public utility easement bridge, access ramp, that portion of any private driveway in the street right(s)-of-way, or other parts of a City right(s)-of-way (all hereinafter referred to as "City rights-of-way" in this chapter), or to make or cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any City right(s)-of-way for any purpose or to place, deposit, or leave upon any City right(s)-of-way any earth or excavation material obstructing or tending to interfere with the use of same, unless such person shall first have obtained a right(s)-of-way excavation permit therefor from the City Engineer, or designee, as herein provided. 
(B)  Since construction of an entrance ramp contiguous to a rollover curb (sometimes called a sloped face curb) does not require a curb cut, subsection (A) has no application to same. However, in all instances where the curb is to be disturbed, an excavation permit is required, no matter that type of curb. 
(C)  Notwithstanding subsection (A) above, ground preparation, seeding and sodding in a storm drainage easement shall not require an excavation permit. However, any other excavation or filling in a storm drainage easement shall require an excavation permit. 
(D)  Notwithstanding subsection (A) above, construction of utility service lines from the main utility line to serve a utility customer shall not require an excavation permit unless a sidewalk, curb or the paved portion of a street is disturbed. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-102 - Application. 
No right(s)-of-way excavation permit shall be issued unless a written application is submitted to the City Engineer. The written application shall state: (a) name and address of the applicant, (b) nature of the project, (c) proposed location, (d) purpose of the excavation, (e) anticipated dates of commencement and completion of the excavation, and (f) other date(s) as may be requested by the City Engineer. The application shall be accompanied by plans or drawings as deemed necessary by the City Engineer, showing the extent of the proposed excavation, the dimensions and elevations of both the existing ground prior to the proposed excavation and the proposed excavated surfaces, the location of the proposed excavation, and such other information as may be requested by the City Engineer. Each applicant for a permit must submit, in a digital format compatible with the City's geographic information system (GIS), any proposed changes to be made in its facilities on a one inch equals 100-foot drawing in plan/profile view including planimetric features (edge of pavement, building footprints, utility poles, manholes, water valves, and the like) to the extent of centerline of pavement to 100 ft. to each side including street cut so that it may be used to update the City's GIS digital base. The submission must correspond with the City's latest control points which are based on North American Datum (NAD) 83 State Plane Coordination System. The City Engineer shall have the authority to waive the filing of detailed plans and drawings if the excavation project is of such a small scale that the City Engineer determines that such drawings or plans are not necessary. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-103 - Right(s)-of-way excavation permit fees. 
A permit fee shall be paid by the applicant to the City for the issuance of a right(s)-of-way excavation permit which shall be in addition to all other fees for permits or charges relative to any proposed construction work. The right(s)-of-way excavation permits shall be $50.00 each. If work begins without first obtaining a permit, the permit fee shall be doubled, except as provided in Code § 28-113. Right(s)-of-way excavation permits shall be issued by the City Engineer or designee. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95; Ord. No. 01-O-32 § 1, 06-14-01) 
Section 28-104 - Requirement of surety bond or cash deposit. 
(A)  Before a right(s)-of-way excavation permit is issued, the applicant shall deposit with the City a surety bond, letter of credit, or surety agreement in a form acceptable to the City Engineer payable to the City. Surety bonds and letters of credit shall be submitted to the City pursuant to subsection (H) herein. The limit of the surety agreement shall be determined by the Engineering Department and the minimum running bond shall be $50,000.00. The required surety bond or letter of credit must be issued by an insurance company or bank licensed and authorized to transact business in the State of Tennessee and shall be conditioned upon the permittee's compliance with this ordinance and the right(s)-of-way excavation agreement, and shall secure and hold the City and its officers harmless against any and all claims, judgments, or other costs arising from the excavation and other work covered by the right(s)-of-way excavation permit by reason of any accident or injury to persons or property, trespass, or inverse condemnation through the fault of the permittee, or subcontractor(s), and further conditioned to require permittee to refill, restore and replace in good and safe condition as near as may be to its original condition and conformity with approved plans, to the satisfaction of the City Engineer; to restore all openings and excavations made in City right(s)-of-way, and to maintain the City right(s)-of-way where excavation is made in good condition for the period of 12 months after said work shall have been approved in writing by the City, ordinary wear and tear excepted. The 12-month period for maintenance will renew and start over with any repair of any portion of the excavation site. Any settlement of the surface within the one-year period shall be deemed conclusive evidence of defective back-filling by the permittee. The City may rely upon the information furnished by the permittee and it shall be no defense to a claim by the City against permittee or surety that the City made an error in issuing the right(s)-of-way excavation permit. 
(B)  (1)  Any owner of real estate repairing or engaging another to repair the owner's sidewalk or driveway shall not be required to give such bond or letter of credit. 
(2)  The developer of a subdivision who has posted a street bond for a subdivision requiring a right(s)-of-way excavation permit, shall not be required to post an additional bond in conjunction with the issuance of the right(s)-of-way excavation permit. 
(3)  In the event the applicant for a right(s)-of-way excavation permit is requesting a street cut in a highway maintained by the State of Tennessee and the applicant has posted a bond with the Tennessee Department of Transportation for the street cut, the applicant will not be required to post an additional bond or letter of credit in favor of the City when obtaining a right(s)-of-way excavation permit. 
(C)  Recovery on a right(s)-of-way bond, letter of credit, or surety agreement for any claim shall not extinguish same, but it shall in its entirety be available for all subsequent claims during the excavation for which it was given, plus maintenance of the excavation for which it was given, plus maintenance of the excavation site as required by this chapter and the right(s)-of-way excavation agreement. In the event of any suit or claim against the City by reason of the negligence or default of the permittee, upon the City giving written notice to permittee and surety of such suit or claim, the permittee and surety shall hold the City harmless and indemnify the City for all expenses, including reasonable attorneys fees and costs. 
(D)  Any annual bond, letter of credit, or surety agreement given under this provision shall remain in force for one year plus the one year maintenance period, conditioned as above, in the amount specified in subsection (H) herein, which is based on the permittee's anticipated work for one year and shall be applicable to all excavation in any City right(s)-of-way. Should the permittee exceed the estimate of utility cuts during the year, the permittee shall increase the bond or letter of credit to the appropriate amount based on subsection (H) herein. 
(E)  In lieu of a corporate surety bond, letter of credit, or surety agreement required above, the application may be accompanied with a cash deposit or certificate of deposit, made to the City for deposit with or holding by the City Recorder. The amount shall be determined by the City Engineer. Any municipal corporation, public utility, or government agency intending or required to make multiple openings, cuts or excavation in City right(s)-of-way, such as the telephone company, electric power distributor, and natural gas distributor may make and maintain with the City Treasurer a general deposit in an amount to be determined by the City Engineer. 
(F)  Any special or general deposit made hereunder shall serve as security for the repair and performance of work necessary to put the City right(s)-of-way in as good a condition as it was prior to the excavation and in conformity with approved plans. If the permittee fails to make the necessary repairs or complete excavation within the time specified in the permit, the City may proceed to complete same and charge the expense to the permittee and surety as provided in subsection (G) below. Upon the permittee's satisfactory completion of the work covered by such permit as determined by the City Engineer, two-thirds of any remaining deposit, except in the case of any annual deposit, shall be refunded (without interest) to the permittee and any remaining balance shall be refunded to the permittee upon the expiration of the maintenance period less all deductions. The balance of any annual deposit shall be refunded at the expiration of the maintenance period. No interest shall be paid on cash deposits. 
(G)  The City may use any or all of any deposit, letter of credit, or bond to pay the cost of any work the City performs to restore or maintain the City right(s)-of-way in the event the permittee fails to perform such work as provided in the right(s)-of-way excavation agreement or this chapter. If the permittee exposes the public to danger and fails to promptly correct same after notice (should the permittee not be readily available, the notice requirement is waived), the City may take steps deemed necessary in the sole discretion of the City to correct a dangerous situation which is a threat to public safety and charge same to permittee and surety. Once an excavation is started, it must be completed expeditiously. In the event an excavation is not pursued expeditiously after started, or is not completed within the time specified in the permit or any extension, or is abandoned, or the area is not properly restored or maintained, the City may give the permittee seven days notice of the deficiency. If corrective action is not initiated within said seven days or any extension thereof granted by the City Engineer, the City may perform the necessary work and charge same to permittee and surety. Prior notice to the surety is waived. Any permittee or surety aggrieved by any action of the City under this article is entitled to a due process hearing before the City Manager upon written notice filed with the City Recorder within ten days of the event giving rise to the complaint. When the City uses its own employees to repair a street, shoulder, sidewalk, storm drainage ditch, or public utility that should have been repaired by a permit holder, the permit holder must reimburse the City at the rate of 150% of actual costs of the City. "Actual costs" are defined as employees' actual wages and benefits, with benefits calculated at 30% of wages; rental value of equipment, signs and barricades in accordance with a uniform schedule; cost of all materials; and, any outside costs. 
(H)  The utility cut performance bonds shall be based upon an estimate of $100.00 per square yard to correct improper utility cuts. The permittee shall estimate the area of the excavation. The bond will be based on a reasonable estimate as determined by the City Engineer. Records will be monitored and should permittee exceed the estimated yardage of repairs, the permittee shall increase the bond to the appropriate amount. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95; Ord. No. 96-O-25 §§ 1-3, 03-28-96; Ord. No. 99-O-45, §§ 1, 2, 08-19-99) 
Section 28-105 - Manner of excavating-Protection of traffic and pedestrians. 
Any person making any excavation or tunnel in a City right(s)-of-way shall do so according to the terms and conditions of this article, the application, right(s)-of-way excavation agreement, applicable government regulations and codes, and the right(s)-of-way excavation permit. Barricades, signage, and lights shall be maintained in accordance with the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices to protect persons and property from injury because of the excavation. If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed to provide for safe travel for pedestrians. The permittee shall construct and maintain adequate and safe crossings over excavations and highways to accommodate vehicular and pedestrian traffic. Vehicular and pedestrian crossings shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with applicable policies, rules, regulations, and ordinances of the City and other applicable government agencies. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-106 - Reserved. 
Section 28-107 - Removal and protection of utilities. 
The permittee shall not interfere with any existing utility without the written consent of the City Engineer and the owner of the utility. If it becomes necessary to remove an existing utility, such removal or relocation shall be performed by the owner of such utility at the expense of the permittee. The permittee shall support and protect all pipes, conduits, poles, wires or other apparatus which may be in any way affected by the excavation work and do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them. In case any of said pipes, conduits, poles, wires or apparatus should be damaged, the permittee must give prompt notice to the utility owning same. The repairs, shall be by the utility owner at the expense of the permittee or surety. The permittee shall be responsible for any damage to any public or private property. The permittee shall inform itself as to the existence and location of all underground utilities before excavation and protect same against damage. The bond, letter of credit, or surety deposit provided in Code § 28-104 shall be available to pay any expense associated with utility damage or damage to the property of another. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-108 - Protection of adjoining property. 
The permittee shall at all times at the permittee's expense preserve and protect from injury adjoining property by providing proper lateral support, and other measures suitable for the purpose. Where it is necessary to enter upon private property for the purpose of taking appropriate protective measures, the permittee shall obtain permission for such entry from the owner of such private property. The permittee shall, at the permittee's expense, shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences or other property which may be damaged during the process of the excavation and shall be responsible for all damage to all public and private property resulting from the permittee's failure to properly protect and carry out said work. Whenever it may be necessary for the permittee to trench through any lawn area or storm drainage ditch, these areas shall be properly reseeded and strawed immediately following backfilling of the trench, unless otherwise directed by the City Engineer. In certain situations the city engineer may direct the permittee to sod these areas instead of seeding and strawing. All construction and maintenance work shall be performed in a manner calculated to leave the lawn, storm drainage ditch, and other areas clean of earth and debris, and in a condition as nearly as possible to that which existed before such work began. All backfill material shall be 100% compacted crushed stone, except for areas outside the limits of the roadway which shall require compacted backfill. Backfill within the limits of the City right(s)-of-way shall conform with The Standard Street Specifications. The bond, letter of credit, or surety deposit provided in Code § 28-104 shall be available to pay any expense associated with utility damage or damage to the property of another. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-109 - Excavated material. 
All material excavated from trenches and stored adjacent to the trench or in any City right(s)-of-way shall be stored and maintained in such a manner as not to endanger those working in the trench, pedestrians or motorist, and so that as little inconvenience as reasonably possible is caused to those using streets, sidewalks, and adjoining property. The material shall not be stored in a drainage way. Where the confines of the area being excavated are too narrow to permit storing excavated material beside the trench, the City Engineer shall have the authority to require the permittee to haul the excavated material to a storage site. In certain situations the City may allow the permittee to permanently dispose of the excess excavated material on property owned by the City. It shall be the permittee's responsibility to secure the necessary permission and make all necessary arrangements for all storage and disposal sites. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-110 - Clean-up. 
As the excavation work progresses, all City right(s)-of-way and private properties shall be thoroughly cleaned of all rubbish, excess earth, rock and other debris resulting from excavation. All clean-up operations at the location of such excavation shall be accomplished at the expense of the permittee and shall be completed to the satisfaction of the City Engineer. From time to time as may be ordered by the City Engineer, and in any event immediately after completion of said work, the permittee shall, at the permittee's expense, clean-up and remove all refuse and unused material of any kind resulting from said work. Notice to the surety is waived. Upon failure to do so within five days after notification to permittee, said work may be performed by the City and the cost thereof charged to the permittee, and surety. The five days notice may be reduced when circumstances reasonably dictate less time, in the sole discretion of the City Engineer, or designee. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-111 - Specifications. 
Each right(s)-of-way excavation permit shall be assigned a set of restoration specification standards. These specifications will be referenced by number and so indicated on the permit. It shall be the responsibility of the City Engineer to maintain and provide the specification standards. The permittee may request and receive a copy of the required specifications. The cost of the photocopy shall be paid by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-112 - Restoration of surface. 
The permittee shall restore the surface of any City right(s)-of-way damaged as a result of the excavation work to its original or better condition and in accordance with the specifications of the City Engineer. Noncompliance may jeopardize the permittee's future application for a permit and/or alter the requirements of future permits. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-113 - Prompt completion of work. 
The permittee shall prosecute with diligence and expedition all excavation work covered by the right(s)-of-way excavation permit and shall promptly complete such work after initiation. Permittee shall promptly restore the City right(s)-of-way and, in any event, not later than the date specified in the right(s)-of-way excavation permit. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-114 - Emergency action. 
In the event of any emergency in which a sewer, water main, electric conduit, gas line or other utility is damaged or breaks and causes imminent danger to the property, life, health, or safety of any individual, the person owning or controlling the damaged utility shall immediately take proper emergency measures to cure or remedy the dangerous condition without applying for and obtaining a right(s)-of-way excavation permit hereunder. However, such utility shall apply for a right(s)-of-way excavation permit not later than the end of the next succeeding business day during which the City Engineer's office is open for business and shall not proceed with permanent repairs without first obtaining a right(s)-of-way excavation permit hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-115 - Inspections. 
The City Engineer or designee shall make such inspections as are reasonably necessary for enforcement of this article. The City Engineer shall have the authority to promulgate and cause to be in force such rules and regulations as may be reasonably necessary to enforce and carryout the intent of this chapter. The City Engineer shall present such rules to the City Council for prior approval by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-116 - Liability of city. 
This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the City, City officials, or employees any liability for damages to any person injured by the performance of any excavation work for which a right(s)-of-way excavation permit is issued hereunder; nor shall the City, City officials, or employees be deemed to have assumed any such liability, or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized hereunder, the issuance of any permit, or the approval of any excavation work. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-117 - Insurance. 
In addition to all other requirements, each person applying for a right(s)-of-way excavation permit shall file a certificate of insurance indicating that the applicant is insured against claims for damages for personal injury and property damage which may arise from or out of the performance of the work, whether such performance by the applicant, subcontractor, or anyone directly or indirectly employed by the applicant. Such insurance shall cover collapse, explosive hazards, and work in a public street right(s)-of-way, and shall include protection against liability arising from completed operations. The insurance limits shall be prescribed by the City Engineer in accordance with the nature of the risk; provided, however, the liability insurance limits for bodily injury shall not be in an amount less than $500,000.00 for each person and $500,000.00 for each accident and for property damages an amount not less than $100,000.00. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a governmental agency or municipal corporation that is self-insured is exempt from this provision. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-118 - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, public or private utility violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subjected to the provisions of Code § 1-8 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Section 28-119 - Applicability to public utilities. 
The Murfreesboro Water and Sewer Department and Murfreesboro Electric Department are required to make application for permits under this chapter, but payment of permit fees and posting of bonds or cash deposits are hereby waived. 
(Ord. No. 95-O-13 § 2, 12-07-95) 
Chapter 29 - SUBDIVISIONS, MAPS AND PLATS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ch. 22, Planning Commission; Ch. 28, streets and sidewalks; Ch. 33, water and sewers; Appendix A, zoning. 

Section 29-1 - Purpose. 
The subdivision of land and the extensions and improvements to streets and utilities are important to the public interest in that the maintenance of public services becomes a public responsibility and the correction of defects is costly and difficult. It is therefore to the interest of the public, the developer, and the future owners that improvements be conceived, designed and developed in accordance with sound rules and proper minimum standards. In support of this purpose, the Planning Commission shall adopt and from time to time amend regulations concerning the process for the development and construction of subdivisions within the City, including specifications for the construction of streets, sidewalks and other public infrastructure. When the word "streets" is used in this section it shall have the same meaning as when it is used in the Subdivision Regulations and Street Design Specifications, as amended. Such regulations and specifications shall have the full force and effect authorized by state law and the City Charter. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 1; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 1, 03-04-10) 
Section 29-2 - Dedication, acceptance, and ownership of streets and public infrastructure. 
(A)  Dedication, acceptance and liability. 
(1)  Streets and related public infrastructure (including but not limited to water, repurified water, sanitary sewer and storm water facilities) shall be dedicated for public use when a final plat of the subdivision of land shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Planning Commission and recorded with the Register of Deeds. 
(2)  The City shall not accept the dedication of streets and related public infrastructure (including but not limited to water, repurified water, sanitary sewer and storm water facilities) until all requirements of the Subdivision Regulations and Street Design Specifications, the Murfreesboro Water and Sewer Department Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, and any specific requirements of any Development Agreement, have been satisfied, including all required testing and inspections. From and after the effective date of this ordinance, written notice of acceptance of construction sent to the developer by the City shall be the only method by which the City accepts dedication; the City will not accept dedication by implication through public use. 
(3)  Liability for claims of personal injury or property damages arising from claims of improper construction or maintenance of streets and related public infrastructure shall be that of the developer rather than the City until the dedication of such streets and related public infrastructure to the City has been accepted by the City sending written notice of acceptance of construction to the developer. 
(B)  Ownership. 
(1)  Streets and related public infrastructure (including but not limited to water, repurified water, sanitary sewer and stormwater facilities) lying within the boundaries of any recorded plat of any subdivision, or lying partly within the boundaries of any such street and partly within the boundaries of any lot or lots in such subdivision, shall be and become the property of the City if and when the City sends written notice of acceptance of construction to the developer and thereby accepts the developer's public dedication of such streets and related public infrastructure. 
(2)  It shall be a condition for the approval of any plat of any subdivision by the Planning Commission, and for the contributions made by the City to the laying of water mains and sanitary sewer lines and towards the surfacing of streets, as herein provided for, that the developer shall consent to the ownership of such facilities being vested in the City as herein provided. Whenever a developer has submitted a plat of a proposed subdivision to the Planning Commission for approval, or whenever such developer shall apply for approval of such plat, it shall be conclusively presumed that such developer irrevocably consented that such ownership shall be vested in the City in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(C)  Notwithstanding subsection (B) above, when the proposed subdivision or subdivision lot is in the Consolidated Utility District (CUD) water service area, then the water lines shall become the property of CUD only when accepted by CUD. However, no proposed subdivision or subdivision lot may be approved in the CUD water service area unless it meets all the City requirements for fire protection, including but not limited to the size of the water line, water pressure and installation of fire hydrants. The Planning Commission Secretary may not sign and approve the final plat until the fire protection requirements of the City have been satisfied or can be satisfied and appropriate surety has been provided to assure same. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 2; Ord. No. 86-28 § 1, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 2, 03-04-10) 
Section 29-3 - Extension of improvements. 
The City or any public authority shall not accept, layout, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street or lay or authorize water mains, repurified water mains, sewers, or connections in any streets and no building shall be erected on any lot with access from any street that does not correspond in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the Planning Commission or which aforementioned development does not conform with the Subdivision Regulations and Street Design Specifications, as amended, and, additionally or alternatively, with the Murfreesboro Water and Sewer Department Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, as amended, three copies of which shall remain on file with the City Recorder, unless such street shall have been accepted and opened and shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to the effective date of this chapter. 
The total costs for the street utilities and storm drainage improvements shall be borne entirely by the developer. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 3; Ord. No. 76-12 § 1, 04-29-76; Ord. No. 86-28 §§ 2, 3, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 10-O-06 §§ 3-5, 03-04-10) 
Section 29-4 - Reserved. 
Section 29-5 - Fee schedule for staff review of site plans and subdivision plats. 
The City Council may adopt by resolution a schedule of fees to offset the cost of review by City staff of site plans, subdivision plats, resubdivision plats, grading plans, and other related materials. An applicant shall pay the appropriate fee(s) to the City when submitting any such materials for review by City staff. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 5; Ord No. 86-28 § 4, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 88-44 § 1, 08-11-88; Ord. No. 03-O-59 § 1, 01-15-04; Ord. No. 06-O-12 § 1, 06-08-06; Ord. No. 08-O-17 § 33, 06-05-08; Ord. No. 09-O-47 §§ 1, 2, 01-21-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 1, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-6 - Approval of preliminary plats. 
Approval of a preliminary plat shall lapse 18 months from the date of approval unless construction has begun in accord with construction plans reviewed and approved by the City Engineer in accordance with the Subdivision Regulations. Preliminary plat approval shall not confer a vested right to proceed with development of the property as shown on the preliminary plat but shall authorize the applicant to submit construction plans in accordance with said approval and the requirements of the Subdivision Regulations. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 6; Ord No. 86-28 § 4, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 91-49 § 1, 10-17-91; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 7, 03-04-10) 
Section 29-7 - Approval of final plats and re-plats. 
Approval of a final plat shall lapse 12 months after the date of approval unless construction has begun in accord with construction plans which have been reviewed and approved by the City Engineer in accordance with the Subdivision Regulations; provided that, if there is no public infrastructure, including but not limited to streets, water, repurified water, sanitary sewer and storm water facilities, required to be constructed, approval of the final plat shall lapse 12 months after the date of approval unless all signatures and certifications required by the Subdivision Regulations are obtained in writing upon the final plat. 
The Planning Commission Secretary's approval to record a final plat or a re-plat shall lapse 12 months after the date of the Planning Commission Secretary's signature upon the plat. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 7; Ord No. 86-28 § 4, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 91-49 § 2, 10-17-91; Ord. No. 94-O-02 § 1, 02-17-94; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 8, 03-04-10) 
Section 29-8 - Reserved. 
Section 29-9 - Water supply system. 
(A)  Water mains, including service lines to serve each lot within the subdivision (which shall be capped off until service through same may be required), shall be properly connected with a public water supply system and shall be constructed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots shown on the subdivision plat for both domestic use and fire protection. 
The entire cost and expense of constructing and installing water mains and service lines, and of constructing and installing necessary main or mains required to extend a public water supply system to the particular subdivision, including without limitation the cost of pipes, valves and fittings, the opening or digging of necessary ditches, backfill, and the laying and covering of the water mains and service lines, shall be borne and be paid by the developer, but same shall be constructed and installed by the City acting by and through the Murfreesboro Water Resources Department (MWRD) and the City's Water Resources Board, either directly with its own forces and equipment or by contract with eligible and qualified contractor or contractors. Should the City elect to not utilize the foregoing procedure, the Department will require the developer to: contract with a reputable, licensed contractor and perform the work pursuant to plans and specifications approved by the City and the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation; fully insure the City against all claims; furnish a bond or letter of credit to assure proper performance and payment of the work; reimburse the City for costs; and, follow MWRD Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements which have been approved by the Water Resources Board and City Council, one copy of which is on file with the City Recorder. 
Except as otherwise allowed in MWRD Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, the minimum size of water lines shall be eight inches in diameter in all cases. Where the City's master planning for water lines or water system extensions indicates or requires a water line larger than eight inches, or in any case or situation where the MWRD Director shall find and determine that a water line larger than eight inches is then needed or probably in the future will be needed to serve other area or areas in the vicinity of or beyond the limits of the particular subdivision, then such larger water line as determined and fixed by the MWRD Director shall be required to be installed at the cost of the developer as hereinabove provided before the proposed subdivision of such developer shall be approved. MWRD's Policies, Procedures, and General Design Requirements identify criteria whereby MWRD, with approval of the Water Resources Board and the City Council, may participate in funding upsized water line or water system facilities of a proposed development. 
MWRD shall provide for water taps for each and every lot within the subdivision, the fees or charges for such taps to be paid at the rate provided for in the City's water rate schedules. 
The developer shall bear the expense and costs of fire hydrants in such number and at such locations as shall be determined by the MWRD Director in accordance with the applicable codes. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary hereinbefore in this section provided or to be implied therefrom, neither the City nor MWRD is obligated to extend water service to any subdivision or area outside of the Department's water service area, and neither the City nor MWRD is obligated by any provision or provisions of this section with respect to any such subdivision or area, unless and until the City Council specifically approves such extension of water service and fix and determine the terms and conditions under which such service shall be extended, and unless and until City Council specifically obligates MWRD with respect to such provision or provisions. 
(B)  Notwithstanding subsection (A) above, when the proposed subdivision or subdivision lot is in the Consolidated Utility District (CUD) water service area, then the water lines shall be connected with the CUD water supply system and shall be constructed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots shown on the subdivision plat for both domestic use and fire protection. It will be necessary for the developer or owner to satisfy all regulations of both CUD and the City in providing water for domestic use and fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 08-24-64 § 9; Ord. of 03-26-64 § 1; Ord. No. 84-40 § 1, 10-18-84; Ord. No. 86-49 § 1, 12-11-86; Ord. No. 90-49 §§ 3, 4, 11-15-90; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 9, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Cross reference- Ch. 23, plumbing. 
Section 29-10 - Sanitary sewers. 
When located within the service area of the City sewerage system, sanitary sewers, including laterals to serve each lot within the subdivision (which shall be capped or plugged off until sewerage service through same may be required), shall be installed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots with connection to such sewerage system. 
The entire cost of constructing and installing such sewers and laterals and of constructing and installing necessary outfall or interceptor sewer or sewers required to extend the City's sewerage systems to the particular subdivision, including without limitation the cost of pipes, manholes and fittings, the opening or digging of necessary ditches, backfilling, and the laying and covering of the sewers and laterals, shall be borne and be paid by the developer, but same shall be constructed and installed by MWRD, either directly with its own forces and equipment or by contract with eligible and qualified contractor or contractors. Should the City elect to not utilize the foregoing procedure, MWRD will require the developer to: contract with a reputable, licensed contractor and perform the work pursuant to plans and specifications approved by the City and the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation; fully insure the City against all claims; furnish a bond or letter of credit to assure proper performance and payment of the work; reimburse the City for costs; and, follow MWRD's Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, three copies of which are on file with the City Recorder. 
Except as otherwise allowed in MWRD's Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, the minimum size of sanitary sewer mains is eight inches in diameter in all cases. Where the City's master planning for sanitary sewers or sewerage system extensions indicates or requires a sanitary sewer larger than eight inches, or in any case or situation where the MWRD Director finds and determines that a sewer larger than eight inches is needed or will be needed in the future to serve other area or: areas in the vicinity of or beyond the limits of the particular subdivision, then a larger sewer line as determined by the MWRD Director will be installed at the cost of the developer as hereinabove provided before the proposed subdivision may be approved. MWRD's Policies, Procedures, and General Design Requirements identify criteria whereby the Department, with approval of the Water and Sewer Department Board and the City Council, may participate in funding upsized sanitary sewer facilities of a proposed development. The size and type or kind of pipes and fittings to be used for laterals to serve the lots in the subdivision, the location of the sewers and laterals, the types or kinds of pipes and fittings to be used for sewers, the location, number and types of manholes, the width and depth of the ditch, the amount and method of making soil cover over the pipes or sewers and other features of the installation all shall conform with accepted standards established by the City and approved in writing by the MWRD Director. 
MWRD shall furnish sewer connections for each and every lot within the subdivision, the fees or charges for such connections to be paid by the builder at the City's rates therefor at the time in force and effect. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary hereinabove in this section provided or to be implied therefrom, MWRD is not obligated to extend sewer service to any subdivision or area outside the corporate limits of the City and is not so obligated by any provision or provisions of this section with respect to any such subdivision or area, until the City Council specifically approves such extension of such service and determines the terms and conditions under which such service shall be extended. 
Where a subdivision or the lots located therein for any reason cannot be economically connected with the City's or other sewerage system, or where for any reason the City Council declines to extend its sewerage or service to a subdivision or any of the lots therein, the lots in said subdivision not connected or to be connected to the City's or such other sewerage system must contain adequate area for installation of approved septic tank and disposal fields based on a percolation test and must be approved in writing by the county health officer and MWRD Director. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 10; Ord. of 07-21-55 § 1; Ord. of 03-26-64 § 2; Ord. No. 84-40 § 2, 10-18-84; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 10, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-11 - Reserved. 
Section 29-12 - Minimum pavement widths. 
Minimum pavement widths in new subdivisions shall be in accord with the Subdivision Regulations and Standard Street Specifications adopted by the Planning Commission, as amended. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 12; Ord. No. 84-22 § 1, 06-21-84; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 11, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-13 - Guarantees and security for improvements. 
No final plat shall be signed by the Secretary of the Planning Commission or accepted by the Rutherford County Register of Deeds until all improvements to be made or constructed by the developer as required by this chapter, by the Subdivision Regulations and Standard Street Specifications, and MWRD's Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements, including but not limited to streets, sidewalks, water mains and service lines, repurified water mains and service lines, sanitary sewer lines and laterals, and storm water drainage facilities, have been constructed in a satisfactory manner and accepted in writing by the City. In lieu of completing such construction before execution and recordation of the final plat, the developer may secure the payment of the estimated cost of completion of all such construction by providing surety in accord with the provisions of the Subdivision Regulations and Standard Street Specifications and MWRD's Policies, Procedures and General Design Requirements. 
(Ord. of 08-12-54 § 13; Ord. of 03-26-64 § 3; Ord. No. 86-28 § 6, 09-18-86; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 12, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-14 - Reserved. 
Section 29-15 - Application of this chapter to approved but undeveloped subdivisions. 
This chapter and the provisions thereof apply to all approved but undeveloped subdivisions and to all undeveloped portions of such subdivisions. No previously approved subdivision, and no portion of any such subdivision, shall be considered to be undeveloped within the meaning and terms of this section where, at the effective date hereof, the streets of such subdivision or such portion thereof have already been laid off, graded and rocked, and where water lines or mains repurified water lines or mains, and sanitary sewer interceptors, collectors and laterals to serve the lots abutting on such streets have already been laid and installed in such streets. 
(Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 14, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-16 - Reserved. 
Section 29-17 - Minimum development improvements prior to issuance of building permit. 
(A)  Minimum improvements for one- and two-family subdivisions: 
(1)  After a final plat has been recorded, the following minimum improvements must be completed prior to the issuance of any building permits, without regard to whether a surety has been submitted for the completion of any part of the improvement: 
(a)  All curbing must be installed and streets constructed to binder course of pavement in accord with the approved construction plans; 
(b)  All water lines, including fire protection lines and fire hydrants, must be installed, have passed all testing including adequacy of fire flows, and be operable; 
(c)  Sanitary sewer lines and manholes (or approved alternative facilities) must be installed, have passed all testing and be operable; 
(d)  Storm water facilities, including erosion prevention and sediment control measures, must be installed and be operable; and 
(e)  All required traffic control facilities, markings and signage in accord with the latest edition of the MUTCD as adopted by Tennessee Department of Transportation must be completely installed and be operable. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of the developer to notify the Development Services Division as items (a) through (e) above are completed and to request appropriate inspections. 
(3)  As the improvements listed in (1) along each street proposed to be developed within each section or phase of the development are completed and all site work on the lots is completed, the Development Services Director may authorize the issuance of building permits for the lots along such street. 
(B)  Minimum Improvements for integrated site plan/subdivision development: Upon recommendation of the Director of Development Services, who shall have consulted with the City Engineer and the MWRD Director, the Planning Commission may modify the requirements set forth in subsection (A) above in the conditions of approval of an integrated site plan/subdivision development. Except as so modified, the requirements set forth in subsection (A) above shall apply equally to an integrated site plan/subdivision development. 
(C)  Minimum improvements for subdivisions other than one- and two-family subdivisions and integrated site plan/subdivision development are identical to those stated in (A) above except for the following: 
(1)  All sanitary sewer lines and manholes (or approved alternative facilities) which are in the right-of-way must be installed, have passed all testing and be operable; and 
(2)  As the improvements listed in (1) along each street proposed to be developed within each section or phase of the development are completed, the Development Services Director may authorize the issuance of building permits for the lots along such street. 
(Ord. No. 88-21 §§ 1, 2, 06-09-88; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 16, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Section 29-18 - Drainage ways. 
It is unlawful for any person (including but not limited to the property owner, builder or contractor) to alter the drainage way in any City drainage easement, to plant trees in any drainage easement, or to construct any building, fence or other structure therein without the prior written approval of the City Engineer as such obstructions are detrimental to public health and safety. 
Upon written notice from the City Engineer, the property owner shall cause any such alteration, tree, building, fence or other structure to be removed and, additionally or alternatively, as the City Engineer may direct, cause the drainage way to be restored. 
If, after such notice, the property owner fails to cause any such alteration, tree, building, fence, or other structure to be removed and restored as directed, the City Engineer may perform or cause to be performed such work, and the owner shall be liable and responsible for all costs incurred, including but not limited to demolition costs, removal costs, construction costs, and engineering fees. In the alternative, the City may seek injunctive or other appropriate relief in the Circuit or Chancery Court. 
If the property owner fails to pay any such costs as are incurred by the City Engineer within 30 days after the mailing of an itemized statement for such costs, the City Engineer is authorized to place a lien on the property of any such person to enforce the collection of such costs by recording an affidavit setting forth the date(s) and amount(s) of such costs with the Register of Deeds of Rutherford County, which lien may be added to and collected as property tax. 
Any person violating any of these provisions shall be subject to punishment as provided in Code § 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 91-11 § 1, 01-31-91; Ord. No. 10-O-06 § 17, 03-04-10; Ord. No. 18-O-40 , § 2, 7-19-18) 
Chapter 30 - TAXICABS AND VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Charter § 4(34), authority of City to license, tax and regulate vehicles for hire and to fix and regulate the rates for carriage of persons or property; Charter § 4(35), authority of City to require insurance policy or bond; Charter § 4(40), authority of City to revoke license. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Section 30-1 - Terminals to be provided. 
It shall be unlawful for any bus or taxicab line or company to operate within the City unless they maintain a terminal station or depot. 
(Ord. of 04-15-26 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 1) 
Section 30-2 - Solicitation of passengers on streets. 
No driver or agent of any bus or taxicab lines or company shall be allowed to solicit passengers upon the streets of the City. 
(Ord. of 04-15-26 § 2; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 2) 
Section 30-3 - Railway depots. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the depots or platforms of any railway company within the corporate limits of the City for the purpose of soliciting business without the consent of such railway company. 
(Ord. of 06-09-17 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 3) 
Section 30-4 - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, unless otherwise provided by this chapter, be punished as provided in Code § 1-8. 
(Code 1949, ch. 24 § 4) 
Sections 30-5-30-14 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING 

Section 30-15 - Prohibited in certain area. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any taxicab or other vehicle operated for hire to park or stand upon the streets, avenues, square and other public thoroughfares of the City within the territory bounded and described as follows: 
Being all that part of the City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee, known as and embraced within the public square and the streets leading into said square for one block off such square, and bounded as follows: 
Beginning at a point, being the intersection of the north boundary or edge of East Main Street and the west boundary or edge of Spring Street, and running thence west with and along the north boundary or edge of East Main Street to a point where the east boundary or edge of the public square intersects the north boundary or edge of said East Main Street; thence north with and along the east boundary or edge of the public square and North Church Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the south boundary or edge of East College Street and then north across said East College Street to the point where the north boundary or edge of East College Street intersects the east boundary or edge of North Church Street; thence across said North Church Street to the point where the north boundary or edge of College Street intersects the west boundary or edge of North Church Street, and thence with and along the north boundary or edge of College Street to the point where said boundary or edge of College Street intersects the east boundary or edge of North Maple Street; thence west across said North Maple Street to the point where the north boundary or edge of College Street intersects the west boundary or edge of North Maple Street; thence south across West College Street to the point where the west boundary or edge of North Maple Street and the south boundary or edge of West College Street intersect, and thence south along and with the west boundary or edge of North Maple Street and the west boundary or edge of the public square to the point where said boundary or edge of the public square intersects the north boundary or edge of West Main Street; thence west along and with the north boundary or edge of West Main Street to the point where said boundary or edge of West Main Street intersects the east boundary or edge of North Walnut Street; thence south across said West Main Street to the point where the south boundary or edge of West Main Street intersects the east boundary or edge of South Walnut Street; thence east with and along the south boundary or edge of West Main Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the west boundary or edge of the public square; thence south with and along the west boundary or edge of the public square and South Maple Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the north boundary or edge of West Vine Street; thence east across said South Maple Street to the point where the north boundary or edge of West Vine Street intersects the east boundary or edge of South Maple Street; thence north along and with the east boundary or edge of South Maple Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the south boundary or edge of the public square; thence east with and along the south boundary or edge of the public square to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the west boundary or edge of South Church Street; thence south with and along the west boundary or edge of South Church Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the north boundary or edge of Vine Street; thence east across said South Church Street to a point where the north boundary or edge of Vine Street intersects the east boundary or edge of South Church Street; thence north along and with the east boundary or edge of South Church Street and the public square to the point where said boundary or edge of the public square intersects the south boundary or edge of East Main Street; thence east with and along the south boundary or edge of East Main Street to the point where said boundary or edge intersects the west boundary or edge of South Spring Street; thence north across East Main Street to the point or place of beginning. 
(Ord. of 06-09-32 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 5) 
Cross reference- Ch. 32, traffic. 
Section 30-16 - Written consent of adjacent property owner required; filing; approval. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any taxicab or other vehicle operated for hire to park or to stand at any place on the streets, avenues, public square and other public thoroughfares of the City, not embraced within the territory described in the immediately preceding section, without first obtaining and filing with the City Recorder the written consent of the owner, occupant or person in possession or control of the immediately adjacent and contiguous property and the approval of the City Manager endorsed on such written consent. Where such consent and approval is given, the City Manager may define, limit and designate the particular area within which such vehicles may park or stand by the erection or placing of appropriate signs or markers. 
(Ord. of 06-09-32 § 2; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 6) 
Section 30-17 - Intention of Code §§ 30-15 and 30-16. 
It is the intention of Code § 30-15 to prohibit and make it unlawful for any person to maintain at any time or under any conditions a permanent or established parking place, place of business or stand upon the streets, avenues, public square and other public thoroughfares and places of the City within the area set forth in Code § 30-15 hereof. It is the intention of Code § 30-16 to prohibit and make it unlawful for any person to maintain any such permanent or established parking place, place of business, or stand at any place upon the streets, avenues, public square and other public thoroughfares and places of the City without first obtaining and filing the written consent, and obtaining the approval, provided for in Code § 30-16. 
(Ord. of 06-09-32 § 3; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 7) 
Section 30-18 - Article construed. 
Nothing contained in this article contained be construed as prohibiting taxicabs or other vehicles operated for hire from making temporary stops for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers and their baggage or for the purpose of loading or unloading freight; nor shall anything in this article be construed as permitting the parking or standing of such vehicles on the streets, avenues, square and public thoroughfares of the City in any manner prohibited by this Code or any other ordinance or parking regulation of the City. 
(Ord. of 06-09-32 § 4; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 8) 
Section 30-19 - Penalty for violation of article. 
The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to buses operating under a franchise granted by the City Council. 
(Code 1949, ch. 24 § 9) 
Sections 30-20-30-29 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIABILITY INSURANCE 

Section 30-30 - Required; filing; type; notice to City of cancellation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive or permit to be operated or driven on the streets and other public places of the City any taxicab, jitney, motorbus or other vehicle engaged in the carriage of passengers or their luggage for hire, except as otherwise provided in Code § 30-32, unless the owner, proprietor or person having control of such taxicab, jitney, motorbus or other vehicle shall have first deposited and left on file with the City Recorder, and shall keep in full force and effect, a policy of insurance issued on each such vehicle by a person duly authorized to transact such business in the state. Such policy shall be in the approved standard form and what is commonly known as a "public liability and property damage policy" in limits of not less than $25,000.00 and $50,000.00 for death or personal injuries and $25,000.00 for damages to property, and issued in the name of the owner, proprietor or person having control of such taxicab, jitney, motorbus or other such motor vehicle; provided, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the issuance of a single policy covering all taxicabs, jitneys, motorbuses or other vehicles of a single owner, proprietor or person having control thereof, where the extent of coverage is as above stated as to each such vehicle; provided further, that every policy shall provide on the face thereof or by rider thereon that such policy shall not be cancelable except upon five or more days notice given to the City, to the attention of the City Recorder. 
(Ord. of 06-11-46 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 10; Ord. No. 75-11 § 1, 05-29-75; Ord. of 07-17-75 § 1) 
Section 30-31 - Issuance of receipts; contents; posting; exhibiting; separate receipts for vehicles covered by fleet policies. 
Upon the depositing of such insurance policy with the City Recorder, as required by Code § 30-30, the City Recorder shall, if the City Recorder is satisfied that such policy complies in all respects with this article, issue a receipt therefor showing therein the number of the policy, the name of the person by whom issued, the name of the owner, proprietor or person in control thereby insured and the make, color, style and the motor or manufacturer's serial number of the vehicles covered by such policy. 
Such receipt shall at all times be posted or displayed in each vehicle so insured or be in possession of the driver of such vehicle while on the streets and other public places of the City. Such receipt shall be exhibited by such driver, upon request, to any officer of the City charged with the enforcement of the laws and ordinances of the City and to the persons injured or damaged or their agents. 
Where a single policy is filed with the City Recorder insuring or covering more than one vehicle, as permitted by the immediately preceding section, the City Recorder shall issue a separate receipt as to each vehicle insured thereunder or covered thereby. 
(Ord. of 06-11-46 § 2; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 11) 
Section 30-32 - Certain vehicles exempt from provisions of article. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to motorbuses or other motor vehicles engaged in the carriage of passengers or their luggage for hire that are subject to the jurisdiction of the railroad and public utilities commission of the state nor to motorbuses operated in the City under franchise granted by the City where other provisions are made by ordinance or otherwise for the carrying of liability insurance for death, personal injuries or property damages. 
(Ord. of 06-11-46 § 3; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 12) 
Section 30-33 - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any who operates any taxicab, jitney, motorbus or other motor vehicle on the streets, or other public places of the City without having filed, and without having in force and effect, the liability insurance required by this article, or who fails to comply with or violates any of the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in Code § 1-8. Each separate operation or trip, or part thereof, by any such vehicle, without complying with the provisions of this article, or without keeping in force and effect the insurance required by this article, shall be considered a separate offense and be punishable as such. 
(Ord. of 06-11-46 § 4; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 13) 
Sections 30-34-30-43 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LICENSES 

Section 30-44 - Required. 
It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for the driver of any taxicab, jitney, motorbus or other motor vehicle operated for hire and engaged in the carriage of passengers and their luggage to drive any such vehicle upon the streets and other public thoroughfares within and subject to the jurisdiction of the City until he shall have first obtained a license so to do from the City Recorder. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 14) 
Section 30-45 - Qualifications. 
The applicant for a license under Code § 30-44 shall possess the following qualifications: 
(A)  be at least 16 years of age; 
(B)  possesses no material impairment or defect of sight or hearing; 
(C)  possess no material defect or impairment in the use of limbs or any part thereof which is likely, in the opinion of the City Recorder, to render the operation of any such vehicle dangerous or unsafe; and, 
(D)  not have been convicted of violating any City ordinance within 90 days next prior to the date of application for such license. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 15) 
Section 30-46 - Issuance; fee; proration; refund; disposition of collected fees. 
If the applicant meets the qualifications set out in the immediately preceeding section and pays the license fee of $2.50, the City Recorder shall grant such applicant a chauffeur's license and issue a metallic badge with the words appearing thereon, "Licensed Chauffeur No.___ (the year in which issued), Murfreesboro, Tennessee"; provided, that any person securing such license on or after October 1 of any year shall be required to pay the sum of $1.50 as such license fee; provided further, that no refund shall be made or allowed to any person on account of a license being suspended or revoked or for any other cause. 
The license fees collected under the provisions of this chapter shall be applied to defraying the expenses and costs of the administration of this chapter, without further specific appropriation therefor, except as is hereby made by this section. Any surplus of such fees, after paying the costs and expenses of such administration, shall be paid into and credited to the general account or fund of the City. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 §§ 1, 8; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 16) 
Section 30-47 - Expiration and renewal date. 
The license and registration of any chauffeur herein authorized to be issued shall expire on December 31 st of the year in which issued and shall be renewed for the ensuing year on or before the last day of the year in which issued. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 3; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 17) 
Section 30-48 - Failure of applicant to meet qualifications. 
If any applicant fails to meet the qualifications set out in Code § 30-45, the City Recorder shall refuse to grant such applicant a license or issue a badge; provided, that the City Recorder may, with the approval of the Chief of Police or City Manager, grant such license and issue such badge, notwithstanding the prior trial and conviction of any such operator or chauffeur for the violation of any of the City ordinances. For the purpose of this article, any such operator shall be deemed to have been tried and convicted for the violation of a City ordinance, notwithstanding any appeal or review seeking to reverse such conviction and until such conviction shall have been reversed or until such operator shall have been acquitted. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 1; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 18) 
Section 30-49 - Description of drivers to be kept; identification card. 
At the time of the granting of such license and the issuance of such badge, the City Recorder shall enter, for the purpose of identification, the full description of such licensed driver in a book kept for that purpose. The description shall set out the name of the driver, sex, age, race, color of eyes and hair, approximate height, residence and by whom employed and, if not employed, the fact that the licensed driver is self-employed. 
The City Recorder shall issue each licensed driver a duplicate identification card which shall be kept in such driver's possession while on duty and shall be shown to any officer upon demand. This identification card shall be nontransferable. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32, § 2; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 19) 
Section 30-50 - Use of driver's badge by other than licensee prohibited; badge to be displayed by licensee. 
The driver's badge shall not be worn or used by any person other than the driver to whom issued. At all times while such licensed driver is engaged in driving any taxicab or other motor vehicle for hire upon the streets and other public thoroughfares of the City, the driver shall wear this badge on the right breast, attached to an outer garment and in plain view. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 2; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 20) 
Section 30-51 - Counterfeit badges. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to counterfeit, make, procure, use or possess any metallic badge of the kind issued, or similar to the kind issued, to licensed drivers under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 4; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 21) 
Section 30-52 - Suspension and revocation-Generally. 
Upon the conviction of any chauffeur licensed under the provisions of this chapter for the violation of any provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the City, the Judge of the City Court may suspend or revoke the license of any such driver. 
Suspension. In the case of a suspension of license, the suspension shall be for not less than ten days nor more than 90 days. The period of suspension shall be fixed by the City Judge, and written notation of the date and period of such suspension shall be made by the City Judge upon the docket of the Court in connection with the record of the case in which the conviction occurred. The City Judge shall, in such case of suspension of license, call for and take up the metallic badge issued to the chauffeur and keep the same until the expiration of the period of suspension, when it shall be returned to the driver upon the latter's application or request in person. A notation shall be made upon the docket of the City Court, in connection with the record of the case in which the conviction occurred, of the date and the fact of such return. 
Revocation. In the case of a revocation of license by the City Judge, written notation shall be made by the City Judge of the date and fact of revocation upon the docket of the City Court in connection with the record of the case in which the conviction occurred, and the City Judge shall call for and take up the metallic badge theretofore issued to the chauffeur. No new license shall thereafter be issued by the City Recorder to the chauffeur whose license has been revoked, without the approval or direction of the City Council. 
It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any licensed chauffeur to fail or refuse to deliver the metallic badge to the City Judge, upon the City Judge's demand or call therefor in any case of suspension or revocation of license of such chauffeur or to drive or operate any motor vehicle for hire during any period of suspension or revocation of license of such chauffeur. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 4; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 22) 
Section 30-53 - Effect of appeal. 
The power to suspend or revoke licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall not be affected or curtailed by the fact that any licensed chauffeur shall appeal or seek a review from any judgment of conviction. The City Judge shall have power to suspend or revoke said license pending such appeal or review. If the person convicted shall be acquitted upon such appeal or review, then the order of suspension or revocation shall be revoked and set aside. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 5; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 23) 
Section 30-54 - Right of appeal. 
Any person who deems they have been aggrieved may within five days after the date of the denial, suspension or revocation of a license appeal to the City Council from the action of the City Recorder in denying a license under the provisions of this article, or from the judgment of the City Judge in suspending or revoking a license under the provisions of this article, by filing in writing with a member of the Council a petition stating the facts, asking for a hearing and the relief desired. The Council shall hear such appeal at the earliest possible and convenient time, not later than 15 days after the filing of such petition. The person so appealing shall have the benefit of representation by counsel and the right to produce proof to sustain such appeal. The decision of a majority of the Council upon such appeal shall be final and not reviewable. 
(Ord. of 06-16-32 § 6; Code 1949, Ch. 24 § 24) 
Chapter 31 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Section 31-1.1 - Purpose. 
The purpose and intent of this chapter is to: 
(A)  establish a local policy concerning telecommunications providers and services; 
(B)  establish clear local guidelines, standards and time frames for the exercise of local authority with respect to the regulation of telecommunications providers and services; 
(C)  promote competition in telecommunications; 
(D)  minimize unnecessary local regulation of telecommunications providers and services; 
(E)  encourage the provision of advanced and competitive telecommunications services on the widest possible basis to the businesses, institutions and residents of the City; 
(F)  permit and manage reasonable access to the public ways of the City for telecommunications purposes on a competitively neutral basis; 
(G)  conserve the limited physical capacity of the public ways held in the public trust by the City; 
(H)  assure that the City's current and ongoing costs of granting and regulating private access to and use of the public ways are fully paid by the persons seeking such access and causing such costs; 
(I)  secure fair and reasonable compensation to the City and the residents of the City for permitting private use of the public ways; 
(J)  assure that all telecommunications carriers providing facilities or services within the City comply with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the City; 
(K)  assure that the City can continue to fairly and responsibly protect the public health, safety and welfare; and, 
(L)  enable the City to discharge its public trust consistent with rapidly evolving federal and state regulatory policies, industry competition and technological development. 
(Ord. No. 96-O-83 § 1, 05-29-97) 
Section 31-1.2 - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, and the interpretation and enforcement thereof, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless the context of the sentence in which they are used shall indicate otherwise: 
"Affiliate" means a person that (directly or indirectly) owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with another person. 
"Annual gross revenue." Reserved. 
"Cable Act" means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 U.S.C. § 532, et seq., and Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, October 5, 1992 P.L. 102-385, 106 Stat. 1460 as now and hereafter amended. 
"Cable operator" means a telecommunications carrier providing or offering to provide "cable service" within the City as that term is defined in the Cable Act. 
"Cable service for the purpose of this chapter shall have the same meaning provided by the Cable Act. 
"City" means the City of Murfreesboro. 
"City authorities" means the Mayor and City Council of the City. 
"City property" means and includes all real property owned by the City, other than public streets and utility easements as those terms are defined herein, and all property held in a proprietary capacity by the City, which are not subject to right-of-way licensing and franchising as provided in this chapter. 
"Excess capacity" means the volume or capacity in any existing or future duct, conduit, manhole, or other utility facility within the public way that is or will be available for use for additional telecommunications facilities. 
"Federal Communications Commission (FCC)" means the Federal administrative agency, or lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee telecommunications carriers, services and providers on a national level. 
"Tennessee Regulatory Authority (TRA)" means the State administrative agency, or lawful successor, authorized to regulate and oversee telecommunications carriers, services and providers in the State of Tennessee. 
"Other ways" means the highways, streets, alleys, utility easements or other rights-of-way within the City, but under the jurisdiction and control of a governmental entity other than the City. 
"Overhead facilities" means utility poles, utility facilities and telecommunications facilities located above the surface of the ground, including the underground supports and foundations for such facilities. 
"Person" means and includes corporations, companies, associations, joint stock companies or associations, firms, partnerships, limited liability companies and individuals and includes their lessors, trustees and receivers. 
"Public street" means any highway, street, alley or other public right of way for motor vehicle travel under the jurisdiction and control of the City which has been acquired, established, dedicated or devoted to highway purposes not inconsistent with telecommunications facilities. 
"Public way" means and includes all public streets and utility easements, as those terms are defined herein, now or hereafter owned by the City, but only to the extent of the City's right, title, interest or authority to grant a license or franchise to occupy and use such streets and easements for telecommunications facilities. 
"State" means the State of Tennessee. 
"Surplus space" means that portion of the usable space on a utility pole which has the necessary clearance from other pole users, as required by the orders and regulations of the Tennessee Regulatory Authority, to allow its use by a telecommunications carrier for a pole attachment. 
"Telecommunications Act" means the Telecommunications Act of 1996, P.L. 104-104, 110 Stat. 55. 
"Telecommunications carrier" means and includes every person that directly or indirectly owns, controls, operates or manages plant, equipment or property within the City, used or to be used for the purpose of offering telecommunications service. 
"Telecommunications facilities" means the plant, equipment and property, including but not limited to, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antennae, electronics and other appurtenances used or to be used to transmit, receive, distribute, provide or offer telecommunications services. 
"Telecommunications provider" means and includes every person who provides telecommunications service over telecommunications facilities without any ownership or management control of the facilities. 
"Telecommunications service" means the providing or offering for rent, sale or lease, or in exchange for other value received, of the transmittal of voice, data, image, graphic and video programming information between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite or similar facilities, with or without benefit of any closed transmission medium. 
"Telecommunications system See Telecommunications facilities. 
"Underground facilities" means utility and telecommunications facilities located under the surface of the ground, excluding the underground foundations or supports for Overhead Facilities. 
"Usable space" means the total distance between the top of a utility pole and the lowest possible attachment point that provides the minimum allowable vertical clearance as specified in the orders and regulations of the Tennessee Regulatory Authority. 
"Utility easement" means any easement owned by the City and acquired, established, dedicated or devoted for public utility purposes not inconsistent with telecommunications facilities. 
"Utility facilities" means the plant, equipment and property, including but not limited to the poles, pipes, mains, conduits, ducts, cables, wires, plant and equipment located under, on or above the surface of the ground within the public ways of the City and used or to be used for the purpose of providing utility or telecommunications services. 
(Ord. No. 96-O-83 § 1, 05-29-97) 
Section 31-1.3 - Registration. 
Except as otherwise provided herein, all telecommunications carriers and providers engaged in the business of transmitting, supplying or furnishing of telecommunications originating or terminating in the City shall register with the City pursuant to Article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 96-O-83 § 1, 05-29-97) 
Section 31-1.4 - Telecommunications license.
