The Engineering Department, in cooperation with the department of public transportation services, is hereby authorized to establish bus stops, bus stands, and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as the departments shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop, bus stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs, erected by the Engineering Department. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1407 - Reserved. 
Section 32-1408 - Stopping, standing and parking of buses and taxicabs regulated. 
(A)  The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any other place other than a bus or taxicab stand so designated for such purpose. 
(B)  Section (A) notwithstanding, a driver of a bus or taxicab is permitted to make temporary courtesy stops or "all-stops" when necessary to load or unload a passenger at a site other than a designated bus or taxicab stand. The driver of the bus or taxicab may exercise discretion as to whether to make such a stop for a passenger and, when so doing, may use such additional signaling efforts or devices as the driver deems reasonable and necessary to alert other drivers that such a stop is taking place. 
(C)  The driver of a bus or taxicab shall operate the vehicle in such a manner that, when it is stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage, the right front wheel of such vehicle shall not be farther than 18 in. from the curb and the body of the vehicle shall be approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 08-O-09 § 1, 03-13-08) 
Section 32-1409 - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers, when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter, or about to enter such zone. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1410 - Parking signs required. 
Whenever any restriction on stopping for the purposes of loading or unloading of freight and/or passengers is established as authorized in Code §§ 32-1401 and 32-1406, it shall be the duty of the Engineering Department to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless said signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense, clearly indicating the limits of such restricted zone. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Sections 32-1411-32-1499 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - REGULATING THE KINDS, CLASSES AND SIZE OF TRAFFIC ON HIGHWAYS 

Section 32-1500 - Scope and effect of article. 
(A)  It is a misdemeanor for any person to drive or move, or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved, on any highway any vehicle or vehicles of a size or weight exceeding the limitations stated in this article, or otherwise in violation of this article. 
(B)  The provisions of this article governing size, weight and load shall not apply to fire apparatus, road machinery, or to implements of husbandry, including farm tractors, temporarily moved upon a highway, or to a vehicle operated under the terms of a special permit issued as herein provided. 
(C)  Provisions of this article shall not apply to vehicles traveling on state maintained highways when the operator of such vehicle has in their possession a written permit authorizing travel on such state maintained highway. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1501 - Width of vehicles. 
The total outside width of any vehicle or the load thereon shall not exceed 96 in. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1502 - Projecting loads on passenger vehicles. 
No passenger-type vehicle shall be operated on any highway with any load carried thereon extending beyond the line of the fenders of the left side of such vehicle, nor extending more than 6 in. beyond the line of the fenders on the right side thereof. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1503 - Height and length of vehicles and loads. 
(A)  No vehicle, including any load thereon, shall exceed a height of 13 ft. 6 in. 
(B)  No motor vehicle as defined in T.C.A. § 55-1-103 consisting of a straight truck whose length, including any part of its body or load, exceeds 40 ft., and no straight truck with trailer attached, the total length of which combination, including any part of the body or load, exceeds 65 ft., shall be operated on any highway. 
(C)  Motor vehicles consisting of a truck-tractor and semitrailer or trailer combination shall be permitted to operate over the federal and state highway system, provided the towed vehicle shall not exceed 50 ft. in length from the point of attachment to the tractor, except that this length may be increased to 52 ft. when the load on such vehicle consists of livestock, automobiles and/or motor vehicles. If the towed vehicle exceeds 48 ft. in length from the point of attachment to the tractor and the load on such vehicle does not consist of livestock, automobiles and/or motor vehicles, the distance between the kingpin and the rearmost axle, or a point midway between the two rear axles, if the two rear axles are a tandem axle, shall not exceed 41 ft. 
(D)  Motor vehicles consisting of a truck-tractor and twin trailer combination shall be permitted to operate on the interstate system and other federal-aid highways designated by the commissioner of transportation, provided neither of the towed vehicles shall exceed 28 ft. 6 in. in length. 
(E)  No twin trailer truck authorized by this chapter shall be operated on any highway designated as a scenic highway under the authority of Title 54, Chapter 17. The interstate system and other federal-aid highways designated by the commissioner of transportation shall not be considered scenic routes for purposes of this chapter. 
(F)  The limitation as to length stated in this section shall not apply to loads of poles, logs or timber in single length pieces; provided, that no motor vehicle, including any part of the body or load, transporting such material shall be in excess of 75 ft. in length unless a permit has first been obtained as authorized in T.C.A. § 55-7-205. 
(G)  The length limitations described in this section shall be exclusive of safety and energy conservation devices designated by the commissioner of transportation, except that no device excluded from the limitations of this section shall have, by its design or use, the capability to carry cargo. 
(H)  It shall not be a violation of the length limits set forth in this section when otherwise properly titled and registered vehicles in compliance with applicable length requirements are disabled on the highways, and require a tow or other assistance in proceeding to the nearest exit or repair or terminal facility within 100 miles of the disablement, and the combined lengths of the disabled vehicle and the tow vehicle exceed the limits herein. This exemption shall only apply to vehicles disabled while operating on the highway, and only to their transport to the nearest exit or suitable repair facility. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1504 - Special load limits. 
(A)  Subject to the foregoing provisions of this article limiting the length of vehicles and loads, the load upon any vehicle operated alone, or the load upon the front vehicle of a combination of vehicles, shall not extend more than 3 ft. beyond the foremost part of the vehicle, and the load upon any vehicle operated alone, or the load upon the rear vehicle of a combination of vehicles, shall not extend more than 6 ft. beyond the rear of the bed or body of such vehicle. 
(B)  The limitations as to length of vehicles and loads heretofore stated in Code § 32-1503 and subsection (A) hereof, shall not apply to any load upon a pole trailer when transporting poles or pipes or structural material which cannot be dismembered, provided that no pole or pipe or other material exceeding 8 ft. in length shall be so transported unless a permit has first been obtained from the appropriate state or City authority. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1505 - Loads on vehicles. 
(A)  No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any highway unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substance may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining such roadway. 
(B)  No person shall operate on any highway any vehicle with any load unless said load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent said covering or load from becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard to other users of the highway. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1506 - Maximum weight of vehicles. 
(A)  The total gross weight imposed on the street or highway by any axle or group of axles shall not exceed the limitations established by the applicable laws of this state. 
(B)  Any police officer having reason to believe that the weight of a vehicle and load is unlawful is authorized to require the driver to stop and submit to a weighing of the same by means of either portable or stationary scales, and may require that such vehicle be driven to the nearest public scales, in the event such scales are within two miles. 
(C)  Whenever an officer, upon weighing a vehicle and load as above provided, determines that the weight is unlawful, such officer may require the driver to stop the vehicle in a suitable place and remain standing until such portion of the load is removed as may be necessary to reduce the gross weight of such vehicle to such limit as permitted under this article. All material so unloaded shall be cared for by the owner or operator of such vehicle at the risk of such owner or operator. 
(D)  Any driver of a vehicle who fails or refuses to stop and submit the vehicle and load to a weighing, or who fails or refuses when directed by an officer upon a weighing of the vehicle to stop the vehicle and to otherwise comply with the provisions of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(E)  The City Manager, in cooperation with the City Engineer, may prohibit the operation of trucks or commercial vehicles, or may impose limitations as to the time of such operation to alleviate traffic congestion and to control noise levels during certain areas. They may also impose limitations as to the weight or size thereof on specific streets where, based on traffic and engineering studies, it is determined that such action is necessary to assure against undue damage to the road foundations, surfaces or structures. Such prohibitions and limitations shall only be effective when designated by appropriate, traffic control devices placed on such streets, or by designating a truck route. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1507 - Liability for damage to highway or structure. 
(A)  Any person driving any vehicle, object or contrivance upon any highway or highway structure shall be liable for all damage which said highway or structure may sustain as a result of any illegal operation, driving or moving of such vehicle, object or contrivance, as provided elsewhere in this article. 
(B)  Whenever such driver is not the owner of such vehicle, object or contrivance, but is so operating, driving or moving the same with the express or implied permission of said owner, then said owner and driver shall be jointly and severally liable for any such damage. 
(C)  Such damage may be recovered in a civil action brought by the authorities in control of such highways or highway structure. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1508 - Restrictions on the operation of combination vehicles. 
No person shall drive or operate a truck-tractor in combination with a trailer or semitrailer on a City street except for state or interstate routes, unless it is for local delivery. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1509 - Restrictions on the movement of house or house trailer. 
(A)  No house or house trailer exceeding a length of 40 ft. extreme overall dimension, or a width of 96 in. extreme overall dimension, shall be towed or otherwise moved upon or across any street or highway between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m., or 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., or during any period of darkness as defined in Code § 32-1001. In addition, notice shall be given to the Murfreesboro Police Department 24 hours in advance. The applicant shall furnish escorts. 
(B)  Notwithstanding subsection (A), the Police Commissioner may direct the oversized load to be moved after 10:00 p.m. and provide a police escort in front and behind the oversized load through the City and charge $200.00 per hour, $200.00 minimum. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1510 - Restrictions as to tire equipment. 
(A)  No person shall use a tire on a vehicle moved on a highway which shall have on its periphery any block, stud, flange, cleat, or spike or any other protuberances of a material other than rubber which project beyond the tread of the traction surface of the tire, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(B)  A person may operate on a highway a vehicle equipped with a tire which may have imbedded in it wire or other material for improving traction on snow and ice during the period of October 1 through April 15 of each year. Such a tire shall be so constructed that the percentage of wire or other material in contact with the roadway does not exceed, after the first 1,000 miles of use or operations, 5% of the total tire area in contact with the roadway. During the first 1,000 miles of use or operation of any such tire, the wire or other material in contact with the roadway shall not exceed 20% of the total tire area in contact with the roadway. The studded tires allowed by this subsection shall not be used at any time on a vehicle with a maximum gross weight of more than 9,000 pounds, unless such a vehicle is a school bus or an emergency vehicle. 
(C)  It shall be permissible to use tire chains of reasonable proportions on any vehicle when required for safety because of snow, ice, or other conditions tending to cause a vehicle to skid. 
(D)  It shall be permissible to use farm machinery with tires having protuberances which will not injure a highway. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1511 - Policies, procedures and regulations authorized. 
The City Engineer is authorized to develop and implement such policies, procedures and regulations as may be necessary and desirable to control the movement of motor vehicles, trailers, semitrailers and other contrivances in order that traffic on and along the streets and roads of the City may be moved along for the benefit of all the citizens of the community. The policies, procedures and regulations authorized herein may include the following similar provisions: 
(A)  The requirement that the owner/operator of a vehicle submit an application for a permit specifically describing the vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved on the particular highways for which the permit to operate is requested, and whether such permit is requested for a single trip, or for continuous operation. The issuance of the permit shall be based upon the statement of the owner/operator as to weight, type, etc., of equipment, and should these statements be found incorrect, or if any of the conditions imposed by the permit are violated, the department may declare such permit void and the owner/operator subjected to the same penalty as if he had not obtained a permit. 
(B)  Such permit may be authorized or withheld at the discretion of the City Engineer; or, if such permit is issued, to limit or prescribe the conditions of operation of such vehicle or vehicles, and may require such undertaking or other security as may be deemed necessary to compensate for any injury to any roadway or roadway structure. 
(C)  The requirement that every such permit be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers, and shall be open to inspection by any police officer or authorized agent of the City. 
(D)  To designate such route or routes upon which any motor vehicles, trailers, semitrailers or other contrivances may be operated. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1512 - Penalty. 
Any person violating a provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine as provided in Code § 1-8 plus any other civil damages provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1513 - Large trucks prohibited on Haynes Drive. 
(A)  Trucks weighing 10,000 pounds or more, or possessing two or more rear axles are prohibited from using Haynes Drive, except for pick-up or deliveries along Haynes Drive or along streets connecting to Haynes Drive, except Thompson Lane and US Highway 231N. 
(B)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine as provided in Code § 1-8, plus any other civil damages provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 99-O-14 § 1, 05-27-99) 
Sections 32-1514-32-1599 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - RESERVED 

Sections 32-1600-32-1699 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - VEHICLE POUND 

Section 32-1700 - Reserved. 
Section 32-1701 - Established; purpose. 
Members of the Police Department shall have the authority to impound any vehicle, by towing such vehicle to the vehicle pound, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(A)  When a vehicle is parked, stopped or standing upon any alley, street or highway so as to obstruct or impede the flow of traffic thereon, or endanger the safety of the public. 
(B)  When a vehicle is parked, stopped, or standing in violation of Code § 32-1301(A)(1), (2) and (3). 
(C)  When a vehicle is parked in violation of Code § 32-1305(5), prohibiting storing a vehicle upon a roadway for a continuous period of time longer than 24 hours. If the vehicle appears abandoned, the officer shall prominently affix a sticker to the rear windshield on the driver's side. Said sticker shall include the date and time the sticker is placed on the windshield, the officer's name or badge number, the violation, and shall notify the owner that the vehicle will be impounded if not moved within 48 hours. If at the expiration of the 48-hour period the vehicle has not been moved, the officer may impound the vehicle. 
(D)  When a vehicle is parked upon any alley, street, highway, or any other municipally leased or owned property, and said vehicle has two or more delinquent parking tickets outstanding as to said vehicle. 
(E)  At any place where official signs or markings designate a "No Parking" or "Tow Away" zone. 
(F)  Violation of Code § 32-1334, or blocking access to ramps for handicapped persons. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 01-O-39 § 5, 08-09-01) 
Section 32-1702 - Notice to registered owner. 
(A)  After a vehicle has remained unclaimed in storage for 48 hours, the owner of the storage lot shall send a notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner of the impounded vehicle. Upon request, a representative of the police department shall determine the name and address of the registered owner from state registration records, using the vehicle's license plate number and vehicle identification number. 
(B)  The owner of the storage lot shall deliver the same notice to owners or authorized agents who appear at the impoundment lot to claim a vehicle. The vehicle owner or authorized agent shall acknowledge in writing receipt of the notice. If any person required by this section to sign a notice refuses to do so, the storage lot owner shall note this fact in writing, which shall constitute prima facie evidence of delivery of notice as required by this section. 
(C)  The notice shall contain: 
(1)  a description of the impounded vehicle; 
(2)  a statement of the date, time, location, and reason for impoundment; 
(3)  opportunity to a hearing as provided in Code § 32-1706; 
(4)  procedure for the release of the vehicle pending a hearing, subject to security requirements; 
(5)  impoundment fee schedule; and 
(6)  location of impoundment lot. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1703 - Procedures for operation and collection of storage charges. 
The Police Chief or Commissioner shall establish, by rules and regulations, the procedures for the operation of the vehicle impoundment lot. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1704 - Charges for towing and storage of vehicles. 
Whenever any vehicle is found parked in violation of Code §§ 32-740 or 32-1301 through 32-1334, the City Manager, the Mayor, the Police Chief or Commissioner, or any regular member of the police force of the City is authorized to have such vehicle removed from the place so found and to be stored at the expense of the owner or driver. The owner or driver shall be obligated to pay the hauling charges for so removing such vehicle and the storage charges on such vehicle before the person hauling and storing such vehicle shall be required to surrender possession of such vehicle to the owner or driver. 
Such hauling and storage charges shall be reasonable. The Police Commissioner, with discretion and with the approval of the City Manager, may arrange with persons, firms and corporations to remove such vehicles as provided for in this section, and to accept therefor reasonable hauling and storage charges as may be agreed upon by and between the Police Commissioner and such persons, firms and corporations. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Cross reference- Penalty for improper parking and violation of the parking limit, § 32-2101. 
Section 32-1705 - Release of vehicle from impoundment. 
(A)  The owner of the impounded vehicle or authorized agent may make application to take possession of the same, and remove such vehicle from the vehicle pound upon presentation of an application for certificate of title or a certificate of title, and upon payment of the cost of towing the vehicle and all charges which may have accrued for the storage of the vehicle. However, payment of towing and storage fees shall not relieve the owner of responsibility for the violation. 
(B)  Any owner who requests a hearing pursuant to Code § 32-1706 may obtain the release of the vehicle from the pound without prepayment of any towing or storage costs; provided, however, as security for the impoundment costs, the owner shall either make a cash deposit or execute a bond with one or more securities as approved by the Police Chief or Commissioner, payable to the City, in a sum equal to the total impoundment fees at the time of release of the vehicle. 
(C)  In each case, the owner of the storage lot, or officer in charge shall give a proper receipt for the fee paid, cash deposit or bond. 
(D)  No owner of a vehicle shall evade the payment of any pound fee herein provided for by representing that said owner was not operating the vehicle at the time of the violation charged. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1706 - Hearing in city court. 
(A)  An owner, whose vehicle has been towed and impounded pursuant to Code § 32-1701, shall have an opportunity for a hearing in City Court on the parking or traffic violation which resulted in the impoundment. 
(B)  If the Court enters a dismissal as to the violation, the Court may order the release of the impounded vehicle to the owner, the return of the cash deposit to the owner, or the release of the bond, whichever is applicable. 
(C)  If the Court enters a conviction as to the violation, the owner shall be liable for the towing and storage fees in addition to the fine and court costs. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1707 - Sale of unclaimed vehicles. 
(A)  If, at the end of 30 days, any impounded vehicle has not been claimed by its rightful owner or authorized agent, and the towing and accumulated storage fees have not been paid, then the Police Department shall furnish the name, type, model, serial number and motor number of such vehicle to the storage lot owner, who shall initiate the procedure to sell same for cash at public sale to the highest bidder. 
(B)  Notice of the sale shall be provided 21 days prior to the date of sale by certified letter to the registered owner of the vehicle and any lienholders, and by announcement in a local newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1708 - Records of vehicle pound fees. 
Proper records shall be maintained by the storage lot owner. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-1709 - Severability. 
If any provision of this article is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, or if the application of such section to any person or circumstance is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the other provisions or applications to this article, which shall be given effect without the invalid or unconstitutional provisions or application. To this extent, the provisions of this article are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Sections 32-1710-32-1799 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - ABANDONED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLES 

Section 32-1800 - Storing, parking or leaving abandoned or inoperable motor vehicles and other objects prohibited and declared a nuisance. 
(A)  An abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for a period of more than 48 hours. 
(B)  An inoperable motor vehicle means a motor vehicle that is unable to be self propelled. 
(C)  The presence of an abandoned, dismantled, or inoperable motor vehicle or other personal property, including but not limited to, recreational vehicle, camper, or sailboat, parked on a public street, in a City parking lot, or Civic Plaza parking garage for 24 hours is hereby declared a nuisance, which may be abated in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(D)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a motor vehicle in the Civic Plaza Parking Garage, or any City parking lot for a continuous and uninterrupted period of 48 hours. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this section shall not apply to any vehicle of a juror who is sequestered during a criminal trial, a City vehicle, a county vehicle, or a City or county employee's vehicle, provided the employee has the written permission of the City Manager or county executive, or designee, clearly displayed on the dash of the motor vehicle so it is visible through the windshield. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 92-37 § 1, 07-30-92) 
Section 32-1801 - Reserved. 
Section 32-1802 - Abandoned or inoperable vehicles and other personal property on public property. 
The City, through the Police Department or other department as designated by the City Manager, may take into custody any motor vehicle which is abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, or inoperable, and any personal property unlawfully parked or stored in violation of this article. The Department may employ its own personnel, equipment, and facilities, or hire persons, equipment, and facilities for the purpose of removing, preserving, and storing abandoned or inoperable vehicles and other personal property. Notice and disposal of the vehicle or personal property shall be in accord with Code §§ 32-1702 through 32-1707. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 92-37 § 3, 07-30-92) 
Section 32-1803 - Liability of owner. 
The owner of any abandoned vehicle or other personal property illegally parked or stored in violation of this article which has been removed and/or stored by the City shall be liable for all costs and expenses incurred by the City for the removal and storage. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 92-37 § 4, 07-30-92) 
Section 32-1804 - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $50.00, and each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Sections 32-1805-32-1899 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - RESERVED 

Sections 32-1900-32-1999 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Section 32-2000 - Putting glass, etc., on highway prohibited. 
(A)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any highway any glass, bottle, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any other substance likely to damage or injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such highway. 
(B)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any highway any destructive or injurious material or material which may cause a hazardous condition to exist, shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. If any such material is not expeditiously removed by the responsible person or organization, removal of the material may be ordered and the cost of such operations recovered from the responsible person or organization, in addition to all other applicable fines and penalties. 
(C)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the highway from such vehicle. 
(D)  No person shall paint, mark, deface, or damage any public street, sidewalk or curb without obtaining a permit or written consent from the Engineering Department. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this subsection (D) shall not apply to (i) public or private utilities or their contractors who mark their utilities in conjunction with construction projects of the utility, (ii) official traffic control markings placed by or under the direction of the City Engineer, City Traffic Department, or Tennessee Department of Transportation, (iii) centerline marks by registered surveyors or licensed engineers, or (iv) street numbers painted on the curb. All persons and corporations exempt from permits and those receiving permits under this section shall be subject to rules and regulations promulgated by the Engineering Department and approved by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 91-31 § 1, 06-06-91) 
Section 32-2001 - Funeral processions. 
(A)  A funeral procession composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia, or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the Police Department. 
(B)  Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand side of the roadway as practicable and safe, and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(C)  No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion, and when such vehicles are properly designated as required in this chapter. 
(D)  Subsections (B) and (C) shall not apply to funeral processions which have entered onto a highway of the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways or other highway incorporating similar design and access control features. In such cases, drivers of vehicles identified as provided in subsection (A) shall follow driving practices common for such highways and grant other drivers adequate opportunities to enter and leave such highways in a safe manner. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2002 - Unlawful riding. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon any portion of any vehicle not designed or intended for the use of passengers when the vehicle is in motion. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2003 - Boarding or alighting from vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion, except City garbage trucks. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2004 - Roadblocks prohibited; penalty. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to conduct a roadblock for the purpose of disseminating information or collecting funds inside the City. A roadblock is defined as standing in or along a public street where funds are sought from motorists on the public street. A roadblock shall be further defined as any person standing in a public street with a sign or poster for the purpose of advertising or informing the public. A roadblock does not include a public parade, which is properly authorized, and traffic stopped or controlled by the Police Department. 
(B)  Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 90-30 § 1(32-2020), 06-28-90) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-30 § 1, renumbered as § 32-2004. 
Sections 32-2005-32-2099 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXI. - PENALTIES AND PROCEDURES ON ARREST 

Section 32-2100 - Moving violation penalties. 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not more than $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 01-O-39 § 6, 08-09-01) 
Section 32-2101 - Penalty for improper parking and violation of the parking limit. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, driver, or operator of any vehicle to park a vehicle in a one-hour parking space for longer than one hour or in a two-hour parking space for longer than two hours as set forth in Code § 32-1312 between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(B)  Any person receiving a ticket shall have the right to contest its validity at a City Court hearing within ten days of issuance of the ticket. The date of the City Court hearing shall be specified on the ticket. For each such violation, the owner, driver, or operator of any such vehicle shall be fined in accordance with the following schedule, based upon when payment is received by City Court: 
Ticket(s) Per Day Paid Within 10 Days Paid After 10 Days & Within 30 Days Paid After 30 Days 1 $3.00 $10.00 $25.00 2 $15.00 $25.00 $40.00 3 or more $30.00 $40.00 $50.00  
(C)  It shall be conclusively presumed that the person or persons to whom a vehicle registration plate was issued was the individual responsible for incurring the violation and resultant liability or fine, unless the person proves said vehicle was used without express or implied authority at a City Court hearing. 
(D)  When there are outstanding tickets on a vehicle of $100.00 or more, the City is authorized to have such vehicle immobilized or removed from the place it is found at the expense of the owner, driver or operator. The owner, driver, or operator shall be obligated to pay any immobilization fee or hauling charges for removing the vehicle and the storage charges before the person immobilizing, hauling, or storing such vehicle shall be required to surrender possession of such vehicle to the owner or driver. Additionally, the person seeking return of the vehicle shall be required to pay all outstanding parking tickets on the vehicle before the vehicle is released. 
(E)  Any hauling, immobilization, or storage charges shall be reasonable. The City Manager has discretion, with the approval of the City Council, to enter into contractual agreements with persons, firms, and corporations for the removal of such vehicles as provided for in this section. 
(F)  Any person who believes their vehicle was immobilized or towed incorrectly may request and shall promptly receive a hearing before the City Judge; hearings shall be held within four weekdays of the request. A copy of this section shall be made available to the owner/operator of the subject vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89; Ord. No. 03-O-06 § 1, 03-20-03; Ord. No. 05-O-10 § 1, 03-31-05; Ord. No. 13-O-28 § 1, 09-26-13) 
Cross reference- Code § 32-1704, charges for towing and storage of vehicles. 
Section 32-2102 - Disposition of fines and forfeitures. 
All fines and forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into the City Treasury and deposited into the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2103 - Service of warrants outside City. 
Any duly and regularly appointed police officer of the City has the authority to serve warrants for the arrest of persons for municipal offenses committed within the municipal limits at any point within Rutherford County. 
(Ord. No. 03-O-06 § 2, 03-20-03) 
Section 32-2104 - Execution on municipal court judgments. 
(A)  When the City Court Judge has entered a judgment for fines and costs, and same remain unpaid for 30 days thereafter, the Court is authorized by and through its Clerk to issue execution thereon from the Court in the same manner and methods as prescribed in Title 26, Chapters 1-3, T.C.A., and the Clerk shall assess the same fees and costs as are allowable to Clerks of General Sessions Court. 
(B)  For purposes of service of a levy of execution or execution by garnishment, the police officers of the City are empowered to serve the same anywhere in Rutherford County. 
(Ord. No. 03-O-06 § 3, 03-20-03) 
Sections 32-2105-32-2109 - Reserved. 
Section 32-2110 - Certain arrested persons to sign notice to appear in court. 
(A)  Whenever a person is arrested for a violation of any provision of this chapter, and such person is not immediately taken before the City Judge, or released on bond pending a hearing before the City Judge, the arresting officer shall prepare in triplicate written notice to appear in court containing the name and address of such person, the license number of the vehicle, if any, the offense charged, and the time and place when and where such person shall appear in court. 
(B)  The time specified in said notice to appear must be fixed by the arresting officer, unless the person arrested shall demand an earlier hearing. 
(C)  The arrested person, in order to secure release as provided in this section, must give a written promise to appear in court by signing the written notice prepared by the arresting officer. The officer shall deliver a copy of the notice to the person promising to appear. Thereupon, said officer shall forthwith release the person arrested from custody. 
(D)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate a written promise to appear given to an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation, regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. A written promise to appear in court may be complied with by an appearance by counsel. 
(E)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $2.00 nor more than $50.00. 
(F)  In the event any person fails to comply with a traffic citation given to such person or attached to a vehicle, or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in City Court, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the City Court Clerk shall secure and issue a warrant for the person's arrest. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2111 - Citation on illegally parked vehicle. 
Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked, standing or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this City or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a parking citation for the driver to answer to the charge in City Court at the time and place specified in the citation. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2112 - Liability for parking violations when operator is other than owner. 
In all prosecutions for alleged violations of the provisions of this chapter relating to parking regulations, the owner of the vehicle involved shall be prima facie presumed to have been the operator or in control thereof at the time the alleged offense was committed. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2113 - Validity of citations and warrants. 
No traffic citation or warrant shall be declared void by reason of the fact that the incorrect ordinance or section number was cited, so long as the complaint or warrant states a cause of action sufficient to place the defendant on notice of the charge said defendant is called upon to defend against. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2114 - Reserved. 
Section 32-2115 - Inspection of nonconforming vehicles. 
(A)  Any police officer may stop and inspect any motor vehicle which appears to be operated in violation of Code §§ 32-1000 through 32-1027. If, upon inspection, the vehicle is found to be in violation of this article, the operator shall be issued a citation stating the particulars of the violation and, in general, the repairs necessary to bring the vehicle into compliance with this article. The citation shall also state a time and place for appearance in court, not less than 14 days from the date of the issuance of the citation. 
(B)  If, upon reinspection or upon presentation of a vehicle repair receipt signed by the mechanic at such an appearance, the defect is found to have been corrected, or if the vehicle is found to be in compliance with this article, the City Judge, may in the Judge's discretion, waive the fine and/or court costs. If, however, the vehicle is found not to be in compliance with this article, the operator shall be fined not less than $2.00 nor more than $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Sections 32-2116-32-2199 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXII. - EFFECT OF AND SHORT TITLE OF ORDINANCE 

Section 32-2200 - Application. 
The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer exclusively to the operation of vehicles upon streets, except where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2201 - Uniformity of interpretation. 
This chapter shall be so interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law of those authorities which enact it. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2202 - Effect of headings. 
Article and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope or extent of the provisions of any article or section thereof. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2203 - Short title. 
This chapter may be known and cited as the "Murfreesboro Traffic Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2204 - Ordinance not retroactive. 
This chapter shall not have a retroactive effect and shall not apply to any traffic accident, any cause of action arising out of a traffic accident or judgments arising therefrom, or any violation of any motor vehicle ordinance of this City, occurring prior to the effective date of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2205 - Effect of partial invalidity. 
If any part or parts of this chapter are for any reason held to be invalid, such decisions shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2206 - Repeal of existing ordinances. 
All existing ordinances covering the same matters as embraced in this chapter are hereby repealed, and all ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with the provision of this chapter are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Section 32-2207 - Effective date. 
Unless otherwise specified in and with reference to a particular section, this chapter shall take effect from and after the first day of November, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 89-42 § 1, 09-28-89) 
Sections 32-2208-32-2299 - Reserved. 
ARTICLES XXIII-XXIX. - RESERVED 

Sections 32-2300-32-2999 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXX. - WRECKER REGULATIONS 

Section 32-3000 - Reserved. 
Section 32-3001 - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Murfreesboro Wrecker Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3002 - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
City is the City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee. 
Chief of police shall mean commissioner of safety or Chief of Murfreesboro Police Department. 
G.V.W.R. means gross vehicle weight rating. 
MPD is the City of Murfreesboro Police Department. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Wrecker service is a person, firm, partnership, association, or corporation engaged in the business, or offering the services, of a vehicle wrecker or towing service to the public for a fee in the City, whereby disabled motor vehicles are towed or otherwise removed from the place where they are disabled by use of a wrecker so designed for that purpose or by a truck, automobile or other vehicle so adapted to that purpose. The term "wrecker service" shall not include a business located outside the territorial jurisdiction of the City which occasionally passes through or delivers within the territorial jurisdiction of the City, unless such wrecker service both picks up and delivers vehicles within the territorial jurisdiction of the City. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3003 - License required. 
No wrecker service shall engage in business within the City or offer such service within the City without first obtaining a license as hereinafter provided from the Chief of Police. The license required herein is in addition to any business tax license. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3004 - Application for license. 
Applications for licenses issued hereunder shall be made upon blank forms prepared and made available by the Chief of Police and shall state: 
(A)  The name, home address, and proposed business address of the applicant. 
(B)  The location, description and hourly availability of the tow trucks owned or operated by the applicant. 
(C)  Description of any available space for properly accommodating and protecting all disabled motor vehicles to be towed or otherwise removed from the place where they are disabled. 
(D)  Such other information as the Chief of Police shall find reasonably necessary to effectuate the purpose of this article and to arrive at a fair determination of whether the terms of this article have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3005 - Application fee. 
An application hereunder shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3006 - Insurance. 
(A)  Insurance policies. No license shall be issued to an applicant hereunder until the applicant shall have deposited with the Chief of Police the following insurance policies: 
(1)  Garage keeper's policy. A garage keeper's legal liability policy covering fire, theft, and explosion in the minimum amounts of $50,000.00, and collision coverage subject to a maximum of $1,000.00 deduction with each accident deemed a separate claim. 
(2)  Garage liability policy. A garage liability policy, covering the operation of applicant's business, equipment, or vehicles, for any bodily injury or property damage. This policy will be in the amount of $100,000.00 for any one person killed or injured and $300,000.00 for more than one person injured or killed in any one accident. This policy shall also provide $50,000.00 coverage for all damage arising out of injury to or destruction or loss of property. 
(3)  Each wrecker service is encouraged to have insurance limits higher than those provided in subsections (1) and (2) above. 
(B)  Notice of change or cancellation. Each policy required herein must contain an endorsement providing for 14 days notice to the City in the event of any material change or cancellation. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3007 - Investigation by Chief of Police. 
Within 14 days after receipt of an application as provided for herein the Chief of Police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and of the proposed operation. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3008 - Standards for issuance. 
(A)  The Chief of Police shall issue a license hereunder when it is found: 
(1)  that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed wrecker service for which application has been submitted; 
(2)  that insurance policies as required by this article have been procured; 
(3)  that the applicant and drivers are fit and proper persons to conduct or work in the proposed business. If the applicant or driver does not have a valid Tennessee driver's license, the applicant shall not be considered a fit and proper person. The minimum age for a driver on the MPD call list is 18 years of age. If the applicant or driver has been convicted of the felony of theft, fraud, the sale or distribution of narcotics, burglary, or similar crimes of dishonesty within the past six years, the applicant shall not be considered a fit and proper person to serve on the MPD call list, subject however, to the due process rights set forth in Code § 32-3017(F) where the applicant must establish by a preponderance of the evidence that exclusion would be unfair, arbitrary, or capricious. 
(4)  That the requirements of this article and all other governing laws and ordinances have been met. 
(B)  A second license will not entitle the wrecker service to a second position on the call list of the MPD unless the applicant clearly shows and demonstrates that the second business is a distinct and different business from the first which holds a license. If the second business (i) is located on the same zone lot as a business holding a license; or (ii) utilizes the same phone system as a business holding a license; or (iii) utilizes the same equipment in whole or part as a business holding a license; or (iv) utilizes the same storage lot owned or under lease by a business holding a license and one of factors (i), (ii), (iii), or (v) is also present; or (v) utilizes the services of an employee of a wrecker service holding a license and one of factor (i) through (iv) is also present, it shall be conclusively presumed that the second applicant is the same as the first for the purposes of this article and as it applies to the privilege of the applicant to participate in the MPD call list. 
(C)  If the wrecker service changes 50% or more ownership, it will be removed from the City rotation or call list until a new license is issued, at which time the wrecker service will be treated as a new business for the purpose of the MPD call list. Notice shall be given to the City within 30 days of any such transfer. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3009 - License fee. 
A license shall be issued to a successful applicant hereunder after payment to the City of a license fee of $25.00 per vehicle. The fee is for one calendar year or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3010 - Promulgation of regulations by Chief of Police. 
The Chief of Police shall adopt and enforce reasonable rules and regulations for wrecker services on the MPD call list. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3011 - Duties of licensees. 
A wrecker service license hereunder shall be issued subject to the following conditions: 
(A)  Exhibition of sticker. The Chief of Police shall issue to a licensed wrecker service a sticker which the wrecker service shall at all times prominently display on the right front windshield of each wrecker or other vehicle used for towing purposes. 
(B)  Maintenance of equipment. Wrecker services shall keep and maintain towing equipment which is adequate to perform such towing service in a reasonably workmanlike manner, and shall be subject to inspection by MPD at any time. 
(C)  Compliance with rate schedule. Wrecker services on the City call list shall charge for their services such rates which do not exceed those fixed by ordinance when on a City call. Wrecker services may charge less than the maximum rate fixed by ordinance. 
(D)  Rotation of City towing. Wrecker services may perform towing service for the City on a rotation basis, but only in accordance with policies of MPD. 
(E)  Interception of police calls. No wrecker service shall intercept police calls by shortwave radio and respond to wrecks without a request from MPD or the vehicle owner or operator desiring service. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3012 - Revocation; hearing. 
(A)  Revocation of license. The Chief of Police may revoke a license issued hereunder when any of the following grounds may be found: 
(1)  the license was procured by fraudulent conduct or false statement of a material fact, or that a fact concerning the applicant was not disclosed at the time of making the application, and such fact would have constituted just cause for refusal to issue said license; 
(2)  the licensee responded to an accident or disabled vehicle without receiving a lawful call or request; 
(3)  the licensee paid any form of a gratuity to any third person not involved in the accident for information as to the location of the accident; 
(4)  the licensee has violated the fee schedule by overcharging; or, 
(5)  the licensee has violated any of the requirements of this article or any of the rules and regulations established by the Chief of Police or the City Council. 
(B)  Due process hearing. Any person or applicant aggrieved by action under this article shall be entitled to a due process hearing by giving written notice to the Chief of Police within seven days of the action which is the subject of the requested due process hearing. The hearing officer shall be designated by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3013 - Wrecker classifications. 
The following classifications shall be established for wrecker service: 
(A)  Class A - For towing passenger cars, pickup trucks, and small trailers: 
(1)  the tow truck chassis shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of one ton (10,000 pounds G.V.W.R.); 
(2)  individual boom capacity of not less than four tons; 
(3)  individual power winch pulling capacity of not less than four tons; 
(4)  one hundred feet or more of three-eighth-inch cable on each drum; 
(5)  belt type cradle tow plate or tow sling to pick up vehicles; cradle of tow plate to be equipped with safety chain; 
(6)  dollies; 
(7)  wheel lift: wreckers possessing equipment capable of lifting the vehicle by the wheels only, with nothing touching the vehicle body: 
(a)  wheel lift wreckers shall meet all Class "A" requirements (Section V, Part A), excluding the belt type tow plate or tow sling; 
(b)  safety restraint straps (nylon straps with ratchets or equivalent) shall be provided to secure the towed vehicle's tires into the wheel-lift forks; and, 
(8)  any wrecker service responding to a call from MPD shall have a wrecker equipped with a wheel lift. A rollback may be substituted for a wrecker with a wheel lift. 
(B)  Class B - For towing medium size trucks, and trailers: 
(1)  the tow truck chassis shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of one and one-half tons (18,000 pounds G.V.W.R.); 
(2)  boom specifications: 
(a)  double booms so constructed as to permit splitting; each boom to operate independently or jointly; individual boom capacity of no less than eight tons, and individual power winch pulling capacity of no less than eight tons; or 
(b)  single boom with no less than a 16-ton capacity and a power winch pulling capacity of no less than 16 tons. 
(3)  two hundred feet or more of seven-sixteenth-inch or larger cable on each drum; and, 
(4)  cradle tow plate or tow sling to pick up vehicle; cradle of tow plate to be equipped with safety chain. 
(C)  Class C - For towing large trucks, road tractors and trailers: 
(1)  the truck chassis shall have a minimum manufacturer's capacity of not less than three tons (30,000 pounds G.V.W.R.); 
(2)  boom specifications: 
(a)  double booms so constructed as to permit splitting; each boom to operate independently or jointly; individual boom capacity of not less than 121/2 tons and individual power winch pulling capacity of not less than 121/2 tons; or 
(b)  single boom with not less than 25-ton capacity and a power winch pulling capacity of not less than 25 tons. 
(3)  two hundred feet or more of nine-sixteenth-inch cable on each drum; and 
(4)  air brakes so constructed as to lock wheels automatically upon failure. 
(D)  Class D - Vehicle transporters designed to tow or carry passenger cars, pickup trucks, small trailers, etc., "damage-free": 
(1)  "rollback" type vehicle transporters: 
(a)  the truck chassis shall have minimum manufacturer's capacity of one ton (10,000 pounds G.V.W.R.); 
(b)  two lift cylinders, minimum three-inch bore, or one lift cylinder, minimum five-inch bore; 
(c)  individual power winch pulling capacity of not less than four tons; 
(d)  fifty feet or more of five-sixteenth-inch cable or larger on cable drum; 
(e)  two safety chains for securing vehicle to carrier bed; 
(f)  carrier bed shall be a minimum of 16 feet in length and a minimum of 84 in. in width inside side rails; and, 
(g)  cab protector, constructed of solid steel or aluminum, that extends at least to the top of the cab. 
(2)  "Rollback" type vehicle transporters or dollies: 
(a)  upon request by a police officer or the owner or operator of a vehicle to be towed a "rollback" type vehicle transporter shall be used; and, 
(b)  if a "rollback" is used for a vehicle which would otherwise require dollies, a dolly fee may be added to the wrecker fee. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3014 - Storage facilities. 
(A)  Wrecker services on the MPD call list must be equipped to provide a lot or building for proper, safe, and secure storage: 
(1)  the storage facility must be within two-tenths mile of the office of the wrecker service, measured along the street; 
(2)  the wrecker service shall be responsible for the storage, safekeeping, and prevention of vandalism of all vehicles and contents towed for MPD; 
(3)  the storage facility shall be secured by a fence, wall, or natural barrier a minimum of 6 ft. high to deter trespassing or vandalism; 
(4)  the storage facility shall be staffed or available for access between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding City legal holidays; and, 
(5)  the storage area shall have a minimum of 5,000 sq. ft. and accommodate all vehicles towed by the wrecker service for MPD. 
(B)  Subsection (A) shall not apply to a wrecker service which is open 24 hours, seven days per week which stores vehicles on the premises. 
(C)  The operations officer of MPD, or designated representative, will be notified of all vehicles which are towed at the request of MPD that are held over 15 days. 
(D)  Violations of any of the above requirements or regulations shall be cause for suspension or removal from the MPD call list. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3015 - Equipment. 
(A)  Each wrecker used on the MPD call list shall be capable of highly efficient performance at the scene of an accident. 
(B)  Emergency equipment (all wreckers): 
(1)  at least one functional, amber-colored, rotor beam or strobe type light shall be mounted on the top of the wrecker. No other color will be approved by MPD. All emergency flasher and directional lights showing to the front must be amber in color; and 
(2)  sirens on wreckers or service trucks are prohibited. 
(C)  The following additional equipment on all wreckers is required: 
(1)  at least one heavy duty push broom; 
(2)  flood lights mounted at a height sufficient to illuminate the scene at night; 
(3)  one shovel; 
(4)  one axe; 
(5)  one pinchbar, prybar, or crowbar; 
(6)  one set of boltcutters; and, 
(7)  minimum of 120-pound Class A, B, C Underwriter Laboratory Listed Fire Extinguisher. 
(D)  The appearance of wreckers on the MPD call list shall be clean, painted, and in good repair. 
(E)  All tow trucks shall display the firm's name, address, and phone number. Such information shall be painted on or permanently affixed to both sides. All lettering shall be at least 3 in. high. Magnetic signs will not be permitted. 
(F)  Wrecker services shall be responsible for carrying the equipment necessary for removal of glass and other debris from highways and roadways following each accident. The wrecker operator is responsible for utilizing the equipment for such removals (T.C.A. § 55-8-170). 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3016 - Services and procedures. 
(A)  Wrecker service on the MPD call list shall be available for immediate response 24 hours a day: 
(1)  the requested wrecker must respond within 25 minutes of the call, or the next scheduled wrecker will be called and the first will lose their turn; 
(2)  the responding wrecker(s) must display the firm's name as called for by the MPD dispatcher; and, 
(3)  a wrecker service cannot refer a call on the MPD call list to another wrecker or substitute another company's wrecker. This shall not apply to a request by the vehicle owner or operator even though the request is made through MPD. 
(B)  Wrecker services shall not perform repair work on towed vehicles without the owner's written request. 
(C)  Hold orders placed by the court or commissioned MPD members on vehicles stored for any reason shall be honored by the wrecker service: 
(1)  hold orders shall be placed on vehicles only when necessary for further investigation, including but not limited to, investigations to determine ownership, to determine if vehicle is stolen or contains contraband or is an instrument of a crime; 
(2)  hold orders shall not be placed on vehicles to obtain information from the owner, driver or suspected driver; and, 
(3)  hold orders by MPD shall be released as soon as possible following the completion of the necessary investigation, and in any event within 72 hours unless MPD requests longer in writing. 
(D)  When no hold order is placed, the vehicle shall be released to the owner upon proof of ownership or authorization of the owner, and when the necessary financial transactions between vehicle owner and wrecker service are completed. 
(E)  Wrecker services shall transport vehicles to any location requested by the owner/operator after financial obligations have been finalized, subject to subsection (C) above. 
(F)  Calls involving an accident within the City limits received by a wrecker service shall be cleared through MPD before the wrecker proceeds to the scene, even if the owner calls the wrecker direct. No wrecker shall remove a wrecked vehicle without it being investigated by a law enforcement agency. A log shall be maintained by dispatchers of MPD so the owners and operators may be informed of the location of towed vehicles. 
(G)  Soliciting at the scene is prohibited by the owner, operator, or representative of any wrecker services. 
(H)  Amber lights may be used while proceeding to, and SHALL be used at, and when towing from the scene. 
(I)  When a wrecker service receives a call for a Class "B" wrecker, it will not affect the wrecker service's status on the Class "A" call list. 
(J)  All wrecker services shall be prohibited from responding to or running to wrecks without a bona fide call from the MPD dispatcher or request from the owner. 
(K)  If a wrecker service desires to be off duty for any length of time, the wrecker service shall inform the MPD dispatcher to avoid losing their turn on the call list. Upon returning, the wrecker service will be placed back on the rotating list. A wrecker service that is not available for 24-hour service is subject to removal from the MPD call list. 
(L)  A wrecker service which accepts a call but fails to answer the call will lose the call. If the problem is recurrent, an investigation will be made by the operations officer of MPD and the wrecker service is subject to removal from the MPD call list. 
(M)  Wrecker(s) are restricted to a maximum of two daytime and two nighttime telephone numbers on the MPD call list. "Call waiting" and "call forwarding" are recommended. Pagers and beepers are not allowed. 
(N)  Wrecker services refusing a call without good cause, or failing to respond promptly to a call, may be removed from the call list. 
(O)  When multiple cars are involved and multiple wrecker services are called: 
(1)  the first wrecker arriving at the scene will tow the car causing the greatest traffic hazard, which will be determined by a member of MPD; 
(2)  if a requested wrecker arrives first, the wrecker will help remove vehicles causing traffic hazard from roadway, then pick up the requested vehicle; or 
(3)  if a wrecker service has two or more wreckers, two or more vehicles may be towed without loss of turn on the rotation, provided all wreckers can respond simultaneously. 
(P)  Only one wrecker service shall be called to any one vehicle accident. If additional equipment or recovery vehicles are needed to adequately complete a tow (i.e. tractor-trailer, rollover or difficult auto recovery), discretion of the responding wrecker should be used in deciding what and whose additional equipment will be required. The severity of the situation and the estimated response time of additional equipment will be weighed by the officer at the scene, who is the deciding authority. 
(Q)  Towing rates of each class will be stipulated (a wrecker who uses a Class "C" or Class "B" wrecker on a Class "A" call, must charge only for a Class "A" call). 
(R)  Current tow and storage rates shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the wrecker service location. 
(S)  Any wrecker service whose tow rates on the MPD call list violate Code § 32-3018 may be removed from the MPD call list. 
(T)  The vehicle owner/operator shall be responsible for payment of towing and related service charges. Payment shall be rendered prior to delivery or release of the vehicle by the towing company. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3017 - General regulations. 
The wrecker services on the MPD call list shall comply with the following general regulations: 
(A)  A wrecker service will not be permitted to operate wrecker equipment under more than one company name. See Code § 32-3008(B). 
(B)  All wrecker services are expected to be familiar with and comply with the traffic laws of the State of Tennessee and Murfreesboro City Ordinances. 
(C)  Wrecker services shall abide by all applicable rules and regulations of MPD. 
(D)  Failure to meet the foregoing requirements will prevent wrecker services from being placed on the MPD call list. 
(E)  Violations of any of the above requirements or regulations shall be cause for suspension or removal from the MPD call list after investigation. 
(F)  MPD shall investigate all complaints of service and violations of this chapter: 
(1)  any valid complaint may result in suspension of towing privileges for a period or removal from the MPD call list; 
(2)  after any suspension, the wrecker service must reapply, and meet all requirements of this article. If the application is approved, the wrecker service will be placed on the call list at the end of the rotation, one full cycle; 
(3)  copies of complaints, investigative reports, and recommended action will be forwarded to the offices of the Assistant Chief and Chief of Police; 
(4)  wrecker services will be advised in writing of suspension or removal by the operations officer or designated representative; and, 
(5)  wrecker services desiring a due process hearing shall give written notice within seven days to the Chief of Police. 
(G)  If a parking citation is not issued and the owner or operator of a vehicle believes the vehicle was towed without just cause, and/or was unfairly charged, or otherwise dealt with by MPD, a complaint may be filed with MPD. MPD shall conduct an investigation into the complaint. If the investigation reveals that the said vehicle was towed without just cause, and/or the owner was unfairly charged and/or otherwise dealt with, the owner shall have the vehicle released to the owner without charge or for an amount established by MPD. Either party is entitled to a due process hearing by giving written notice within seven days to the Chief of Police. If a parking violation is involved, Code § 32-1706 shall control the due process hearing rights of the owner or operator. 
(H)  Wrecker services shall sweep and carry away the debris off the street at the accident scene. If two or more wreckers respond, all are equally responsible for removing debris, regardless of the vehicle(s) towed. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91; Ord. No. 01-O-39 § 7, 08-09-01) 
Section 32-3018 - Maximum fees for MPD call list. 
(A)  It is the policy of MPD to regulate the maximum fee(s) which may be imposed upon the owner of a vehicle which has been towed as a result of action by MPD. 
(B)  As a condition of being placed on the MPD call list, any wrecker service shall agree to abide by the current schedule of maximum allowable fees as set forth below and to apply a uniform rate schedule for all customers of the wrecker service in response to the MPD call list. (This does not mean all wrecker services have the same rate.) The following are the maximum rates: 
Regular tow, (7:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.) ..... $40.00 
Regular tow, (5:00 p.m. - 10:00 p.m.) ..... 45.00 
Regular tow, (10:00 p.m. - 7:00 a.m.) ..... 50.00 
Holiday (City Holidays) rate in addition to tow fee) ..... 10.00 
Roll back - Requested (in addition to tow fee) ..... 30.00 
Dolly fee (in addition to tow fee) ..... 30.00 
Change tire (each tire) ..... 9.00 
Remove drive shaft ..... 20.00 
Upright overturned vehicle ..... 27.00 
Winching (flat rate) ..... 25.00 
Unlock vehicle without key ..... 15.00 
Unpin transmission ..... 15.00 
Waiting time for utilities, etc. (per hour) ..... 30.00 
Service call (no tow) one-half (1/2) wrecker call rate. 
Service call (to retrieve previously towed vehicle) Same as above. 
Storage - Outside, per day ..... 8.00 
*Storage - Outside, covered w/tarp, per day ..... 10.00 
*Storage - Inside building, per day ..... 15.00 
Separate entangled vehicles without tow, 1/4 wrecker call rate for each vehicle. 
[*At the request of vehicle owner or police officer only.] 
NOTE: Wrecker services may charge the applicable day rate for each day or fraction thereof, except that there shall be no storage charge for the first six hours from the dispatch time, shown on the police tow-in report, provided the owner claims the vehicle within that six-hour period. 
No extra charge will be allowed for the use of wheel lifts. No extra charge will be allowed for sweeping debris at an accident scene under 30 minutes, and the charge will be no greater than the rate for waiting time set forth above. 
The requirement for a uniform rate schedule shall not apply to a continuing long term contract between the wrecker service and a customer such as a car dealership. 
(C)  If a wrecker service is requested to release a vehicle or personal property from the vehicle by the owner or operator, the wrecker service shall release the personal property or vehicle within two hours of the request, subject to payment of charges due or posting of bond as provided in Code § 32-1705(B), and subject to Code § 32-3016(C). Any vehicle or personal property released during normal working hours shall not be subject to an additional charge for same. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3019 - Display of rate card. 
Every wrecker service on the MPD call list shall have the current rate card issued by the City setting forth the maximum authorized rates and charges displayed in such a place as to be in full view of anyone wishing to inspect same. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3020 - Receipts. 
The driver of any wrecker shall render to the operator or owner of any vehicle to be towed a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the licensee, amount of charges, date of transaction and type of vehicle towed. The licensee shall keep a copy of such receipts and shall permit the City to inspect, at any time during the business hours of the day, such receipts or to produce same before the City upon request. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3021 - Licensee to maintain daily manifest. 
Every licensee shall maintain or cause to be maintained a daily manifest upon which is recorded all vehicles transported or towed each day, showing the time and place of origin and destination of each trip, and type of vehicle and the amount of charge or rate. Every licensee shall retain and preserve all manifests in a safe place for at least the calendar year next preceding the current calendar year, and such manifests shall be made available to the City for inspection at all times. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3022 - Accident reports. 
All accidents arising from or in connection with the operation of wreckers which result in death or injury to any person or damage to any property in an amount exceeding the sum of $400.00 shall be reported within 48 hours from the time of occurrence to MPD on a form to be furnished by the Department. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3023 - Instructions of vehicle owners, operators and police. 
The driver of the wrecker shall tow, transport or convey the vehicle to be towed to any place designated by the owner of such vehicle. It shall be unlawful for the owner, driver or driver helper or operator of a wrecker or an agent, employee or representative of the owner or driver of a wrecker at the scene of any accident, to high-pressure or otherwise coerce or insist upon any owner or operator of a vehicle to sign a work order or agreement at the scene of the place from which the vehicle is to be transported for any repairs to be made on such vehicle. The driver of the wrecker shall in all cases, before moving the vehicle to be towed, ask of the owner or operator of such vehicle the place to which the owner desires the vehicle to be taken and shall so transport such vehicle to such place upon the towing charges being paid or secured; otherwise, the vehicle shall be towed or transported to the wrecker operator's storage lot. If the vehicle to be transported is involved in an accident and the owner or operator thereof is unable to give any instructions in the owner or operator's own behalf, the driver of the wrecker shall transport the wrecked vehicle to the location or facility designated as the wrecker service's place of storage in the application for a license and it will be presumed and considered prima facie evidence that the owner or operator of such vehicle consents to and desires that the vehicle be transported to such place or facility. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3024 - Unlawful acts of nonlicensed persons. 
(A)  It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to knowingly or willfully summon a wrecker, or report that a wrecker is needed when such person should reasonably know that the services of a wrecker are not needed. 
(B)  It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to operate a wrecker service or a wrecker within the geographical jurisdiction of the City without a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. See Code § 32-3002(C). 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Section 32-3025 - Penalties. 
(A)  Any person violating the terms and provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to revocation of the license, and fine as provided in Code § 1-8. Upon the first violation, the revocation shall be for a period of time up to but not exceeding six months. The second violation within any five-year period will subject the licensee to revocation up to but not exceeding one year. A third violation within any five-year period shall subject the licensee to revocation for a period up to but not exceeding two years. A fourth violation within any five-year period shall subject the licensee to revocation for a period up to but not exceeding five years. 
(B)  Upon revocation of a license, all fees previously paid shall be forfeited. 
(C)  If the wrecker service loses its license due to revocation, the wrecker service owner, nor any member of the wrecker service owner's household, may obtain a license under a different business name for the period of revocation. 
(Ord. No. 91-17 § 1, 03-28-91) 
Chapter 32.5 - TREE MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1992-O-04, added Chap. 34, renumbered Chap. 32.5. 

Section 32.5-1 - Purpose and intent. 
(A)  The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the planting, maintenance, and removal of all trees in public areas in the City by and through: 
(1)  the establishment of a Tree Board; 
(2)  the establishment of the Urban Environmental Department as the agency prescribing regulations, subject to prior approval of the City Council, relating to the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees in public areas; 
(3)  the provision for the issuing of permits for the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees in public areas; 
(4)  the provision for the pruning and removal of trees on private property which endanger public safety; and, 
(5)  the provision for prescribing penalties for violations of these regulations. 
(B)  The purpose of the landmark tree designation program is to preserve and protect the cultural heritage, natural resources, aesthetic enhancement, and those environmentally sensitive areas inherent in those trees or tree groups so designated. From and after such time as a tree is designated as being a landmark tree, it shall be subject to all rules, regulations and/or requirements prescribed by this chapter. 
(C)  The standards set out herein are hereby established in order to encourage the planting of trees within the City; to encourage the maintenance and protection of existing trees; to encourage the removal of hazardous, undesirable, or diseased/pest-infested trees; and, to reduce air pollution and promote clean air quality through increased dust filtration, reduction of noise, heat and glare. 
(Ord. No. 92-O-04 § 1, 03-24-94; Ord. No. 94-O-71 § 1, 05-05-94) 
Section 32.5-2 - Name. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "Tree Management." 
(Ord. No. 92-O-04 § 1, 03-24-94; Ord. No. 94-O-71 § 1, 05-05-94) 
Section 32.5-3 - Definitions.
