Cross reference- Water connections and tapping charges, § 33-2. 

Section 33-50 - Sanitary sewer connection or tapping fees and house service fees or charges. 
Upon request for a new sewer connection or additional use of an existing sewer connection as described in subsection (A)(4) below, the same shall be granted upon payment of a sanitary sewer connection or tapping fee and, in appropriate cases as hereinafter provided, upon the payment of a sanitary sewer house service fee or charge, in accordance with the following provisions of this section and the following schedule, to wit: 
(A)  Connection fee. 
(1)  The sewer connection or tapping fee for each connection, unless specified otherwise in this section 33-50, shall be as follows: 
Customer Description Connection Fee Single-family residence $1,800.00 per unit prior to March 1, 2012 and, on and after March 1, 2012, $2,550.00 per unit Multifamily, condominium apartments, mobile homes $2,550.00 per unit Restaurants $110.00 per seat Hotels/motels $800.00 per room Retail shop and service establishments $2,550.00 per unit Hospitals/Nursing Home $800.00 per bed Schools $24.00 per student Office complex, 5,000 square feet or more $2,550.00 per SFU Equivalent  and, for each and every 1,000 square feet of habitable floor space over 5,000 square feet $2,550.00 per SFU Equivalent Office complex, over 35,000 square feet $2,550.00 per SFU Equivalent Laundries $2,550.00 per SFU Equivalent Car Wash:  Automatic Nylon Brush $16,800.00 per bay and per SFU Equivalent for Special Sanitary Sewer Assessment Districts  Full Service Attended  Brushless Automatic If there is a car wash associated with a convenience store, the above car wash sewer connection fee shall apply plus connection fees for one retail shop and service establishment, or multiple thereof, if more than one shop. Any of the categories itemized above that discharge into a Decentralized Wastewater Treatment Facility (e.g., Recirculating Sand Filter) whose effluent is land applied through a drip irrigation system and whose assets have been dedicated to MWSD will not be subject to any sanitary sewer connection fees. Sewer connection fees may be assessed as set by resolution on a case-by-case basis should the decentralized wastewater treatment system be funded by MWSD and system development charges (i.e., capacity buy-in fees) required for recoupment of rate payer funded assets. House service charges based on ROW width: Right-of-way less than 50 feet $1,000.00 where existing laterals exist to edge of ROW. 
For new taps and laterals, O&M material and labor costs recouped. Over 50 feet and less than 60 feet Over 60 feet and less than 80 feet 80 feet and greater Notwithstanding the foregoing, the house service charges for customers (i) paying monthly sewer charges on the effective date of this section for the property in question, (ii) who are not actually connected to the public sewers, and (iii) who have a house service line already in place to serve the subject property may connect to the public sewers before January 1, 2002, and pay the house service charges in effect before adoption of this section. Sewer Clean Out Connection: $100.00  
(2)  When the applicant for sewer services does not fit into one of the foregoing categories, the connection fee shall be based on $2,550.00 for each 260 gallons per average daily demand (gpd). 
(3)  The sewer connection fee for sewer service to any industrial use, or commercial space exceeding 35,000 square feet, shall be fixed and established by the City Council upon recommendation of the Board after considering and taking into account the location, size, extent, nature and requirements of such customer, and the estimated cost of furnishing such sewer service to the customer, and further considering the estimated usage, occupancy and plumbing fixtures to be installed. 
(4)  It shall be presumed that there is a request for additional sewer use and an additional sewer connection or tapping fee shall be paid for the additional use when: 
(a)  An additional water meter connection is requested, except when the request is for a water meter installed for the sole purpose of irrigation; 
(b)  The existing water meter or water connection is enlarged; 
(c)  A new sewer connection is made to the public sewer line. Notwithstanding the foregoing, when an existing commercial or industrial property is partitioned or subdivided without any new construction or change in use or capacity, and the applicant requests a new sewer connection, or a new sewer connection is required by Code § 29-10, the applicant shall not be required to pay a sewer connection or tapping fee; 
(d)  A building enlargement consisting of a minimum of 5,000 sqare feet exclusive of garage, shop and warehouse space; 
(e)  The number of additional plumbing fixtures exceeds 12; 
(f)  The change involves an additional industrial discharge of a minimum of 20% of the prechange 12-month average; 
(g)  Substantial change in use, including, but not limited to, single-family residence to duplex or multifamily, commercial building to restaurant, warehouse to commercial use or industry, service station expansion to include automated car wash or commercial building to laundromat; or 
(h)  Demolition of an existing commercial or industrial building and construction of a new building; but not for replacement of same or similar building destroyed by fire or tornado, provided such building was not vacant for 12 consecutive months next preceding the fire or tornado. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any applicant who demolishes an existing industrial or commercial building and constructs a new building on the same lot of record for the same type use or a use with a "similar" water consumption in the sole discretion of the Board, shall be entitled to a credit for any documented connection fee previously paid for service to the demolished building, but not to exceed the current applicable connection fee. "Similar" shall mean anticipated usage no greater than the previous user's 13-month average plus 10%. Any residential customer whose building is demolished may reconnect for the same type residential service without paying an additional connection fee. In all cases, the customer shall be responsible for any changes, such as a new, replaced, or relocated meter connection, service lines, or complete water tap for the reconnected service. 
(5)  (a)  If the request is for a new sewer connection or sewer service for a new customer or for additional sewer use for a restaurant operation at a location used as a restaurant within the 36 months prior to the application or for which a restaurant connection fee has been paid to the City since March 5, 1987, and no additional seating capacity is proposed for the location, then no new connection fee shall be required. 
(b)  If the request is for a sewer connection or sewer service for a new customer or for additional sewer use for a restaurant operation at a location used as a restaurant within the 36 months prior to the application or for which a restaurant connection fee has been paid to the City since March 5, 1987, and additional seating capacity is proposed for the location, then an additional connection fee calculated on the additional seating capacity shall be required. 
(c)  If the request is for a sewer connection or sewer service for a new customer for a restaurant operation at a location not used as a restaurant within the 36 months prior to the application and for which no restaurant connection fee has been paid to the City since March 5, 1987, then payment of the connection fee set forth in subsection (A)(1) herein, calculated on the basis of total seating capacity shall be required. 
(d)  Seating capacity for a restaurant shall be calculated one seat per each 15 square feet of area used for serving patrons. 
(e)  It shall be presumed that there is a request for additional sewer use and an additional connection fee shall be paid for any increase in seating capacity in a restaurant. 
(B)  Where a lateral sanitary sewer or sewers in a public street or streets or other public thoroughfare or thoroughfares or place or places has or have not been constructed and installed within the corporate limits of the City and is or are not available for sanitary sewer connection thereto by the owners of property abutting thereon or by the owners of other property if any that would be served by such lateral sewer or sewers if constructed and installed, and where the City acting by and through its City Council, upon petition of the owners of 65% or of such other percentage of the properties abutting on such street, streets, thoroughfare, thoroughfares, place or places and of other properties if any that would be served by such lateral sewer or sewers as shall be specifically approved by the City Council, requesting the construction and installation of such sanitary sewer or sewers and wherein each petitioning owner or owners of every such property shall agree to pay in cash to the City, prior to the award of a contract or contracts for the construction and installation of such sewer or sewers, a house service fee or charge in addition to the connection or tapping fee prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof, in accordance with the schedule of house service fees or charges hereinafter in this subsection (B) set forth, shall, after the effective date of this section, authorize the construction and installation of a lateral sanitary sewer or sewers in such public street, streets, thoroughfare, thoroughfares, place or places as said City Council shall specify, the sanitary sewer house service fees or charges for each connection for sewer service from each such property to any such lateral sewer, to be paid by the respective petitioning property owner or owners and to be collected by the City prior to the award of such contract or contracts, shall be as set forth in the following schedule, to wit: 
House service charges based on ROW width: 
$1,000.00 where existing laterals exist to edge of ROW. 
For new taps and laterals, O&M material and labor costs recouped. 
The foregoing house service fees or charges shall be in addition to the connection or tapping fee prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof, and petitioning property owners shall be required to pay such connection or tapping fee at and prior to the time of actual connection for sewer service to any such lateral sewer. Nonpetitioning owners of such properties, who later request or are required pursuant to the provisions of any ordinance or ordinances of the City, now or hereafter in force and effect, to make a connection for sewer service to any such lateral sewer, shall pay to the City, and the City shall collect, both said house service fees or charges and the connection or tapping fee prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof at the time the connection permit is issued. 
For the purposes of this subsection (B), where the width from property line to property line of any public street, thoroughfare or place is established or shown by or is described in or appears upon or from any recorded or unrecorded deed, other conveyance or any subdivision or other plat, conveying title to or an easement for any such public street, thoroughfare or place or dedicating or offering to dedicate to public use any such public street, thoroughfare or place, the width of such street, thoroughfare or public place shall be the width thereof as so established or shown by or described in or as appears upon or from such deed, conveyance or plat. Where the width of any such street, thoroughfare or place is not so established, shown or described, and does not so appear, then for such purposes the width of such street, thoroughfare or place shall be found, declared and established by the City Council of the City from such relevant evidence as may be available or be presented to the City Council, including but not limited to the apparent width of such street, thoroughfare or place, the location and extent of the paved, hard-surfaced or main traveled portion or portions thereof and of the shoulders, drainage ditches, curbs, gutters and sidewalks or sidewalk areas thereof, the location of telephone or electric poles and lines and of gas lines, sewers of any kind and other public utility distribution or service facilities thereon or therein, the visible indication or indications of the property lines on each side of such street, thoroughfare or place, and any other relevant facts and circumstances indicating the width of such street, thoroughfare or place between such property lines; and owners of property or properties abutting on any such street, thoroughfare or place or to be served by the lateral sewer proposed to be constructed and installed in such street, thoroughfare or place shall be afforded an opportunity to be present, and to offer evidence and to be heard as to the width of such street, thoroughfare or place, at a public hearing to be held by the City Council at a time and place to be fixed by the City Council and notice of the holding of which shall be published in the form and as directed by the City Council at least once in a newspaper published or of general circulation in the City at least ten days prior to the day of holding such hearing, before the City Council's finding, declaration and establishment of the width of such street, thoroughfare or place shall be final and binding upon such property owners; provided of course, however, that nothing herein provided shall prevent the determination of the width of any such street, thoroughfare or place by written agreement and consent of all the owners of such property or, as to any individual owner, by written agreement with and consent of such individual owner. 
Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions of this subsection (B) and whenever for any reason the owners of properties abutting on a public street or streets or other public thoroughfare or thoroughfares or place or places within the corporate limits of the City are unwilling to file, or fail to file, a petition pursuant to the provision of this subsection (B), or shall file such petition which the City Council shall find to be unacceptable to it under said subsection (B), the City Council on its own initiative may by resolution authorize and direct the construction and installation of a lateral sanitary sewer in such street or streets, other public thoroughfare or thoroughfares or place or places to serve such properties abutting thereon and other properties if any which the City Council in said resolution may find can conveniently be served and shall direct to be served by such sewer, and the City Council in such resolution or by subsequent resolution shall, in accordance with the schedule of house service fees or charges hereinabove in this subsection (B) set forth, fix the amount of the house service fee or charge to be collected by the City from, and to be paid by, the owner or owners of each such property, or the successor or successors in title or interest of such owner or owners, as the case may be, in addition to the connection or tapping fee prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof, at and prior to actual connection for sewer service to such sewer, whether such owner or owners or successor or successors in title or interest request or are required pursuant to the provisions of any ordinance or ordinances of the City, now or hereafter in force and effect, to make connection for sewer service to such sewer. 
(C)  Where any lateral sanitary sewer has heretofore been, is now being, or is hereafter, constructed and installed in any public street or streets, road or roads, highway or highways, other thoroughfare or thoroughfares or place or places located outside the corporate limits of the City, no owner or owners of property or properties shall be permitted to make connection for sewer service to, or to receive sewer service through, any such lateral sanitary sewer without first paying to the City a house service fee or charge in the amount of $450.00 with respect to each such property to be connected to said sewer, which house service fee or charge shall be in addition to the connecting or tapping fee prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof, and which connection or tapping fee shall be paid by the property owner or owners prior to the time of actual connection for sewer service. 
(D)  Where lateral sewers and sanitary house service sewers to property served or to be served by any such lateral sewers are constructed and installed, in a subdivision at the cost of the subdivider or subdividers or developer or developers of such subdivision, owners of property applying for a permit for sanitary sewer service connection to such sewers shall be required to pay, and the City shall collect from such property owners, only the connection or tapping fee for each connection prescribed in subsection (A)(1) hereof. 
If any person obtaining a permit to connect with the sanitary sewer system of the City shall, within two years after the date of the issuance of such permit, fail to request the City to make the sewer connection covered thereby, and if in the meantime the applicable connection or tapping fee and the applicable house service or charge if any prescribed by this section shall be increased, then such permit shall be null, void and of no further force and effect, unless such person shall pay to the City such additional amount which, together with the amount already paid, will equal such increased connection or tapping fee and such increased house service fee or charge if any required to be paid. 
For the purposes of this section, a "lateral sewer" is defined to be a sanitary sewer constructed and installed in, under and along any public street, thoroughfare or place for the purpose of collecting and carrying sewage flowing therein from house service sewers, connecting properties abutting on such street, thoroughfare or place and other property if any served or to be served by such lateral sewer, to such lateral sewer; and a "house service sewer" is defined to be a sanitary sewer extending from the property line of any such property to a lateral sewer. 
Nothing herein provided shall be held or construed to obligate the City and its City Council upon petition of property owners or upon its own initiative or otherwise, to construct and install any sanitary lateral sewer in any public street, road, highway, thoroughfare or place, but whether or not such lateral sewer shall be constructed and installed shall be a matter to be determined in the sole discretion of the City Council. 
And nothing herein provided shall be held or construed in any wise or to any extent to modify, change, amend or otherwise affect the subdivision regulations or other rules and regulations of the City, now or hereafter from time to time in force and effect, relating to the installation and construction of water mains, lines and facilities and of sanitary sewers and other sewage facilities in any subdivision or subdivisions now being or hereafter developed, whether within or without the corporate limits of the City; but such subdivision regulations and such other rules and regulations, as now or hereafter from time to time in force and effect, shall govern and be applicable to the installation and construction of such mains, lines and facilities and of such sanitary sewers and other sanitary sewage facilities in such subdivisions, including the amount or amounts to be contributed and paid by the developer or developers of such subdivisions towards, or for the payment of, the costs of such installation and construction. 
(E)  Notwithstanding subsections (B) and (C) of this section, the same shall not be held or construed in any wise or to any extent to affect or to apply to any sanitary sewer heretofore or hereafter installed and constructed in any subdivision and paid for in whole or in part by the developer of such subdivision. 
(Ord. of 06-20-28 § 2; Code 1949, ch. 26 § 12; Ord. of 08-23-62 § 1; Ord. of 10-03-63 § 1; Ord. of 06-08-67 § 1; Ord. of 05-16-68 § 4; Ord. of 12-11-69 § 1; Ord. No. 77-8 § 1, 03-22-77; Ord. No. 91-44 § 1, 08-01-91; Ord. No. 91-47 § 2, 09-12-91; Ord. No. 92-20 § 2, 03-26-92; Ord. No. 92-O-11 §§ 1, 2, 12-03-92; Ord. No. 93-O-17 § 1, 05-13-93; Ord. No. 93-O-26 § 2, 08-12-93; Ord. No. 16-O-65 , § 4, 1-5-17; Ord. No. 18-O-23 , §§ 3-5, 5-10-18) 
Section 33-51 - Reduction in charges for water excluded from sewerage system. 
(A)  In the event that it is established to the satisfaction of the Department that all or a portion of the water consumed does not and cannot enter the public sanitary sewerage system, then such water not reaching the system may be excluded from the computation of the charge for sewerage service. In such event the Department shall require the installation of an additional meter at the customer's or interested party's expense in such a manner as to measure the quantity of water actually excluded from the public sanitary sewerage system. All outlets for such water shall be consolidated and measured by one single meter at a location satisfactory to the Department. All repairs thereto shall be made at the expense of the owner or interested party. 
(B)  Eligibility. 
(1)  Customers are eligible for the adjustment of monthly sewer charges in only the following circumstances: 
(a)  the average amount of water diverted by an industry equals a minimum of 112,500 gallons per month for a 12-month period; or, 
(b)  the customer is a municipal golf course; or, 
(c)  customers are eligible for the adjustment of monthly sewer charges in only the following circumstances: the customer is a residential or commercial customer who uses extra water for lawn or garden irrigation purposes and satisfies the requirements herein. The reduction period will be only for the months of April, May, June, July, August, September and October. If the consumption for a said month exceeds 120% of the monthly winter average calculated by averaging the months of November through March less the high and the low months, the customer shall not be charged sewer charges on the excess. If the customer does not have a consumption for winter average calculation as set forth above herein, the consumption average for the customer's category plus 20% shall be used and 6,750 gallons shall be used as an average for residential applicants; or 
(d)  the commercial or residential customer has and utilizes a separate water meter for an irrigation system. 
(e)  any "water only" customer who has public sewer available (within 200 ft. of the property line) shall be entitled to the credit provided in (c) above during only the months of June, July, August and September. 
For the purpose of this section, "commercial" is defined as nonresidential, except for multifamily, and non-industrial business enterprises. 
(C)  In the event that the Department finds it is not practical to measure the flow of diverted water, the Director, at its discretion, approve some other manner of computing or estimating the amount of water diverted from the public sanitary sewerage system. 
(D)  Customers requesting consideration from a reduction in sewerage service charges because of water excluded from the public sanitary sewerage system shall make written application to the Department for such consideration, giving their name, address, account number and supporting data fully describing all sources of water, as well as the disposition of water alleged not to be entering the public sanitary sewerage system. The application shall be accompanied by a sketch to approximate scale showing the plan of the property, water distribution system, sewer, layout, points of connection to the sewer system, existing meters and proposed meter and the scheme proposed for determining the quantity of water entering the public sanitary sewerage system and that flow excluded from the sanitary sewerage system. 
(E)  In the event the customer modifies the system without the prior written consent and approval of the Department, the Department may in its discretion permanently terminate the customer's right to the exclusion provided for in this section. In like manner, if the Department determines that the customer has tampered with the meters or bypassed the meters, or in any way abused the right granted under this section, the Department may in its discretion permanently terminate the customer's right for a reduction in charges provided for in this section. 
(F)  By making such application the applicant hereby consents to the City making inspections without prior notice. 
(Ord. of 09-30-71 § 1; Ord. No. 89-37 § 1, 08-17-89; Ord. No. 93-O-26 § 1, 08-12-93; Ord. No. 97-O-23 § 1, 05-29-97; Ord. No. 01-O-14 § 1, 03-22-01; Ord. No. 17-O-15 , § 6, 5-18-17) 
Section 33-52 - Disputed bill or action. 
(A)  Any customer who disputes the accuracy of the bill or any action of the Water Resources Department under the terms and provisions of this article shall be entitled to review of the bill or action, provided the request for a hearing is made on or before the due date of the disputed bill. 
(B)  Hearings on disputed bills or actions of the Department under this article will be held by appointment at the offices of the Department between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. any business day. 
(C)  A customer requesting a hearing has the right to examine the records of the Department pertaining to that customer's service. 
(D)  A customer requesting a hearing has the right to have a representative at the hearing, to testify and to present witnesses. 
(E)  Hearings will be conducted by an authorized counselor duly appointed by the Department. The authorized counselor will hear the evidence and render a decision. 
(F)  If the customer believes the decision of the counselor is in error and requests an appeal hearing in writing by noon of the third business day next following, or if the counselor desires to refer the matter to a higher level, a hearing will be conducted by the Director of the Department. The Director will hear the evidence and render a decision. If the customer is still not satisfied with the decision, the customer may appear before the Water Resources Board at a regular monthly Board meeting, who will hear the evidence and render a final decision, provided a written appeal is filed by noon of the third business day next following. 
(G)  The customer's service will not be terminated until an appropriate decision is reached. 
(H)  The customer has the right to a post termination of service hearing under the above procedures if there was no hearing before termination, if the customer requests such post termination of service hearing by noon of the third business day following such termination. 
(I)  A copy of the above hearing appeal procedures will be posted in the office of the Department at the immediate location where customers pay bills. 
(Ord. No. 90-47 § 22, 10-11-90; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Sections 33-53-33-100 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Section 33-101 - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to conserve the water supply of the City for the greatest public benefit with particular regard to public health, fire protection and domestic use, and to conserve water by reducing waste during a water shortage emergency. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80) 
Section 33-102 - Waste of water prohibited; penalty for violation. 
(A)  No water furnished by the City shall be wasted. Waste of water includes, but is not necessarily limited to the following: 
(1)  permitting water to escape down a gutter, ditch or other surface drain; 
(2)  failure to repair a controllable leak of water; and 
(3)  failure to put to reasonable beneficial use any water withdrawn from the City's system. 
(B)  Any violation of this provision shall be punished in accordance with Code § 33-108, provided the violation occurs during any period that has been declared a water shortage emergency. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 01-O-72 § 1, 10-18-01) 
Section 33-103 - Declaration of water shortage emergency by Mayor. 
(A)  The Mayor may declare a water shortage emergency irrespective of whether the City water supply has reached water shortage emergency level 1 or 2. The Mayor may declare an end to a water shortage emergency. 
(B)  Water shortage emergency level 1 is when the water level in Walter Hill Reservoir drops more than two feet below the dam crest, or when the water level supply from Percy Priest Lake is interrupted or not available, or whenever the water level in two or more of the distribution reservoirs cannot be brought above the two-thirds full mark in a 48-hour period. When the water supply reaches water shortage emergency level 1, the Mayor, upon the recommendation of the Director of the Water Resources Department, may declare any or all of the uses of water identified as nonessential use category 1 and said prohibition shall remain in full force and effect until the next meeting of the City Council. The list of nonessential uses may be increased or decreased pending the next meeting of the City Council. 
(C)  Water shortage emergency level 2 is when water level in the Walter Hill Reservoir drops more than five feet below the crest of the dam, or when the water supply from Percy Priest Lake is interrupted or not available, or the water level in two or more of the distribution reservoirs cannot be brought above the one-quarter full mark within a 48-hour period. If water shortage emergency level 2 is reached, the Mayor, upon recommendation of the Director of the Department, may declare any or all of the nonessential uses provided for in this article as being prohibited and the same shall remain in full force and effect until the next meeting of the City Council. The Mayor may increase or decrease the number of prohibited nonessential uses pending the next meeting of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 01-O-72 § 2, 10-18-01; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-104 - Nonessential uses during water shortage emergency. 
(A)  Declaration by Mayor. The Mayor, in the Mayor's discretion, may declare a water shortage emergency and request voluntary conservation of water. 
(B)  Nonessential use category 1. The following uses are declared to be nonessential uses, category 1: 
(1)  Washing sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other exterior paved areas, except by the City for the public safety. 
(2)  Filling or refilling a swimming pool. 
(3)  Noncommercial washing of privately owned motor vehicles, trailers and boats. 
(4)  Any use of water from a fire hydrant except for fighting fires, or use by the City. 
(5)  Watering of lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs or other plants. 
(6)  Watering any portion of a golf course. 
(7)  Use of water for dust control or compaction during construction. 
(C)  Nonessential use category 2. The following uses are declared to be nonessential uses, category 2: 
(1)  Use by a laundromat in excess of 70% of the amount of water used by it during the corresponding billing period for the previous year. If the laundromat was not operating the previous year, an assumed amount shall be computed by the City from its records. 
(2)  Use by a motor vehicle washing facility in excess of 70% of the amount used by it during the corresponding billing period the previous year. If the facility was not operating the previous year, an assumed amount shall be computed by the City from its records. This subsection shall not apply to any facility that recycles water in a manner satisfactory to the Water Resources Department and has received written approval and exemption from this subsection. 
(3)  Any nonresidential use in excess of 70% of the amount used by the customer during the corresponding billing period for the previous year. If the customer was not operating the previous year, an assumed amount shall be computed by the City from its records. The Director of the Department, with the concurrence of the City Manager, may increase the percentage for any connection use or customer if it is determined that such increase is necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare or to spread equitably among the water users of the City the burden imposed by the shortage in the City's water supply. 
(D)  Nonessential use category 3. The following uses are declared to be nonessential uses, category 3: 
(1)  Schools and industry. Discretion may be used in selecting schools and industries to be closed, based upon the amount of water used and anticipated to be saved by closing same. Industries which use a negligible amount of water should not be closed. Industries with a large process of water needs may contribute substantially to the conservation effort by closing same. Specifically, the guidelines for closing schools and industry shall be in accordance with the foregoing and summarized as follows: 
(a)  close only those customers where a significant water saving would be involved; 
(b)  try to arrange a long weekend shut down or a shortened work week so that a minimum disruption would result; and, 
(c)  if possible, employ a selective rotation of industry shut down so that no one industry has to bear the major part of the conservation effort. 
(2)  Use in any dwelling or separate residential unit in excess of 50 gallons per day for each permanent resident thereof. Each customer of the City shall on the request of the Director of the Department certify in writing under penalty of perjury the number of permanent residents of each dwelling or separate residential unit billed to the customer. If the customer fails to furnish such certification, the City will assume there is one permanent resident in each such dwelling or residential unit. 
(3)  Any nonresidential use in excess of 50% of the amount used by the customer during the corresponding billing period for the previous year. If the customer was not operating the previous year, an assumed amount shall be computed by the City from its records. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 01-O-72 § 3, 10-18-01; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-105 - City Council action. 
(A)  The City Council may declare a water shortage emergency irrespective of whether the water supply has reached water shortage emergency level 1 or 2. Only the City Council may terminate or end a water shortage emergency declared by the City Council. 
(B)  The City Council may prohibit any nonessential use, category 1, during any period that a water shortage emergency has been declared, irrespective of whether the water shortage has reached water shortage emergency level 1 or not. 
(C)  The City Council may prohibit any nonessential use when the water supply of the City has reached the water shortage emergency level 1. 
(D)  Any water shortage emergency declared by the Mayor shall continue until the next meeting of the City Council. If the City Council does not take action to terminate the water shortage emergency, the same shall continue in full force and effect. The City Council may terminate or modify any limitations on nonessential use of water. 
(E)  In the absence of affirmative action by the City Council, the action of the Mayor shall be final, (subject to the right to a hearing provided for in Code § 33-107; the hearing provisions of Code § 33-107 shall be applicable to the action of the City Council). 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80) 
Section 33-106 - Notice of water shortage and prohibited uses. 
Upon the declaration of the existence of a water shortage emergency by the Mayor or City Council, the City Manager shall notify the local newspapers, cable TV government channels, City web site and radio stations and furnish detailed information concerning the existence of the water shortage emergency and all prohibited uses. In addition, a newspaper ad shall be published on three successive days in any local daily newspaper informing the public of the water shortage emergency and any prohibition concerning the nonessential uses. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 01-O-72 § 4, 10-18-01) 
Section 33-107 - Right to hearing. 
(A)  Any customer of the City who feels that the customer or the customer's business has been aggrieved by the prohibition against a nonessential use shall have the right to a hearing before the Water Resources Board, or before a committee of three appointed by the Board. 
(B)  Any such hearing shall occur within 24 hours of a request. Any person aggrieved may appeal the decision to the Mayor and City Council of the City or to a board appointed by the Mayor and City Council for hearing same. 
(C)  Any person requesting a hearing before the Board or the committee appointed by same, shall be exempt from the prohibition against the nonessential use pending the results of said hearing, provided the water level has not reached water shortage emergency level 1. If the Board or its committee rules against the customer, the prohibition shall remain in full force and effect although appealed to the City Council. Witnesses may be subpoenaed for either hearing by the same process as witnesses are subpoenaed to City Court. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-108 - Violations. 
(A)  Notice of Violation. If a person or customer violates Code § 33-102 or violates a prohibition against a nonessential use during a water shortage emergency as provided for in Code §§ 33-103, 33-104, and 33-105, a written notice shall be placed on the property where the violation occurred, personally delivered or mailed to the person who is regularly billed for the service where the violation occurs. 
(B)  Contents of Notice of Violation. Said notice shall describe the violation and order that it be corrected, cured or abated immediately or within such specified time as the Director of the Water Resources Department or City Manager determines is reasonable under the circumstances, taking into consideration the public health, safety and welfare. 
(C)  Failure to follow order, disconnection of service. If the order is not followed, the City may forthwith disconnect the service where the violation occurs. The customer shall be entitled to a hearing as set forth in Code § 33-107. 
(D)  Hearing. If the water level has not reached water shortage emergency level 1, the hearing may be requested and the service continued pending the hearing. If the water level has reached water shortage emergency level 1, water service may be discontinued, pending the hearing although a hearing is requested. After the notice is given to a customer of a violation, the customer must request a hearing within 48 hours of the notice being posted on the property or receipt of the notice, whichever is the first to occur. If no hearing is requested in said period, the provisions outlined in the notice are final and unappealable. 
(E)  Reconnection fee; statement of compliance. Any service disconnected pursuant to subsection (C) hereof and who is not completely vindicated by a hearing, (provided a hearing is timely requested), shall pay a reconnection fee of $50.00 and execute a written statement by said customer that compliance will be made with the prohibition of nonessential uses as provided for during the water shortage emergency then existing. 
(Ord. No. 80-21 § 1, 07-31-80; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-109 - Double water charge during emergency. 
Any customer who registers an average daily use of water, during a period when a water shortage emergency has been declared by the Mayor or City Council, which is greater than the customer's average daily use for the previous 12 full months (12 water readings), shall be charged for the water at double the rate then in effect for the same quantity of water. This shall not apply to the charge for sewer. If the customer was not operating the previous year, an assumed amount shall be computed by the City from its records, based upon actual use since said customer was a customer of the City. 
(Ord. No. 80-22 § 1, 08-14-80) 
Sections 33-110-33-199 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SANITARY SEWER SPECIAL ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS 

Section 33-200 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-O-43 , § 1, adopted August 16, 2018, repealed § 33-200, which pertained to Compton Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sections 33-201, 33-202 - Reserved. 
Section 33-203 - Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District. 
(A)  The City hereby creates a sanitary sewer special assessment district called "Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District" in order to recoup funds expended for construction and installation costs of the Overall Creek sewage additions, providing sanitary sewer service to the properties shown on Map No. 33-203, copies of which are on file with the City Recorder and Director of the Water Resources Department. 
In addition to the properties shown on Map No. 33-203, any residence, business, or other improvements constructed in the future that has sanitary sewer discharge into the sewer constructed in the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District shall pay $1,000.00 per single family unit or its equivalent as defined in Code § 33-50(A)(2) for sewer connections. The Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District assessment shall remain in effect until such date as the City shall determine and declare that it has been repaid for all development costs for the improvements. 
EXCLUSIONS: Any customer of the Department shall be excluded from the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District if it is determined by the Director of the Department or designee that the sewage from the property does not discharge into the Overall Creek sewerage system. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Rutherford County Blackman School Complex site shall be excluded from the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District since the sellers have previously paid a sum to the City as a special assessment for the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District. 
(B)  Each applicant for sanitary sewer service in the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District shall tender and pay to the City prior to connection for such service, the sewer connection and tapping fee prescribed in Code § 33-50(A)(1) as amended, plus the outside house service charge prescribed in Code § 33-50(C), if applicable, and an additional special sewer area charge of $1,000.00 per single family unit or its equivalent as defined in Code § 33-50(A)(2) for sewer connections in the future, in addition to all other applicable sewer connection or sewer service fees. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the City may impose additional charges associated with construction of sewer laterals to connect property to the sewer trunk line. 
(C)  Additional charges for other uses shall from time to time be fixed and established by the City Council upon recommendation of the Water Resources Board, shall also be paid and collected before connection for sewer service. 
(D)  Persons owning and/or occupying property which is accessible to the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer System as defined in Code § 16-28 shall be exempt from monthly sewer service charges until such time physical connection is made to a sanitary sewer or the Overall Creek Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District ends as provided in (A) above. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-39 § 1, 08-12-99; Ord. No. 01-O-71 § 4, 10-18-01; Ord. No. 15-O-13 § 1, 03-19-15; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-204 - Reserved. 
Section 33-205 - Salem Highway and Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District. 
(A)  The City hereby creates a sanitary sewer special assessment district called "Salem Highway and Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District" in order to recoup funds expended for construction and installation costs of the Salem Highway and Barfield Road sewage additions, providing sanitary sewer service to the properties shown on Map No. 33-205, copies of which are on file with the City Recorder and Director of the Water Resources Department. 
In addition to the properties shown on Map No. 33-205, any residence, business, or other improvements constructed in the future that has sanitary sewer discharge into the sewer constructed in the Salem Highway and Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District shall pay $750.00 per single family unit or its equivalent as defined in Code § 33-50(A)(2) for sewer connections. The Salem Highway and Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District assessment shall remain in effect until such date as the City shall determine and declare that it has been repaid for all development costs for the improvements. 
EXCLUSIONS: Any customer of the Department shall be excluded from the Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District if it is determined by the Director of the Department or designee that the sewage from the property served does not discharge into the Barfield Road sewerage system. 
(B)  Each applicant for sanitary sewer service in the Salem Highway and Barfield Road Sanitary Sewer Special Assessment District shall tender and pay to the City prior to connection for such service, the sewer connection and tapping fee prescribed in Code § 33-50(A)(1) as amended, plus the outside house service charge prescribed in Code § 33-50(C), if applicable, and an additional special sewer area charge of $750.00 per single family unit or its equivalent as defined in Code § 33-50(A)(2) for sewer connections in the future, in addition to all other applicable sewer connection or sewer service fees. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the City may impose additional charges associated with construction of sewer laterals to connect property to the sewer trunk line. 
(C)  Additional charges for other uses fixed and established from time to time by the City Council, upon recommendation of the Water Resources Board, shall also be paid and collected before connection for sewer service.

ARTICLE VII. - REPURIFIED WATER 

Section 33-300 - General. 
(A)  Definitions. 
(1)  Customer shall mean the person or legal entity who owns property to which repurified water service is to be, or is being, provided. Because of the variety of infrastructure and use issues arising with repurified water, the owner of the property is required to complete the application and agreement for service. If a person other than the owner is to be billed for the monthly service charge and the repurified water usage, both the owner and the other person must complete the application and agreement. The owner and the other person will collectively be the customer and both will be required to follow the terms and conditions of this ordinance and the agreement. 
(2)  MWSD shall mean the City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee, Water Resources Department. 
(3)  Repurified water shall mean the highly treated reclaimed water produced at the Joe W. Lovell Water Quality Control Center. The product has been subjected to physical and biochemical processes, and has been filtered and disinfected with both ultraviolet light and chlorine prior to being introduced into a dedicated distribution system. While not intended for human or animal consumption, this water is suitable for a number of domestic, commercial and industrial applications, as established by the City. 
(B)  Use of repurified water regulated. All persons using repurified water produced by the City shall comply with all relevant provisions of City ordinances and MWSD policies and standards relating to potable water, repurified Water Resourcesage systems of the City. 
(C)  Use of repurified water required. Repurified water shall be utilized for irrigation and may be utilized for other approved uses as established by policies adopted by MWSD. The use of potable water by customers of MWSD for irrigation shall be discontinued within 90 days of repurified water becoming available. Available shall mean that a repurified water distribution line is located in a street, alley, right-of-way, easement or other public property abutting on the property in question. 
(D)  Infrastructure. All lines and appurtenances dedicated to public use shall be located in public right-of ways or easements approved by the City. Such lines and appurtenances and easements shall become the property of the MWSD, and shall be maintained by MWSD. The construction of all repurified water lines shall be in accordance with the requirements and policies of the City. 
(E)  The City Council, after receiving a recommendation from the Water & Sewer Board, shall by resolution establish and from time to time adjust rates, fees, charges and credits for the repurified water system. 
(F)  The Board shall adopt policies and regulations for the repurified water system and the use of repurified water. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-55 § 1, 09-15-05; Ord. No. 18-O-47 , § 7, 8-16-18) 
Section 33-301 - Conditions for repurified water service. 
(A)  Compliance with regulations. Repurified water is subject to a variety of federal, state and local regulations to protect the safety of the public and the integrity of both the potable and repurified water systems. Customer agrees to comply with any federal, state and local laws, regulations and standards that may apply the customer's use of repurified water. Such laws, regulations and standards may include: 
(1)  requirements and restrictions governing the use of repurified water; 
(2)  application methods that reasonably preclude certain kinds of human contact with repurified water; 
(3)  controlled access to the repurified water, its delivery system, storage and use; 
(4)  requirements to prevent repurified water from standing on open access areas during normal periods of use; 
(5)  requirements to prevent repurified water from coming into contact with drinking fountains, water coolers or eating areas; and, 
(6)  requirements to identify certain components of the delivery system, or to provide public notice or signage that repurified water is used on the customer's premises. 
(B)  Compliance with agreement. A repurified water customer agreement establishes the terms and conditions that apply to the ultimate consumer of the City's repurified water. No repurified water service of the City may be connected or served until the following conditions are met: 
(1)  a complete agreement and application for repurified water is executed by the owner of the property and, if different from the owner, the user; 
(2)  MWSD and the customer agree on the use site; MWSD agrees to deliver repurified water to a meter at the customer's property line at the designated use site and the customer agrees that repurified water will be stored and/or used exclusively at the designated use site; 
(3)  customer may not resell repurified water, and is prohibited from conveying repurified water delivered under this agreement to any other premises or location not specified in the application; 
(4)  the MWSD repurified water distribution system terminates at the meter. The Customer is solely responsible for any on site costs arising from the construction, maintenance or operation of the on site portion of the system; and, 
(5)  credit toward usage rates may be given for initial site capital costs in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees and charges established by the City Council. 
(C)  Color coding. The use of color code Pantone Purple 522C is required for all public repurified water lines, valves and outlets and appurtenances, and is strongly recommended for distribution and application facilities located on private properties. If distribution and application facilities located on private property are not color coded Pantone Purple 522C, they must be labeled in a MWSD approved manner which adequately identifies the water as non-potable. 
(D)  Hose bibs. Customer specifically agrees not to install hose bibs, except as allowed by City policy, on any component of the repurified water delivery system. 
(E)  Signage. Customer is responsible for posting and maintaining signs that will inform the public that repurified water is being used on the customer's premises. Such signage shall conform to the policies of the City. Customer may also be responsible for posting other signage that may be required by the State of Tennessee. 
(F)  Cross-connection control. Repurified water is designated as a non-potable water supply. Since it is virtually impossible to distinguish repurified water from drinking water by sight or scent, it is important to maintain complete separation of the repurified water and potable water systems. To accomplish this goal, the provisions of the cross connection control program as outlined in Chapter 33, Article II, Sections 33-18 through 33-22 shall apply. At a minimum, a reduced pressure backflow prevention device shall be required on the potable water supply for the site served with repurified water. Cross connection protection may be required on the repurified system. MWSD shall determine the required level of protection based on the potential risk. 
(G)  Inspection. Customer agrees that the City or any other public agency with the authority to verify compliance with the repurified water use regulation may inspect the customer's premises to verify compliance with applicable laws and regulations. Customer further acknowledges the responsibility and obligation to inform MWSD of certain activities relating to the construction, maintenance and operation of its private repurified water system, including, but not necessarily limited to, materials, construction or modification, testing, violations and emergency situations. 
(H)  Plans. Customer acknowledges the responsibility to maintain a copy of the on site repurified water system plans at the premises where the water is being used. 
(I)  Potential Disruption of Service. Customer accepts the possibility that MWSD may be required to disrupt repurified water service or to reduce pressure due to emergency conditions, peak demands, or planned system maintenance. MWSD will not be responsible for any damage or loss that may be sustained because of any interruption of service. 
(J)  Emergency terminations. When there is an unforeseen emergency, MWSD may terminate delivery of repurified water without notice. When notice of an emergency is given, customer shall reduce or cease usage of repurified water. 
(K)  Cessation or reduction in use. In order to accommodate peak demands or planned maintenance, MWSD shall provide the customer with 24-hour notice of the need to cease or reduce repurified water usage. Upon receipt of such notice, customer shall comply with the notice. 
(L)  Transfer of property. Customer agrees that all leases of the premises subject to the agreement for repurified water service shall be in writing and must be made expressly subject to the agreement. Should the customer sell or otherwise transfer ownership or control of the premises described herein to a third party, MWSD shall not be obligated to provide repurified water to any subsequent owner or customer unless such sale or disposal incorporates the agreement by reference, and makes any successors and assigns expressly subject to the agreement. If such third party disposition does not include such provisions, customer will close its account with MWSD and pay any fees or charges incurred by customer before the disposition of the property is effective. 
(M)  Termination of service. Customer acknowledges that potable water, repurified water and sewer service may be discontinued for failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the agreement for repurified water service, including, but not limited to, failure to pay for potable water, repurified water or sewer services provided by MWSD. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-55 § 1, 09-15-05) 
Section 33-302 - Discontinuance of service for failure to pay bill. 
If any person shall fail to pay their bill for potable water, repurified water or sewer service by the due date shown on such bill, MWSD may cut off and disconnect repurified water from the premises of the person owning or controlling the property to which such bill relates, and water shall remain cut off and disconnected from such premises until bill shall be paid. 
If the water shall be so cut off or disconnected, the same rules that apply for disconnection and reconnection of potable water as set forth in § 33-3 shall apply. 
If any check is returned by any bank for any reason, there shall be a service charge as set forth in § 33-3. If service is discontinued due to failure by the customer to make satisfactory restitution for said check, the reconnection fee described in the preceding paragraph shall apply. 
MWSD shall not be liable for any damages resulting from discontinuance of service for failure to pay bill, or from delay in reconnection of service. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-55 § 1, 09-15-05) 
Section 33-303 - Tapping mains without permission; using unmetered water; tampering with meters, etc.; interfering with installation, operation, etc., of meter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(A)  To make a tap or connection with any repurified water main of the City or with any pipe connected with any such repurified water main, without first obtaining the consent of MWSD; 
(B)  To take, use or consume any repurified water from any such water main or any pipe connected with any such repurified water main, unless such repurified water is regularly metered by a water meter installed, or the installation of which has been approved, by MWSD; 
(C)  To tamper in any manner with any such meter, including all fittings and fixtures thereon and connection thereto, or in any respect with the regularly approved installation of same; or, 
(D)  By the installation or use of any pipe, by-pass, cut-off or other device or by other means whatsoever, to interfere in any manner with the approved installation of any such meter or with the normal operation of any such meter or with the normal registration thereon and thereby of the quantity of water consumed. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-55 § 1, 09-15-05) 
Section 33-304 - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be penalized as provided in Code § 1-8. 
In addition, whenever it has been determined that an illegal connection has been made, MWSD shall charge the owner of the property any costs associated with removing the connection. 
(Ord. No. 05-O-55 § 1, 09-15-05) 
Sections 33-305-33-399 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HUMAN EXCRETA DISPOSAL 

Section 33-400 - Definitions. 
The following definitions and terms shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
"Accessible sewer." A public sanitary sewer located in a street, alley, right-of-way, easement or other public property abutting on the property in question. 
"Approved septic tank system." A watertight covered receptacle of monolithic concrete, either precast or cast in place, constructed according to plans approved by the City Health Officer. Such tanks shall have a capacity of not less than 750 gallons, and, in the case of homes with more than two bedrooms, the capacity of the tank shall be in accordance with the recommendations of the Tennessee Department of Public Health as provided for in their 1958 bulletin entitled "Recommended Construction of Septic Tanks and Disposal Fields for Residential Uses." A minimum liquid depth of four feet should be provided with a minimum depth of air space above the liquid of one foot. The septic tank dimensions should be such that the length from inlet to outlet is at least twice but not more than three times the width. The liquid depth should not exceed five feet. The discharge from the septic tank shall be disposed of in such a manner that it may not create a nuisance on the surface of the ground or pollute the underground water supply, and such disposal shall be in accordance with recommendations of the City Health Officer as determined by acceptable soil percolation data. 
"Health Officer." The person duly appointed to such position having jurisdiction, or any person authorized to act as the Health Officer's agent. 
"Human excreta." The bowel and kidney discharges of human beings. 
"Other approved methods of sewage disposal." Any privy chemical toilet, or other toilet device (other than a sanitary sewer, septic tank, or sanitary pit privy as described above) the type, location and construction of which have been approved by the City Health Officer. 
"Sanitary pit privy." A privy having a flytight floor and seat over an excavation in earth, 42 inches square and four feet deep, located and constructed in such a manner that flies and animals will be excluded, surface water may not enter the pit, and danger of pollution of the surface of the ground or the underground water supply will be prevented. 
"Sewage." All water-carried waste from residences, buildings, or industrial establishments. 
"Watercourse." Any natural or artificial drain which conveys water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. of 10-05-39 § 3; 1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 8; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 05-O-48 § 1, 08-25-05; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-401 - Sanitary method for disposal of sewage and human excreta. 
Every residence, building, or place where human beings reside, assemble, or are employed within the corporate limits or the police jurisdiction of the City shall be required to have a sanitary method for disposal of sewage and human excreta as required by this article. 
(Ord. of 10-05-39 § 4; 1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 9; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Cross reference- Code § 14-120, pet excrement disposal. 
Section 33-402 - Flush closets where accessible sanitary sewer exists. 
Wherever an accessible sanitary sewer exists and water under pressure is available, flush closets shall be provided, the wastes from such closets shall be discharged through a proper connection to the sanitary sewer, and on any lot or premises provided with a connection to the sanitary sewer, no other method of human excreta disposal shall be employed. 
(Ord. of 10-05-39 § 5; 1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 10; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
State Law reference- T.C.A. §§ 68-221-101-68-221-110. 
Section 33-403 - Disposition of wastes where no sewer available. 
Wherever water-carried sewage facilities are installed and their use is permitted by the City Health Officer, and an accessible sewer does not exist, the wastes from such facilities shall be discharged into an approved septic tank system. 
No septic tank or other water-carried sewage disposal system except a connection to a public sewer shall be installed without the approval of the City Health Officer or a duly appointed representative. The design, layout, and construction of such systems shall be in accordance with specifications approved by the City Health Officer and the installation shall be under the general supervision of the Board of Health. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 31; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; 1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 11; Res. of 12-15-61 § 4; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Editor's note- Resolution of 12-15-61 was a resolution of the Board of Health of Rutherford County, included in this section. 
Cross reference- Code § 33-34, requirements as to private sewage disposal system. 
Section 33-404 - Permit for sewage disposal equipment. 
Every person, firm, or corporation who operates equipment for the purpose of removing digested sludge from septic tanks, cesspools, privies, and other sewage disposal installations on private or public property must register with the City Health Officer and furnish such records of work done within the City as may be deemed necessary by the City Health Officer. 
(Ord. of 10-05-39 § 6; Res. of 12-15-61 § 5; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-405 - Sanitary pit privy. 
Wherever a sanitary method of human excreta disposal is required under Code § 33-401 and water-carried sewage facilities are not used, a sanitary pit privy or other approved method of disposal shall be provided. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 12; Res. of 12-15-61 § 6; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-406 - Approval of facilities by City Health Officer. 
Any person, firm, or corporation proposing to construct a septic tank system, privy or other sewage disposal facility, requiring the approval of the City Health Officer under this regulation, shall before the initiation of construction obtain the approval of the City Health Officer for the design and location of the system and secure a permit from the City Health Officer for such system. 
(Res. of 12-15-61 § 7; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-407 - Duty to provide facilities. 
It shall be the duty of the owner of any property upon which facilities for sanitary sewage or human excreta disposal are required by this article, or the agent of the owner, to provide such facilities. 
(Res. of 12-15-61 § 8; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-408 - Duty of tenant to maintain facilities. 
It shall be the duty of the occupant, tenant, lessee, or other person in charge to maintain the facilities for human excreta disposal in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. No refuse or other material which may unduly fill up, clog, or otherwise interfere with the operation of such facilities shall be deposited therein. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 14; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-409 - Deposit of excreta except in accordance with article prohibited. 
No sewage or human excreta shall be thrown out, deposited, buried, or otherwise disposed of except by a sanitary method of disposal as specified in this article. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 15; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-410 - Deposit of excreta in lake or watercourse. 
No sewage or excreta shall be discharged or deposited into any lake or watercourse except under conditions specified by the City Health Officer and specifically authorized by the Tennessee Stream Pollution Control Board. 
(Res. of 12-15-61 § 11; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-411 - Sewage shall not pollute ground water. 
No sewage, effluent from a septic tank, sewage treatment plant, or discharges from any plumbing facility shall empty into any well, either abandoned or constructed for this purpose, cistern, sinkhole, crevice, ditch, or other opening either natural or artificial in any formation which may permit the pollution of ground water. 
(Res. of 12-15-61 § 12; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-412 - Inspections by City Health Officer; correction of improper condition. 
It shall be the duty of the City Health Officer to make an inspection of the methods of disposal of sewage and human excreta at least once each year. Written or verbal notification of any violation of this article shall be given by the City Health Officer to the person responsible under this article for the correction of the condition, and such correction shall be made within 30 days after notification. If the City Health Officer shall advise any person that the disposal of sewage and human excreta made by such person constitutes an immediate and serious menace to health, such person shall at once take steps to remove the menace, and failure to remove such menace immediately shall constitute a misdemeanor; but such person shall be allowed the number of days herein provided within which to make permanent correction. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 16; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-413 - Failure to correct improper condition; work performed by City. 
If the provisions of this article have not been complied with within 30 days following the date of notification of the violation, the City shall have the right to make or have made such changes or corrections as are deemed necessary by the City Health Officer to meet the requirements of this article. The cost of changes and corrections necessary to meet the provisions of Code § 33-401 and Code § 33-407 shall be charged to the owner. The cost of changes and corrections necessary to meet the provisions of Code § 33-408 shall be charged to the occupant. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 17; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-414 - Carnivals, circuses, and other transient groups. 
Whenever carnivals, circuses, and other transient groups of persons come within the corporate limits of the City, such groups of transients shall provide a sanitary method for disposal of sewerage and human excreta. Failure of a carnival, circus, or other transient group to provide such sanitary method of disposal and to make all reasonable changes and corrections proposed by the City Health Officer shall constitute a violation of this article and a misdemeanor. In these cases, the violator shall not be entitled to the notice of 30 days provided for in Code § 33-412. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 18; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Section 33-415 - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, unless otherwise provided by this chapter, be punished as provided in Code § 1-8. 
(1949 Code, Ch. 13 § 19; Ord. of 03-28-68 § 1; Ord. No. 16-O-23 § 4, 06-16-16) 
Chapter 36 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS 

Section 36-1 - General provisions. 
(A)  Title. This Chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "City Cable Communications Chapter." 
(B)  Effective date. This Chapter shall be and become effective on April 25, 2003, and such date shall be referred to as the effective date of this Chapter. 
(C)  Findings and purpose. The City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee ("City") finds that the further development of cable communications may result in great benefits for the people of the City. The City further finds that public rights-of-way to be used by a franchisee for the operation of a cable system are valuable public property acquired and maintained by the State and the City. The City further finds that the grant of a franchise to use public rights-of-way is a valuable property right without which a franchisee would be required to invest substantial capital. 
(1)  Cable technology is rapidly changing, and cable plays an important role as part of the City's basic infrastructure. Cable communications systems permanently occupy and extensively make use of scarce and valuable public rights-of-way, in a manner different from the way in which the general public uses them. The City finds that public convenience, safety, and general welfare can best be served by establishing regulatory powers vested in the City or such persons as the City so designates to protect the public and to ensure that any cable communications franchise granted is operated in the public interest. 
(2)  Further, it is recognized that cable systems have the capacity to provide not only entertainment and information services to the City's residents, but can provide a variety of broadband, interactive communications services. 
(3)  In light of the foregoing, the following goals, among others, underlie the provisions set forth in this Chapter: 
(a)  Cable service should be available to as many City residents as possible. 
(b)  A cable system should be capable of accommodating both present and reasonably foreseeable future cable-related needs of the City. 
(c)  A cable system should be constructed and maintained during a franchise term so as to maximize the integration of new technology into existing system facilities. 
(d)  A cable system should be responsive to the cable-related needs and interests of the City and its residents and should promote the widest possible diversity of cable services to the public. 
(e)  A cable operator should pay fair and reasonable compensation to the City for the use of local public rights-of-way. 
(4)  The City intends that all provisions set forth in this Chapter be construed to serve the public interest and the foregoing public purposes, and that any Franchise issued pursuant to this Chapter be construed to include the foregoing findings and public purposes as integral parts thereof. 
(D)  Delegation of powers. To the extent permitted by law, the City Council may delegate the performance of any act, duty, or obligation, or the exercise of any power, under this Chapter to any City employee, officer, commission, department or agency. 
(Ord. No. 03-O-10 § 4, 04-10-03) 
Section 36-2 - Definitions and word usage. 
Definitions and usage-General. For the purposes of this Chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and abbreviations shall have the meanings given herein, unless otherwise expressly stated. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense; words in the plural number include the singular number, words in the singular number include the plural number, and the masculine gender includes the feminine gender. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory. The word "may" is permissive. Unless otherwise expressly stated, words not defined herein shall be given the meaning set forth in Title 47 of the United States Code or Title 47 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as amended, and, if not defined in either source, their common and ordinary meaning. 
"Access Channel." Any channel on a cable system set aside by a franchisee for noncommercial educational or noncommercial governmental programming. 
"Affiliate." Any person who owns and controls, is owned and controlled by or is under common ownership and control with a franchisee. 
"Cable Act." The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 U.S.C. §§ 521 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
"Cable Commission." The Murfreesboro Cable Television Commission, its designee or any successor entity. 
"Cable Modem." An electronic device, commonly referred to as such or performing the same functions as an electronic device commonly understood to be a cable modem. 
"Cable Service." One-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming services; and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming services. For purposes of this Chapter, the City acknowledges that as of the effective date there exist ongoing legal proceedings regarding whether cable modem service may be lawfully considered a cable service under federal law. As of the adoption of this Chapter, cable modem services are not considered cable service. As to the definition of cable service, and any inclusion of cable modem service in such service, any franchisee shall agree to comply with future applicable federal or state law or applicable regulations. 
"Cable System or System." A facility consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within the City, but such term does not include (a) a facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; (b) a facility that serves subscribers without using any public rights-of-way; (c) a facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of Section 621(c) of the Cable Act) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; (d) an open video system that complies with 47 U.S.C. § 573; or (e) any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
"Cable Television Coordinator." The individual responsible for assisting the City regarding administration of this Chapter. 
"Channel." The electromagnetic frequency spectrum, which is used in a cable system and, which is capable of delivering a television channel (as such term is defined by the FCC by regulation). 
"City." The City of Murfreesboro, Tennessee, a municipal corporation in the State of Tennessee. 
"City Code." The Murfreesboro City Code, as amended from time to time. 
"Converter." An electronic device which may serve as an interface between a system and a subscriber's television monitor, receiver or other terminal equipment, and which may perform a variety of functions, including signal security, descrambling, frequency conversion and channel selection. 
"City Council." The governing body of the City or its lawful designee. 
"Educational Access Channel or Educational Channel." Any channel on the system designated for noncommercial educational programming. 
"FCC." The Federal Communications Commission, its designee, or any successor governmental entity thereto. 
"Franchise." The nonexclusive authorization or renewal thereof granted pursuant to a franchise agreement to construct, operate and maintain a system along the public rights-of-way within the franchise area. No franchise shall include any license or permit generally required of any person for the privilege of transacting and carrying on business within the City. 
"Franchise Agreement." A contract entered into pursuant to this Chapter between the City and a franchisee that sets forth, the terms and conditions under which a franchise will be granted and exercised. 
"Franchise Area." The area of the City that a franchisee is authorized to serve by its franchise agreement. 
"Franchisee." A natural person, partnership, domestic or foreign corporation, association, joint venture, or organization of any kind that has been granted a franchise by the City. 
"Governmental Access Channel or Governmental Channel." Any channel on the system designated for noncommercial government programming. 
"Gross Revenues." Any and all revenues actually received by the franchisee from the operation of the franchisee's cable system to provide cable services in the franchise area. Gross revenues shall include revenues received by an entity other than the franchisee where necessary to prevent evasion or avoidance of the franchisee's obligation under this franchise to pay the franchise fee. Gross revenues shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee which are imposed directly on any subscriber or user by the state, City, or other governmental unit and which are collected by the franchisee on behalf of said governmental unit. A franchise fee is not such a tax. For purposes of calculating franchise fee payments, for any package which includes cable services and non-cable services or other products, any charges and discounts shall be allocated in a reasonable manner and in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) or other standard industry practices. Franchise fee payments covering periods in which any such aggregated bill is used shall be accompanied by an explanation of such allocation and the amounts so allocated. Any such allocation may be addressed in any audit conducted pursuant to this Chapter.
